headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Nestle to Buy Pfizer’s Infant Nutrition Unit for $11.9 Billion
abstract: The Swiss food giant Nestlé agreed on Monday to buy Pfizer’s infant nutrition business for $11.9 billion to expand its presence in the global baby food market.

headline: A Slimmer DreamWorks Gets a New Financing Deal
abstract: Despite its star founders, Steven Spielberg and Stacey Snider, the company has been struggling as a smaller player in Hollywood.

headline: Pasty-gate and a Series of ‘Own Goals’ Hit Cameron
abstract: It has been one of those weeks for Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain. A string of embarrassing gaffes includes a growing furor over the government’s tax assault on one of the country’s favorite snacks.

headline: Thursday Reading: Heart Attack Survivors May Develop P.T.S.D.
abstract: Heart attack survivors may develop P.T.S.D., playing music on a Kindle reader, your parents still don’t want to live with you and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Futures Regulator Updates Congress on MF Global Inquiry
abstract: Jill Sommers, a Republican member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, testified on Tuesday about potential routes to mounting a civil enforcement action against the bankrupt brokerage firm.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: Round-up of news from across the country.

headline: Citigroup’s Chief Rebuffed on Pay by Shareholders
abstract: Citigroup’s shareholders voted down an endorsement of the bank’s plan to award its chief executive, Vikram Pandit, $15 million in compensation, in a show of frustration about Wall Street pay.

headline: How to Escape a Lowly Socioeconomic Class: Go to College
abstract: How much economic mobility do Americans really have? Are they stuck in the income class they were born to? The answers to these questions depend largely on whether they went to college.

headline: The Upfronts en Español
abstract: Tanzina Vega reports on the growing interes in Latino audiences at this year’s upfront presentation to advertisers.

headline: Consumers Less Happy With BlackBerrys
abstract: A survey of consumer satisfaction among cellphone users found that RIM’s BlackBerry is losing ground. On a scale of up to 100, RIM’s aggregate satisfaction score is lowest, at 69. By contrast Apple, the index leader, scored 83.

headline: How Richer States Finance Poorer Ones
abstract: A plan for helping the indebted nations of the euro zone may find a model in a currency union of a different sort, the United States, an economist writes.

headline: Mitsubishi and Mitsui to Acquire a $2 Billion Stake in Natural Gas Project
abstract: Mitsui and the Mitsubishi Corporation have agreed to buy a combined 14.7 percent stake in an Australian liquefied natural gas project for $2 billion, the latest transaction in the fast-expanding global energy sector.

headline: A Healthy Deal for Airborne
abstract: Schiff Nutrition International has agreed to buy the herbal supplement maker Airborne, majority owned by GF Capital, for $150 million in an all-cash deal.

headline: Ex-Prime Minister of Iceland Convicted on Charge Related to Financial Crisis
abstract: Public opinion has been largely split on whether the case against Geir H. Haarde helped society learn from the missteps of government leaders or amounted to scapegoating.

headline: Verizon to Sell Spectrum if It Can Buy More From Cable Companies
abstract: Verizon Wireless, the nation’s No. 1 carrier, is prepared to sell some parts of its radio spectrum if it is allowed to buy wireless spectrum licenses from cable companies. But carriers constantly warn of a looming spectrum shortage that could affect the speed and reliability of smartphones and tablets. How can there be a shortage if Verizon has some it can sell?

headline: In Military Courts, Considering Alternative Punishment for Troubled Service Members
abstract: A military lawyer argues in a law review article that the military needs to consider alternative sentencing programs for service members with combat-related problems.

headline: The Monaco Grand Prix: Be Still My Racing Heart
abstract: It is, arguably, the most challenging track of the season, though not the fastest, through the narrow streets of this fairytale principality above the gleaming Mediterranean.

headline: Indian Companies Spend Overseas for Growth
abstract: As Western companies look to India, Indian companies explore foreign markets.

headline: A New Tool to Compare Airline Fees
abstract: NerdWallet.com is introducing a new tool that compares airline fees.

headline: Announcing … the Winner of India Ink’s Finance Minister Contest
abstract: The best of readers’ suggestions to put the Indian economy back on track.

headline: Olympus Goes Back to the Future
abstract: The new OM-D E-M5 from Olympus is meant to evoke 1972’s groundbreaking Single Lens Reflex Olympus OM-1. But this modern version isn’t an SLR—it’s digital, not to mention splash- and dustproof.

headline: NBC Fires Producer of Misleading Zimmerman Tape
abstract: The network reacted to the furor that erupted after it was revealed that its edit took George Zimmerman’s comments on Trayvon Martin’s race out of context.

headline: Politico Makes the Call: New Obama Biography ‘Dangerous’
abstract: The biography, by David Maraniss, isn’t out yet but already the media is on edge.

headline: UBS Earnings Sink, Following a Trend in Europe
abstract: The bank, hit by a trading scandal last year, said it was pleased with its progress amid the financial crisis in Europe.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Fewer Young Women Complete HPV Vaccine
abstract: Fewer young women complete H.P.V. vaccine, Omega-3 diet may lower Alzheimer’s protein, bending company rules for business travel and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: This Week in Small Business: It’s Small Business Week!
abstract: Plus: cheap gas, the worst phones, “Zuckerberg: The Musical” and your company’s obituary.

headline: Joy Behar Is Reviving Her Talk Show, This Time for Current TV
abstract: The comedian and political commentator, best know as a co-host of “The View,” lost her spot on HLN in November.

headline: What You Did for Your Financial Tuneup
abstract: Bucks readers share the list of things they accomplished during their annual financial tuneups.

headline: Barclays Executives Will Forgo Some Bonuses if Goals Are Not Met
abstract: After criticism from shareholders about executive pay, Barclays said Thursday that its executives would give up parts of their bonuses if the British bank failed to meet certain profitability goals.

headline: Monday Reading: Have Elite Fliers Been Downgraded?
abstract: Elite frequent fliers can feel downgraded by airlines, how to free a hijacked Facebook account, the value of a checkbook and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Behind a Band’s Stunt, an Entrenched World of Ticket Fees
abstract: String Cheese Incident, a jam band from Colorado, recently made a symbolic protest against Ticketmaster, but the surcharges that Ticketmaster collects feed many mouths in the music industry.

headline: News Corporation Acknowledges Breach of Foreign Ownership Rule
abstract: The company said that foreign ownership had risen to 36 percent, higher than the 25 percent limit for broadcasters that is allowed under United States law.

headline: Reactions to the Death of Mike Wallace, ’60 Minutes’ Pioneer
abstract: Mike Wallace, who died Saturday at age 93, was remembered by colleagues and competitors alike as a pioneer of American broadcasting.

headline: The Cartoon That Taught Indians The Meaning of “Many”
abstract: Documentary filmmaker Vijaya Mulay talks about the 1974 animation film –”Ek Anek Aur Ekta”– that was created to spread the message of unity in diversity

headline: Business Day Live: Stores Make Online Deals
abstract: What the lawsuit over e-book pricing means; an interview with Andy Dunn, chief executive of Bonobos; and why oil prices are rising, but natural gas is getting cheaper.

headline: Dylan Ratigan Leaving MSNBC
abstract: Mr. Ratigan, whose news analysis show is now broadcast at 4 p.m. Eastern time, said in a telephone interview that he was electing to leave cable so that he could put into practice what he has talked about on TV.

headline: Database of Veterans’ Medals Cited as Alternative to ‘Stolen Valor’
abstract: Justice Anthony Kennedy said a “database of medal winners” could offer an alternative solution to the Stolen Valor Act, perhaps a reference to the work of Doug Sterner, a Vietnam veteran who for more than a decade has been painstakingly logging military award citations into a public database.

headline: Congress Suffers Electoral Defeat in Andhra Pradesh
abstract: The party led by the jailed member of Parliament, Jagan Mohan Reddy, swept the by-polls in the southern state.

headline: Prosecutors Draw ‘Secret Pipeline’ Pattern; Defense Asks, ‘Where’s the Beef?’
abstract: Closing statements were heard in the trial of Rajat K. Gupta, the highest profile individual to be ensnared by the government’s insider trading crackdown.

headline: Daily Report: Europe Weighs Antitrust Case Against Google
abstract: The European Commission warned Google to propose changes in “a matter of weeks” to its method of answering user queries, or face a potential antitrust lawsuit.

headline: Why José Antonio Ocampo Wants to Run the World Bank
abstract: A conversation with the former Colombian finance minister, one of two challengers to the Obama administration’s nominee.

headline: Google Schools Apple on Maps
abstract: Apple is expected to dump Google Maps from its operating system, in favor of its own product. In response, Google is showing off how much it has done in maps, and how many features it has. The message to Apple is, this will cost more and take longer than you think.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers See Tough Year for Industry
abstract: A study of 400 hedge fund managers found about half believed that 2012 would be “a difficult or somewhat difficult” year for the industry, partly because of new regulations and cutthroat competition.

headline: About.me Releases Mobile Application
abstract: About.me, an online profile site that allows people to create personal identity pages online, announced the release of its first mobile application on Thursday, which allows people to identify people nearby.

headline: Secretary of Veterans Affairs Sides With Veteran in DOMA Case
abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs said it would not defend the constitutionality of two federal laws that define marriage as between a man and a woman.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Drone Lists and iPhone Rumors
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selection includes concerns about the greater numbers of male editors vs. female editors on Wikipedia, Canadians suing Apple and publishers and accusing them of fixing prices and a look at the scant evidence of employers asking job applicants for Facebook passwords.

headline: Insurer Details Higher Risks for Drivers After Deployment
abstract: A new study by USAA finds that troops are responsible for more automobile accidents after returning from Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Book Takes Aim at Murdochs
abstract: “Dial M for Murdoch,” an exposé about Rupert Murdoch and News Corporation, has been rushed out even as the British Parliament continues to investigate a phone-hacking scandal involving the company’s news outlets.

headline: Forthcoming Facebook Motion Said to Discuss Nasdaq’s Role in I.P.O.
abstract: A month after its botched I.P.O., the social network is set to file a motion to consolidate all shareholder lawsuits against the company — a filing that could place some blame on Nasdaq.

headline: The First Graduates From Advertising High
abstract: The graduation ceremony for the High School for Innovation in Advertising and Media, in Canarsie, Brooklyn, is to take place on June 26 at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Silver Lake and Partners Group to Buy Global Blue for $1.25 Billion
abstract: The private equity firm Silver Lake and the investment management company Partners Group have agreed to buy Global Blue, a tax-free shopping business.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Women and Tablet Ratings
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selection includes an artist whose canvas is snow and whose brushes are his feet, a discussion of how much money Google takes in via Android and an experimental health sensor tattoo.

headline: Britain Faces $3.2 Billion Loss from Northern Rock Sale
abstract: While the British government is expected to recoup the £37 billion it injected into Northern Rock, the loss would result from the discounted loans the government handed to the lender, the National Audit Office says.

headline: The Dubai You Don’t Know
abstract: When its grandiose visions collapsed, Dubai suffered the steepest property crash in the world, laid off workers and downsized banks. Foreigners fled. But Dubai is back, thanks partly to the Arab Spring.

headline: At the Oxygen Upfront, It Was Showtime
abstract: The Oxygen channel distilled its upfront presentation Wednesday night to 30 minutes of appearances by many of the energetic young cast members of its new and returning series.

headline: Will the Whale Swallow JPMorgan’s 2nd-Quarter Earnings?
abstract: While Jamie Dimon has given many assurances that the bank will report solid second-quarter profits, the botched derivatives trade could weigh on the bottom line.

headline: Partisan Divide in D.C.? Not Over the S.B.A.
abstract: House Republicans have proposed appropriating $1.6 billion to the S.B.A. — about $40 million more than the Obama administration has sought.

headline: Big Banks Fined $9 Million Over Risky Products
abstract: Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, UBS and Wells Fargo agreed to pay fines of more than $9 million to settle cases tied to exchange-traded funds.

headline: The Untraditional Origins of a New Southern Comfort Ad
abstract: Like Dannon before it, Southern Comfort is running commercials created through a crowd-sourcing initiative rather than by a traditional advertising agency.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: 36 Hours in Hyderabad
abstract: Must visit spots for a weekend trip to the city.

headline: LinkedIn Was Breached. Now What Do You Do?
abstract: Encoded passwords for one out of 25 LinkedIn users were posted to a Russian hacker site. As hackers work to crack those passwords, LinkedIn users would do well to quickly change their log-in credentials. Here is the important thing to note if you are worried about your password being taken. You need to change the password not just for LinkedIn but for any other site where you used the same password.

headline: Introducing Deirdre Lord, a New Business Group Member
abstract: Deirdre Lord and a longtime colleague teamed up to start The Megawatt Hour. “Essentially, we’re the Turbo Tax for businesses that buy energy in deregulated markets,” she said.

headline: AOL Strikes $1.1 Billion Patent Deal With Microsoft
abstract: AOL agreed on Monday to sell Microsoft a portfolio of over 800 patents, and license about 300 more, amid an arms race within the technology industry for intellectual property.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Microsoft Buys Into the Nook, and Radio’s Shrinking Diversity
abstract: Also, caution and relative stagnation at News Corporation, and Discovery Channel crashes a Boeing 727.

headline: S.&P. Gives Negative Outlook for India
abstract: The government’s inability to rein in debt and cut its fiscal deficit worry ratings agency.

headline: Rich Ross, Disney Studio Chairman, Is Forced Out
abstract: The move ends a two-and-a-half-year tenure that was more notable for continued misses than hits.

headline: George Martin, Katy Perry and Indie Label Heads on Universal-EMI Deal
abstract: As regulators consider perhaps the most significant music industry deal in the last decade, various musicians and business figures have spoken out about the deal.

headline: Making Sense of New E.E.O.C. Rules on Hiring
abstract: Is a candy company that gives tours to children taking a risk if it does not hire criminals?

headline: Americans Remain Wary of the Stock Market, Survey Finds
abstract: Americans are beginning to feel more financially secure but remain wary of investing in the stock market, a survey finds.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Where Is the Recovery?
abstract: Plus: the shale boom, falling home prices, incorporating fun and six ways not to start a business.

headline: Apollo May Again Face an Unwanted Battle
abstract: Apollo Global Management has proactively tried to stave off a battle as it tries to buy an amusement park company. But its acquisition agreement could still permit others from bidding more.

headline: Facebook: The New Danaher, Apco, Precision Castparts, Raven Industries or HollyFrontier?
abstract: Many of the best-performing stocks of the last 30 years are those of companies that most people have never heard of. And it’s awfully hard to pick them out before they begin their run.

headline: In Britain, a Plan to Give Shareholders More Say on Pay
abstract: Under new rules presented to Parliament, companies listed in Britain would have to get majority support from shareholders for their executive compensation packages.

headline: Pakistani Lawmakers Criticize U.S. Reward for Militant Leader
abstract: Bounty sends ‘negative message,’ implies lack of trust, Pakistan officials said.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Introduces the Surface Tablet
abstract: The big news this morning is Microsoft’s introduction of its Surface tablet, intended to challenge the iPad, reports Nick Wingfield in Tuesday’s New York Times. The device has a built-in “kickstand” that allows it to be propped up for watching movies, and a thin cover that also serves as a keyboard.

headline: Image of the Day: May 31
abstract: India’s outgoing army chief, General Vijay Kumar Singh handed over charge to his successor General Bikram Singh in New Delhi.

headline: Federal Prosecutors Are Said to Be Examining Goldman Banker
abstract: An investigation of an unnamed Goldman executive emerged last week during a pretrial hearing in the case of Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman director. That executive is said to be an investment banker based in San Francisco.

headline: Carlyle’s Profit Falls in First Quarter
abstract: In its first report as a public company, the Carlyle Group said on Tuesday that first-quarter economic net income fell 26 percent, to $392 million, from the period a year earlier.

headline: Business Day Live: Greek Banks Receive Financing
abstract: A Silicon Valley lawsuit highlights the scarcity of women in top technology jobs. Why Greek businesses fear a return to the drachma. Athenians talk about the economic crisis.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: In Footnote, Carlyle Hints at Size of I.P.O.
abstract: The Carlyle Group, the large private equity firm, indicated that it might sell 10 percent of its shares in its initial public offering, a disclosure buried on page 197 of its revised prospectus.

headline: In Motion, Facebook Lays Out Defense and Highlights Nasdaq’s Missteps
abstract: Facebook, in a motion that seeks to consolidate several shareholder lawsuits, provided the first glimpse of the social network’s defense of its bungled I.P.O. It is a defense built, in part, on Nasdaq’s missteps.

headline: Q&A: Fixing an Ailing Mailbox
abstract: When the Mac Mail program seems to be hiding some of your old messages, rebuilding your mailbox may help sort things out.

headline: Coty Raises Bid for Avon to $10.7 Billion
abstract: Coty increased its offer 6.5 percent, to $24.75 a share, disclosing that Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway is providing some financing for the bid.

headline: The Next Treasury Secretary
abstract: Whoever is elected president, there will be a new Treasury secretary come January, and the handicapping has already begun.

headline: Facebook’s Debut Marred by Trading Flaws
abstract: The Facebook $16 billion offering was the biggest I.P.O. that Nasdaq had ever listed. Now there are growing questions over how its market debut was handled.

headline: In JPMorgan Chase Trading Bet, Its Confidence Yields to Loss
abstract: While the $2 billion trading loss is not a huge threat to a bank as large and powerful as JPMorgan, it is a stark reminder that the banking system remains vulnerable to market shocks and has heightened concerns that big banks continue to make risky financial bets that could threaten the economy.

headline: JPMorgan Loss Puts Spotlight on Possible Ratings Downgrade for Global Banks
abstract: A Moody’s analyst said JPMorgan Chase’s loss of $2 billion showed big banks were carrying risks that were not fully apparent in their current ratings.

headline: Human Genome Sciences Adopts Poison Pill to Thwart Glaxo Takeover
abstract: Human Genome Sciences has adopted a shareholder rights plan to fend off a $2.59 billion takeover offer from the British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline.

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi, Beyond Myanmar’s Borders
abstract: Aung San Suu Kyi’s trip to Thailand, her first outside Myanmar since 1988, signals her confidence that President Thein Sein’s government is serious about democratic reforms.

headline: Yahoo Director Who Headed C.E.O. Search Committee to Stand Down
abstract: Patti S. Hart, the Yahoo director who headed the search committee that picked Scott Thompson as the company’s chief executive, will not stand for re-election.

headline: ‘Little Monsters’ in South Korea Are Not Amused
abstract: As North Korea enters the final countdown to its launch of a long-range missile, South Korea is debating Lady Gaga, and her young fans — her “little monsters,” as she calls them — are not happy.

headline: Cumulus, a Growing Radio Power, Sells 55 Scattered Stations
abstract: The second-largest radio operator is selling 55 stations across the country for 10 in two cities and $116 million in cash.

headline: Facebook Shares More About How It Uses Your Data
abstract: Facebook offers more information about how it uses what you post on the site, at a time when it needs to exploit your data much more deftly to satisfy its would-be shareholders.

headline: A Pakistani Observes From the Indian Side of the Wagah Border
abstract: The ceremony at the Wagah Border shows more similarities between Indians and Pakistanis than differences.

headline: Dish Network Says It Will Drop AMC in Summer
abstract: Amid a deepening feud, the satellite distributor said it would not renew its contract with AMC Networks. The channels affected include the flagship cable channel — home of “The Killing” and “Mad Men” — as well as IFC, WE tv and the Sundance Channel.

headline: Partner Exodus May Upend Dewey’s Loans
abstract: With eight more partners announcing their departures from Dewey on Tuesday, at least 66 of 300 partners have now left the firm since January, which could put its loan agreements at risk.

headline: Limbaugh to Leave AM Station in Philadelphia
abstract: “The Rush Limbaugh Show” is leaving WPHT, the dominant conservative talk radio station in Philadelphia.

headline: Greece vs. Germany?
abstract: Five days after Greece’s elections, its soccer team could play Germany’s. How would fans — and politicians — behave?

headline: Lockerbie Bomber Dead, Conspiracy Theories Survive
abstract: The Lockerbie bomber is dead. But that will not end a controversy over whether he, and Libya, were really responsible for a terrorist outrage in which 270 people died almost a quarter century ago.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Facebook’s ‘Global Citizen,’ and a Crossover Act in Spanish
abstract: And network executives got a glimpse at the future this week, and they didn’t like it: digital video recorders that automatically skips ads.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Arrested in Russia and Nokia’s Problems
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes an explanation of what the recent Tupac Shakur ‘hologram’ really was, a criticism of Yelp with suggested improvements and Amazon’s agreement with Nevada to collect sales tax.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Trust in Government, Declining With Cuts
abstract: Declining confidence in institutions and cutting funds for those institutions can be a self-perpetuating cycle.

headline: Jefferies Profit Falls 22%
abstract: The Jefferies Group’s second-quarter profit tumbled 22 percent from the same time last year, the investment bank said on Tuesday, with only debt-trading posting a rise in revenue.

headline: Fitch Warns Banks Must Raise $566 Billion in New Capital
abstract: The world’s largest banks must raise a combined $566 billion to satisfy new capital requirements, Fitch Ratings says, as the authorities press firms to hold more cash in reserve to protect against future financial shocks.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Reaction to Stolen Valor Ruling
abstract: Twitter users react to the Supreme Court’s overturning a federal law making it a crime to lie about having earned a military decoration.

headline: To Do Deals, Nothing Helps Like  Friends in High Places
abstract: In emerging markets, where political connections are often the path to wealth, Wall Street deal makers will want to make friends with government leaders.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Murdoch Says He ‘Failed’ on Hacking, and a Missing Vogue Profile
abstract: Also, the difficulty of filling Rich Ross’s job as Disney’s movie chairman, and why did Justin Patterson’s killing not get the notoriety that Trayvon Martin’s did?

headline: A Few Things to Ask Your Financial Adviser
abstract: What Carl Richards tells people who ask him for help finding a financial planner, starting with the fiduciary question.

headline: News Corp. Profits Increase Despite Scandal
abstract: Net income at the giant media company was up 47 percent despite the ongoing hacking scandal in Britain. The company’s strong cable television division helped drive the profits.

headline: Q.&A.: Wireless Industry Likes Spectrum Sharing, but Still Wants More
abstract: A presidential advisory committee is urging President Obama to adopt technologies so that better use is made of radio spectrum for wireless communications. In response, CTIA, the association that represents the wireless industry, says that it is excited about the idea of spectrum sharing, but that giving the carriers more spectrum should still remain the government’s top priority.

headline: A Conflicted Jury Finds Rajat Gupta Guilty
abstract: The jury for the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta took only two days to reach its verdict. But the process was not easy, with several jurors saying they felt conflicted.

headline: Vodafone Takes Legal Action Over Tax Proposal in India
abstract: Vodafone invokes treaty between India and Netherlands.

headline: CBS Threatens ABC Over ‘Glass House,’ a ‘Big Brother’-Like TV Show
abstract: The CBS letter stops short of announcing a lawsuit; instead, it says ABC and the producers “will be acting at their own peril” if they proceed. However, so far, lawsuits over reality TV have never succeeded.

headline: Daily Report: A Turning Point for Mobile
abstract: Facebook’s acquisition of Instagram could be something of a turning point, as even Facebook tries to get a better grasp on a market that requires a rethinking of old rules. But it was probably not crazy to pay $1 billion.

headline: A Look at Why Consumers Are Using Prepaid Debit Cards
abstract: Prepaid debit cards are attractive to some users because they help them stick to a budget. But fees are seen as a drawback.

abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.
