abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Cambodian Start-up Competes With India in Natural Hair Market
abstract: India has long provided much of the world’s natural hair, but Cambodians have similar hair quality.

headline: What JPMorgan’s Bonds Say About the Fortress Balance Sheet
abstract: JPMorgan’s long-term debt costs need to be watched closely. In the first quarter, JPMorgan paid a higher interest rate on its third-largest source of funds – $255 billion of long-term debt.

headline: Obama and Romney Agree: Cut Americans’ Already Low Taxes
abstract: Despite having some of the lowest tax rates in the developed world, Americans have reached a political consensus that they should pay even less.

headline: Facebook’s $10 Billion Sales Pitch
abstract: In preparation for its roadshow, Facebook uploaded its I.P.O. presentation to the Web, a glossy video production with a full cast of characters, traveling video shots and upbeat music.

headline: A Consensus Begins to Emerge on Derivatives in Bankruptcy
abstract: Yes, derivatives sometimes do deserve special treatment in bankruptcy cases, but there is a growing recognition that the current exemptions can go too far.

headline: Shares in European Banks Rebound After Ratings Downgrade
abstract: Shares in many of Europe’s banks rebounded in late morning trading on Friday after initially trading lower as investors reacted to a new round of credit downgrades for the world’s largest financial institutions.

headline: Does the iPad Have One Button Too Many?
abstract: The front of the iPad has one button, and that is one physical button too many. For the last couple of weeks I’ve been using the iPad without touching that home button, and it’s often a more enjoyable way to use the device.

headline: Google Aims to Smooth the Path for Android Developers
abstract: Android is the top operating system in mobile, but Android app developers don’t seem to be making much money compared to Apple iOS developers. Google is trying to change that.

headline: Shades of Guilt in One Soldier’s Purple Heart
abstract: For one decorated soldier, the metal on his lapel that represents the capacity to survive, endure and sacrifice also carries with it a darker side, including the shadows of the lives taken.

headline: Opposition to Universal-EMI Deal Intensifies Before Senate Hearings
abstract: A week before a Senate subcommittee is set to hold hearings, two consumer-advocate organizations tried to rally opposition to the $1.9 billion acquisition with a detailed report on the deal.

headline: TNT Orders Series Based on Novel by Dr. Gupta of CNN
abstract: In an usual case of corporate synergy within Time Warner, TNT will adapt “Monday Mornings,” a novel by the medical correspondent at CNN.

headline: Live Nation Acquires Electronic Music Promoter
abstract: Live Nation Entertainment has acquired Hard Events, a Los Angeles company that has put on popular festivals and concerts across North America.

headline: A Top London Banker at JPMorgan Chase Resigns
abstract: Ian Hannam, JPMorgan’s global chairman of equity capital markets, left the bank after British financial regulators fined him for disclosing inside information.

headline: NBC’s ‘Today’ Show Wins Ratings Showdown
abstract: The “Today” show on NBC, locked in a week-long showdown against ABC’s “Good Morning America”, scored its biggest ratings win of the week on Thursday.

headline: Looking for the Next Generation in Private Equity
abstract: A handful of men who reign over the private equity industry are now in their 60s, but they have set forth no clear succession plans.

headline: Meet Nancy Powell, the United States’ New Ambassador to India
abstract: America’s first female ambassador to India arrives this week, amid strained ties between the two countries.

headline: In India, Cynicism and a Nationwide Strike
abstract: Across the country, many were skeptical of the strike’s impact on Thursday and pessimistic about their future.

headline: Google Opens Up About Its Network
abstract: Google is notoriously closed-mouthed about its inner workings. So it is something of a surprise that Google is talking about its new advanced network. The goal is to increase Internet use by making it cheaper, and maybe help a few incumbent players.

headline: Microsoft Taps Yahoo Scientists for New York Research Lab
abstract: Microsoft is setting up a research lab in New York, picking off a team of researchers from the struggling Yahoo. The initial group, Microsoft says, is just a start as it seeks to tap into the “groundswell” of science and technology development under way in New York.

headline: Cravath Names a New Leader
abstract: The New York law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore has elected C. Allen Parker as its next chief, succeeding Evan R. Chesler, who will become chairman.

headline: China Flexes Its Regulatory Muscle, Catching Google in Its Grip
abstract: China is having the final word on Google’s biggest and perhaps most strategic deal to date — its proposed $12.5 billion acquisition of Motorola Mobility, the American handset maker and communications company.

headline: When Insolvency Cases Are Global
abstract: A United Nations working group is trying to to come up with, and constantly improve, guidelines for handling insolvency cases. Both cross-boarder cooperation and international harmonization are the aim.

headline: HBO Says No, for Now, to Fans Who Want a Web-Only Option
abstract: “Take My Money, HBO!” is a Web page meant to encourage HBO to allow Internet-only subscriptions. Via Twitter, HBO indicated that it was better off keeping with its cable and satellite partners.

headline: Digital Notes: Sony’s EMI Deal Is Approved by Europe
abstract: The deal still needs approval in the United States, however. Also, the Universal Music Group has made a shift in management.

headline: Cricket’s Juggernaut Returns to Action
abstract: By turning many cricketers into millionaires, the Indian Premiere League has transformed the game.

headline: Lawmakers Support Shifting Financial Oversight
abstract: A plan, introduced by the House Financial Services Committee, would shift oversight from federal authorities to groups backed by the financial industry, most likely the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.

headline: With Nook Deal, a Hint of Microsoft Hardware
abstract: Microsoft rarely makes its own hardware, preferring instead to make the software that powers devices made by other companies. The company’s decision to invest in the Nook e-book business of the struggling retailer Barnes & Noble offers some tantalizing clues that Microsoft may be rethinking its position on hardware, though.

headline: Daily Report: For Google and Others, Devices Made in the U.S.A.
abstract: Google’s new wireless home media player, the Nexus Q, is being manufactured in the United States, one of several signs that the trend of producing consumer electronic goods outside this country may be reversing, reports John Markoff in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: Judge May Permit Wiretaps as Evidence in Insider Case
abstract: Judge Jed S. Rakoff says that he intends to allow the jury in the trial of Rajat Gupta to hear four wiretapped conversations involving Raj Rajaratnam and colleagues of the Galleon Group hedge fund.

headline: Cheers and Jeers For Queen’s Jubilee
abstract: A full program of festivities has been set out for this weekend’s 60th anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II’s reign. Even penny-pinching republicans are joining in, if only to protest.

headline: Dimon vs. Volcker, the Television Series
abstract: Beyond the bank’s letters, lobbying and trips to Capitol Hill to fight what it sees as excessive regulation, JPMorgan’s chief has repeatedly taken his case to the public, in a succession of interviews. Here are three of them.

headline: A New Addition to Samsung’s Family of Players
abstract: The Galaxy Player 3.6 has a readily available Wi-Fi connection, which may be its only advantage to the more powerful smartphones: you can play music, video and games without having to pay monthly cellphone service fees.

headline: DBS Group to Buy Bank Danamon for $7.2 Billion
abstract: DBS Group Holdings of Singapore agreed on Monday to buy Bank Danamon of Indonesia for $7.2 billion in one of the largest takeovers in Southeast Asia’s financial services industry.

headline: Microsoft Tries to Make Windows Updates Flame Retardant
abstract: Security researchers are learning more about Flame, the computer virus aimed at computers in the Middle East. Among the most intriguing discoveries: The virus should not have been that hard to find. It was, however, a failure of the computer security industry. The antivirus makers were out of their league, one researcher acknowledges.

headline: Business Day Live: American Airlines in Bankruptcy Court
abstract: What American Airlines hopes to achieve in bankruptcy court and LPL Financial’s Jeffrey Kleintop on market outlook.

headline: Is Cricket Really a ‘Gentleman’s Game?’
abstract: The game was once dominated by the elite, but has never been played gently.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: At-Home vs. Employed Mothers: Who’s Happier
abstract: At-home mothers are more likely than employed mothers to report feeling sad or angry and being diagnosed with depression, according to a new report by Gallup.

headline: The Return of Goldman’s Mark Schwartz
abstract: After leaving Goldman in 2002, the banker worked for George Soros and later formed an investment firm with Raj Rajaratnam and Rajat K. Gupta.

headline: Finding New Ways to Separate the Rich From Their Cash
abstract: While most people in Europe and other parts of the developed world are being urged to tighten their belts, figures show spending on luxury goods and services by the global rich is higher than ever.

headline: From Bleak Central India, a People’s Movement
abstract: In the Pati region of Madhya Pradesh, villagers are fighting for their basic rights and entitlements.

headline: Thomson Reuters Sells Health Care Business for $1.25 Billion
abstract: Adding to a flurry of health care deals announced on Monday, Thomson Reuters has sold its health care unit to an affiliate of Veritas Capital for $1.25 billion in cash.

headline: As Tamil Nadu Nuclear Plant Opening Nears, Protests Enter ‘Death Throes’
abstract: Protests over the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Project have been happening since 1988.

headline: Dish Seeks Ruling on Feature That Skips All Commercials
abstract: The Dish Network and three television networks filed opposing lawsuits on Thursday over a feature that allows television viewers to automatically skip all the commercials during most prime time shows.

headline: Grooveshark, a Music Service, Is Sued Again
abstract: The popular streaming service is being sued by EMI Music, the one major record label that had made a licensing deal with it.

headline: An App That Prompts Children to Do Their Chores
abstract: The old-fashioned chore board has been reborn as an iPhone app called ChoreMonster. It assigns children tasks, tracks their completion via e-mails to parents, and gives children points, which can be applied to rewards of the parent’s choosing.

headline: JPMorgan Chase’s Earnings Beat Expectations
abstract: JPMorgan Chase reported better-than-expected revenue growth, buoyed by improving credit conditions among consumers and continued demand for new loans.

headline: What Chen Guangcheng’s Arrival in America Means
abstract: Chen Guangcheng arrived at Newark’s Liberty International Airport on Saturday night, a face-saving sign of a maturing superpower rivalry between the United States and China. But this is not detente.

headline: Inventor of Wireless Remote Dies: Clunky Technology Lives On
abstract: More than 50 years after Eugene Polley invented the wireless TV remote, we are still struggling with how to tell our TVs what to watch.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Ray Bradbury’s Long Shadow, and a First Lady’s Journalism
abstract: Also, a European “shareholder spring” erupts over payouts to advertising executives, and “The Clock” is coming to Lincoln Center, free of charge.

headline: A Pitch to Collect Charity From Casino Gamblers
abstract: Carol Roth analyzes an entry in the Make Your Pitch contest.

headline: Refinery Venture Reflects Easing of India-Pakistan Relations
abstract: A $4 billion oil refinery on the northern border with Pakistan is expected to stimulate trade between the two countries.

headline: Alliance Boots Taps Longtime Adviser Centerview in Walgreens Deal
abstract: Centerview Partners, the American investment banking boutique, was named Tuesday as the sole adviser to Alliance Boots in its $6.7 billion deal with Walgreens.

headline: Fight Over Post Tests Congress Party’s Mettle
abstract: A tussle over the nomination of Pranab Mukherjee, for president, appears to be a rare case in which the Congress Party has outfoxed the competition.

headline: Regulator May Grant Foreign Banks Brief Reprieve on Derivatives
abstract: In a speech to bankers, the head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission outlined a plan to regulate overseas derivatives trading while delaying some rules for foreign banks.

headline: How Jellio Is Solving Its Manufacturing Problems
abstract: The maker of quirky home furnishings will continue to make some products locally and has found a way to produce in China, too.

headline: Health Care Ruling: The Wordle
abstract: For readers who want to get a flavor of the language and themes in today’s Supreme Court ruling without reading all 193 pages, here’s a word cloud showing the most commonly used terms

headline: Q&A: An E-Signature for an E-Return
abstract: Instead of your John Hancock, the I.R.S. will accept a five-digit PIN as an electronic signature.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: On ‘Having It All’ (or Some), and Cracks at NBC News
abstract: Also, Facebook will let users opt out of becoming part of advertisements, and a promotional tie-in between “Madagascar 3″ and a children’s medication draws fire.

headline: Mood Upbeat on Iranian Trade Tour of India
abstract: Dozens of Iranian businessmen, searching for deals and trade agreements, are touring India this week.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Drilling Down: What Small Businesses Should Know About Crowdfunding
abstract: A crowdfunding entrepeneur says he would welcome more regulation.

headline: For International Students, a College Admissions Checklist for May
abstract: For this week’s installment of The Choice on India Ink, we present an international version of our May checklists for juniors and seniors.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Vending Machine and Beyond Google Glasses
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes a critical look at the way Microsoft presented the Surface tablet, a case for there being plenty of broadband capacity available if it is used efficiently and the value of having a partner in a start-up firm.

headline: The Lowdown on Google Drive
abstract: Google released its long-awaited cloud storage product, Google Drive. The basics include 5 gigabytes of free storage, no ads and a sliding fee scale if you need more. The surprises include just how much of Google’s computational wizardry has gone into what you can do with Drive. On Monday, in anticipation of Google Drive, Microsoft raised SkyDrive’s free limit to 100 gigabytes.

headline: Battered Man Group Shares Get a Boost
abstract: Citigroup analysts give the stock a buy rating based on valuation and the belief that the worst could be over for the giant hedge fund manager.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Less-Than-Daily Newspapers, and Richard Dawson’s Kisses
abstract: Also, sales of the Sunday edition of Rupert Murdoch’s Sun tabloid have yet to match The News of the World’s circulation figures; and Anthony Bourdain moves to CNN.

headline: Q.&A.: Copying iTunes Content From PC to Mac
abstract: How to move iTunes files from one computer to another.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Awash in Cash
abstract: We examined Facebook’s $1 billion deal for a mobile start-up, Microsoft’s $1 billion deal for patents and a $2.15 billion “lawsuit waiting to happen.” A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Roche: Illumina Is No Apple
abstract: In a letter to Illumina’s shareholders, Roche’s chief executive, Severin Schwan, said there were few parallels between the iPhone maker and the genetic analysis provider, despite statements from the board that suggest otherwise.

headline: Despite Good Health, Bank Holds Tight to TARP Funds
abstract: M&T, a regional lender based in Buffalo, has redeemed $700 million of the government’s preferred shares, but it still owes taxpayers $382 million.

headline: Unit of Ally, ResCap, Said to Plan Bankruptcy
abstract: The mortgage unit of Ally Financial plans to put itself into bankruptcy, according to people briefed on the matter, allowing the bank to effectively remove the biggest obstacle to its turnaround efforts.

headline: Timing of Nuclear Claim Puts Tehran on the Spot
abstract: As Iranian and international atomic energy officials sat down for a latest round of talks about Tehran’s nuclear program, a picture published over the weekend appeared to cast further doubt on the regime’s denials that it is developing a bomb.

headline: Daily Report: EBay to Power a Data Center With Fuel Cells
abstract: EBay plans to build a data center that will draw its power from fuel cells rather than the national power grid, which is heavily dependent on coal plants, James Glanz reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: At London Olympics, NBC Says, ‘If Cameras Are on It, We’ll Stream It’
abstract: In a change in thinking, events will be available online as they happen. To protect the prime-time broadcast, big events, like gold-medal races, will not be archived until they have appeared on TV.

headline: Is This Kashmir’s Road Map for Peace?
abstract: Findings of a newly issued report, compiled after speaking to thousands in Kashmir.

headline: Sears Plans to Spin Off Part of Canadian Unit
abstract: The spinoff marks a curious change in strategy for the hedge fund billionaire Edward S. Lampert, who in 2009 moved to ratchet up the company’s stake in Sears Canada.

headline: Denouement in France
abstract: French voters began going to the polls Sunday morning in what has been characterized as one of the most dramatic and consequential elections in the postwar era, with the Socialist candidate, François Hollande, widely expected to defeat the incumbent, President Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: It’s Official: ’30 Rock’ Will End Its Run Next Season
abstract: NBC announced the end of the critical acclaimed sit-com at its upfront presentation in New York.

headline: Digital Notes: Royalty Service Responds to Suit by Sirius XM
abstract: The issue of how to collect payments for satellite radio and online streams is a contentious one, with some parties concerned that artists could lose substantial royalties as a result; also, a new survey tries to answer who listens to Internet radio, and for how long?

headline: In Europe, It’s a Jeff Koons Summer
abstract: Jeff Koons’s “Split-rocker” has popped up again this summer. This time it’s in Basel, in one of three exhibitions of the prolific American artist’s work.

headline: Could You Handle Being an Employee?
abstract: When a business is sold, some owners make the difficult transition from entrepreneur to employee. Owners who have had the experience say it is important to negotiate well — and be prepared for the worst.

headline: Nokia Adds to Its Low-End Lineup of Phones
abstract: As Nokia waits for its high-end business to grow, it made another move to shore up its bread-and-butter market. The company on Wednesday added two touch-screen cellphones to its low-end lineup. The Finnish company generates about 54 percent of its revenue from so-called bulk models.

headline: Video: Facebook’s Diaspora
abstract: Somini Sengupta and Peter Lattman discuss the diaspora of Internet and technology entrepreneurs that Facebook has created, and how that might end up being one of the company’s lasting legacies.

headline: In ‘The Meadow,’ a Chilling Alternate View of the 1995 Kashmiri Kidnappings
abstract: Rather than working for the hostages release, the Indian government prolonged their capture to damage Pakistan’s image, a new book alleges.

headline: Q&A: Safely Dumping Old Data Discs
abstract: Destroying old CD and DVD backup discs helps keep your personal information safe.

headline: China Blocking All Mention of Chen and His Daring Escape
abstract: China seems to have issued a gag order to prevent any mention of Chen Guangcheng and his daring late-night escape from house arrest. State-run newspapers have not yet carried any news about Mr. Chen, and Internet searches of his name, his initials and “blind man” are being blocked, along with the phrase “U.S. Embassy” — where Mr. Chen is said to have sought sanctuary.

headline: Will Ad Agencies Move Work to India?
abstract: The advertising industry is ripe for an overhaul, one executive says.

headline: Jawbone’s Jambox, Now With More Jam
abstract: Jawbone introduced the first Jambox, a wireless speaker, in 2010 to some fanfare. Its newest sibling, the Big Jambox, is twice as big as the original model and it weighs just two pounds more.

headline: Buffett’s Goldman Deal Is Topic in an Insider Case
abstract: Byron D. Trott, an adviser to Warren E. Buffett and a former Goldman Sachs vice chairman, detailed how Mr. Buffett’s investment in Goldman came about.

headline: One on One: Lane Becker, Author of ‘Get Lucky’
abstract: Lane Becker, left, and Thor Muller, co-founders of the site Get Satisfaction, have written a book called “Get Lucky,” which is described as a manual for serendipity in the digital age. We talk to Mr. Becker about how to make your own luck.

headline: Dimon Agrees to Testify, Without Committing to Specific Date
abstract: While Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has agreed to testify before a Congressional committee in June to discuss the bank’s recent multibillion-dollar trading loss, he has not committed to a date.

headline: Honoring the Exchange of Life for Life
abstract: Every year in the lead up to Memorial Day, one veteran of the Iraq War ponders the loss of his comrades and how to let go.

headline: Figuring Out the Market for Fine Watches
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinion on the market for expensive, collectible watches.

headline: Good Features Demand Good Design
abstract: Manufacturers have to weigh the desire to have devices do a lot of things against the simplicity that consumers demand — and deserve. They keep loading on features that drag down a product’s usefulness rather than adding to it.

headline: Third Point Calls for Interim C.E.O. at Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo’s latest efforts to contain the controversy surrounding the embellished credentials of its chief executive do not seem to impress Daniel S. Loeb.

headline: ID Theft Firms Criticized on ‘Free Trial’ Policies
abstract: Consumers often complain that some identity-theft protection services make it hard to cancel after free introductory periods, a new report found.

headline: Energy Meeting Hopes to Bring Light to Millions of Homes
abstract: Ministers from 22 countries and the E.U. hope to develop modern lighting for two million Indians by the end of 2015.

headline: Your Tech Questions, Answered: Part 4
abstract: Sam Grobart, writer of the new tech-help column Tool Kit, answers readers’ questions posted online.

headline: Sberbank of Russia in Talks to Buy DenizBank for $4 Billion
abstract: Sberbank of Russia is in exclusive talks to buy DenizBank, a Turkish subsidiary of the struggling French-Belgian lender Dexia, for $4 billion.

headline: Digital Notes: Dogged by Lawsuits, MP3Tunes Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The digital music locker service drew an infringement lawsuit from EMI in 2007, which led to the bankruptcy filing.

headline: Koovagam’s Non-Stop Party Comes With Chaos
abstract: An uneasy relation between the locals and transgenders becomes a security problem for the police.

headline: How Wider Coverage Affects Health Spending
abstract: Readers weigh in on an Oregon study that found a group of newly insured people were happier, but also incurred more medical expenses than uninsured people.

headline: Goldman Sachs Cuts a Little Deeper
abstract: The Wall Street firm laid off about 50 people last week, a number of them managing directors, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Image of the Day: June 27
abstract: A newlywed’s protest against the lack of toilets in her marital home in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Just a Minute: Chozick on Opportunity Cost of News Corporation’s Troubles
abstract: Amy Chozick on her article “Scandal and Scrutiny Hem In Murdoch’s Empire.”

headline: After Rejecting Higher Offers, Talbots Agrees to $369 Million Buyout
abstract: After walking away from higher takeover offers from Sycamore Partners, the troubled women’s clothing retailer Talbots struck a more modest deal with the private equity firm.

headline: Agilent to Buy Dako for $2.2 Billion
abstract: Agilent Technologies, a maker of scientific instruments, has agreed to buy Dako, a Danish cancer diagnostics company, for $2.2 billion.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Scrutiny for E-Book Pricing, and Phone-Hacking Lawsuits in U.S.
abstract: Also, the new chief executive of Sony promises “difficult decisions” to revive the company, and Ann Romney starts a Twitter account to respond to comments from a Democratic strategist.

headline: Business Day Live: India Struggles With Growth
abstract: I.M.F. meeting opens as a European slowdown looms; a lack of energy infrastructure hampers growth in India; and questions about safety of medical devices.

headline: Daily Report: A Glimpse at Facebook’s Financials
abstract: The latest filing by Facebook to the Securities and Exchange Commission reveals more about the company as its initial public offering nears. Among the disclosures: Facebook’s profit fell 12 percent in the first three months of the year.

headline: Ex-Goldman Director Faces New Insider Trading Claim
abstract: Federal prosecutors say that Rajat K. Gupta, a former director at Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble, tipped Raj Rajaratnam about Procter & Gamble’s sales forecasts in late 2008.

headline: Others in the Spotlight After JPMorgan’s Big Trading Loss
abstract: Amid JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss at its chief investment office, DealBook highlights some executives who may face additional scrutiny from the embarrassing incident.

headline: New Ad Tools From Google
abstract: Google announced a suite of Web analysis products that it will offer to marketers who want more insight into how well their digital ads are performing.

headline: Q&A: Powering Up Overseas
abstract: Modern power adapters can often handle international electricity standards, but check the label before you go.

headline: Hindu Wedding Planners Thrive in the United States
abstract: A new group of specialists for opulent Indian-American weddings.

headline: Morgan Spurlock on Producing a Show for Hulu
abstract: The director of “Super Size Me” says it was easier to persuade the streaming-video service to back his latest project, “A Day in the Life,” compared with a cable TV outlet.

headline: Jobs Forecast Shifts the Electoral Outlook
abstract: The latest projections by Moody’s Analytics for monthly job growth still point to a close race for the White House. But the odds of a mini-boom that would help the incumbent have faded.

headline: After New York Radio Deal, Early Signs of Ratings Gains
abstract: In April, two venerable New York City R&B stations — WRKS and WBLS — merged, and ESPN moved to the FM band. It’s still early, but the moves have brought improved ratings.

headline: Sirius XM Gains on Car Sales
abstract: Sirius reported $805 million in revenue for the first three months of 2012, up 11 percent over the same period the year before. An increase in monthly subscription rates didn’t appear to lose the company subscribers.

headline: A Tiger in Love
abstract: A review of “I Am an Executioner,” a first collection of unpredictable short stories by Rajesh Parameswaran.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: How to Talk About Money With Your Spouse
abstract: There is often a radical mismatch between two spouses’ financial expectations that doesn’t emerge until years into a marriage or partnership. Don’t be that couple.

headline: The Unfunded Liabilities You Love
abstract: Spending cuts favored by Republicans would not simply reduce commitments not covered by projected revenues, but would shift them to individuals and families, an economist writes.

headline: Letterman and Ferguson Extend Runs on CBS
abstract: CBS announced Tuesday that both David Letterman and Craig Ferguson have agreed to continue in their current light-night shows for at least two more years.

headline: To Help Africa, First Understand It
abstract: One hundred million people watched a video in March that described how Uganda’s Joseph Kony brutalized children in his Lord’s Resistance Army. But it will require more than momentary outrage to help heal Africa’s wounds.

headline: First the Mandate, Then All Tax Incentives
abstract: Striking down the health insurance mandate could suggest that all sorts of tax incentives are similarly unconstitutional, an economist says.

headline: Hackers Breach Sites of Foreign Policy and Human Rights Groups
abstract: Security researchers have discovered that hackers breached Web sites belonging to several foreign policy and human rights groups using security flaws in Adobe and Oracle software. Among the sites still infected were sites belonging to Amnesty International Hong Kong, the Center for Defense Information and the Cambodian Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

headline: Taxpayers Warned to Beware of E-Mails From I.R.S.
abstract: The I.R.S. warns taxpayers to beware of fraudulent e-mails purporting to be from the agency, which doesn’t begin communication via e-mail.

headline: Texas Is the Future
abstract: In the government’s state-by-state survey of economic growth in 2011, six states’ economies contracted, some were helped by manufacturing or energy, and Texas showed broad-based gains.

headline: Addressing Pay and Protesters at Morgan Stanley’s Annual Meeting
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s annual meeting was dominated by questions — and assertions — from individuals about financial regulation and bankers’ pay. But shareholders overwhelmingly approved executive compensation packages.

headline: What Volcker Rule Could Mean for JPMorgan’s Big Trades
abstract: Bruno Iksil, the JPMorgan Chase trader who is effectively betting that the creditworthiness of a group of companies will improve, may be protected under the new regulation.

headline: Condé Nast Acquires Online Recipe Service
abstract: Condé Nast will announce on Wednesday that it is purchasing ZipList, a digital and mobile shopping list and recipe service.

headline: Image of the Day: June 20
abstract: Ahead of World Music Day, two men look for music at a store in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Show Gupta and Rajaratnam Were Close Friends
abstract: The government showed the jury e-mails to suggest that Rajat Gupta, the former director at Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble, harbored affection for the hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Weakness in Facebook Stock Adds to Pause in I.P.O.’s
abstract: In the days since the highly anticipated opening of Facebook turned into a flop, the impact has become worse as would-be issuers have taken a second look at what they’re getting into.

headline: Are College Entrants Overdiagnosed as Underprepared?
abstract: For many high school graduates directed by colleges into remediation, it is like entering the Bermuda Triangle, never to emerge, an economist writes.

headline: The Kalnirnay ‘Calmanac’ Goes Digital
abstract: A popular religious calendar-almanac, used by millions to identify auspicious days, embraces new technology.

headline: How Older Workers Weather Layoffs
abstract: A Government Accountability Office report looks at the difficulties they face finding new jobs, and how their financial security in retirement may be compromised.

headline: Pinterest Raises $100 Million
abstract: Pinterest, which allows users to share photographs, recipes and other media on custom “pinboards,” raised $100 million in a funding round led by the Japanese e-commerce company Rakuten.

headline: LinkedIn’s Leaky Mobile App Has Access to Your Meeting Notes
abstract: Researchers discovered that LinkedIn’s app for the iPhone had transmitted users’ calendar entries— which may include details about their meeting locations, participants, dial-in information, passwords and sensitive meeting notes — to its servers and stored it, without their knowledge. The practice could violate Apple’s privacy guidelines, which expressly prohibit app makers from transmitting users’ data without their permission.

headline: Formula One and Civil Unrest, Chapter IV: Montreal
abstract: MONTREAL — Bizarrely, the last four races have encountered social disturbances in a diverse set of countries — and a growing trend of demonstrators using the series to publicize their cause.

headline: New Study Outlines How the Military Could Create a Leaner, Less Expensive Force
abstract: A new study released Wednesday by the Center for a New American Security offers some provocative ideas for how the Pentagon could reshape itself for this new era.

headline: How Facebook Tries to Protect Users’ Online Credentials
abstract: Facebook can cross-check credentials from hacked companies to see if any of its users are affected.

headline: Europe’s Woes Continue to Hamper Takeovers
abstract: So far this year, the combined value of takeovers in Europe has fallen 23 percent as market volatility and a reduction in financing continue to thwart efforts across the Continent to complete deals.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Rules for Robots and Amazon the Tax Collector
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items.Thursday’s selection includes advice for entrepreneurs on handling the demands of their start-up and actual families and an entry on Twitter posts deleted by politicians.

headline: K.K.R. Posts Slight Gain in Profit Despite Drop in Fees
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reported that its first-quarter adjusted profit rose 5 percent, as an increase in the value of the investment firm’s holdings helped offset a drop in deal-related fees.

headline: Samsung Backs Open Source, Joining Linux Foundation
abstract: Samsung is becoming a platinum member of the Linux Foundation, giving $500,000 to the nonprofit in support of the Linux operating system and the open-source projects related to it. The new membership status gives Samsung a seat on the foundation’s board, giving it more of a say on how the Linux system is developed.

headline: Business Day Live: Owning a Bit of Facebook
abstract: Frenzied interest in Facebook’s pending market debut; Dean Maki of Barclays looks at employment numbers; and James B. Stewart on the decline and fall of Dewey & LeBoeuf.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Least Gruesome’ Gruesome War Photos, and ‘Idol’ on Dick Clark
abstract: The Los Angeles Times defends its decision to publish two photographs of American soldiers with the body parts of Afghanistan insurgents, and “American Idol” commemorates the death of Dick Clark.

headline: In ResCap Bid, a Savvy Move by Berkshire
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway’s effort to buy ResCap assets illustrates the many pieces of the distressed debt puzzle.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Renewed Europe Worries Sap Deal-Makers Confidence
abstract: Announced deals totaled $169 billion during the first three months of the year, a 17 percent drop compared to the same period in 2011, according to the data provider Thomson Reuters.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Google Gets Defensive, and Remote Control Inventor Dies
abstract: Also, “American Idol” approaches an off-season of “creative reinvigoration” to counter falling ratings, and the Metropolitan Opera reconsiders.

headline: Angered by Unsafe City, Gurgaon Women Call for a ‘Girlcott’
abstract: A series of violent crimes against women inspires a boycott of the outsourcing city’s stores, restaurants and services.

headline: NBC Hopes Olympics Can Help New Comedies
abstract: “Go On,” which stars Matthew Perry as a sports talk radio host, and “Animal Practice,” which stars Justin Kirk and co-stars a monkey, will be shown commercial free during expected high points of the games.

headline: A Flat Day for Carlyle in Its Debut as a Public Company
abstract: The private equity firm closed at $22.05, just 5 cents about its offering price.

headline: Daily Report: Google Founders Solidify Power
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin writes that though Google’s founders plan to sell shares and the company continues to issue new shares to employees, they have a developed a plan to retain an iron grip over their company.

headline: Owner of Lane Bryant Sold to Rival for $890 Million
abstract: Charming Shoppes, the owner of the Lane Bryant line of women’s clothing stores, agreed to sell itself to a rival, the Ascena Retail Group, for about $890 million.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Outrage Over Leaks, and ‘Power’ Designer for ‘Dynasty’
abstract: Democrats and Republicans on the Senate and House intelligence committees denounce leaks to the news media about classified programs, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is set to testify in a judicial inquiry investigating press ethics, and the fashion designer Nolan Miller dies at age 79.

headline: Investment Fund to Pay $1.3 Billion for Edinburgh Airport
abstract: Global Infrastructure Partners agreed Monday to buy Edinburgh Airport for $1.3 billion in its latest acquisition in the British airport sector.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Addiction and Mainstream Memes
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a discussion of Léo Apotheker’s 11 months at Hewlett-Packard, an early look at a new kind of search from Google and a call to throw out the terms “tech company” and “tech startup” because overuse has made themuseless.

headline: For Gupta, What Lies Ahead
abstract: Rajat K. Gupta’s conviction shows that federal prosecutors can still win an insider trading case based largely on circumstantial evidence. But his lawyers have several issues they may bring up on appeal.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Records Strong First-Quarter Results
abstract: The British bank said its operating profit rose 4 percent to $1.9 billion in the first three months of this year, as the nationalized firm was close to repaying all its government-backed emergency loans.

headline: British Utility Rejects $9.5 Billion Offer From GDF Suez
abstract: The British utility International Power has rejected a $9.5 billion offer from the French energy giant GDF Suez for the 30 percent stake in the British company that it does not already own.

headline: CVR Energy Reaches Agreement With Icahn
abstract: After resisting the investor, the oil refining and marketing company will now allow Carl C. Icahn to pursue a takeover offer for $30 a share, plus a “contingent cash payment” right, or more than $2.6 billion.

headline: Indian Airlines Snub Europe’s Emissions Rule
abstract: Two Indian airlines were among the 10 that failed to submit data on carbon emissions to the EU.

headline: With Lackluster Debut, Facebook Must Prove Itself to Investors
abstract: The lack of a bounce in Facebook’s stock price on its first day might mean that investors are not comfortable with the high valuation for the social media site.

headline: Indians Host Clinton While Also Wooing Iran
abstract: New Delhi staged diplomatic choreography this week, with both the Americans and the Iranians in town.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Documentary Filmmaker Wins Against I.R.S., Which Saw Her as a Hobbyist
abstract: The agency disputed Lee Storey’s deductions related to making and marketing the film “Smile ‘Til It Hurts: The Up With People Story,” arguing that she wasn’t engaged in a business. The tax court disagreed.

headline: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Enters Bankruptcy Process
abstract: The educational and trade publisher, financially troubled for several years, has agreed with most of its senior lenders and bondholders to a restructuring that would convert existing long-term debt to equity.

headline: A Costly Toy Subsidized by Others
abstract: If rich guys are going to buy their toys, they should probably use only their own money.

headline: Colloquial Music Reflects Changes in Rural Indian Romance
abstract: Scores of of songs in the Bhojpuri language, commonly used in north India, celebrate the mobile phone both as a fashion statement and a handy tool for romance.

headline: Dim Prospects for Financial Crisis Prosecutions
abstract: Two items in the news last week underscore that the likelihood for a signature case arising out of the financial crisis is near zero.

headline: Did Blankfein Snub Paulson?
abstract: In television appearances on Wednesday, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, claimed that “my predecessors didn’t go to China.” That would be news to Henry M. Paulson Jr.

headline: Image of the Day: May 7
abstract: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, left, returns a traditional gesture from West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee.

headline: Discovery Buys Revision3, Producer of Web Video Series
abstract: Discovery, the television-focused owner of the Discovery channel, TLC, Animal Planet and other cable channels, was said to have paid roughly $30 million for the company.

headline: Bank of America, Focusing Less on Retail, Leans on Trading for Profit
abstract: Bank of America reported a better-than-expected operating profit in the first quarter, as lower credit losses among consumers and strength on Wall Street offset continuing weakness in its mortgage business.

headline: Today’s Technologies Need an Off-the-Hook Option
abstract: Before smartphones and unlimited communications, people could escape by taking phones off the hook, making it impossible to get through. Don’t today’s smartphones and computers need the same technological solution?

headline: Bank of America Hires Senior Oppenheimer Health Care Banker
abstract: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired Brian McCarthy from Oppenheimer & Company as a vice chairman of health care investment banking, the firm announced on Monday in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

headline: Q&A: The Life and Obsolescence of a Windows System
abstract: Each version of Microsoft Windows has its own technical-support lifespan.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Citigroup’s First-Quarter Net Income Falls 2%
abstract: Citigroup, however, reported better-than-expected revenue growth on Monday, driven by steady demand for loans from consumers and businesses and an improving economic condition in the United States.

headline: New Republic Cancels Lottery to Attend Washington Dinner
abstract: The contest, which would have sent a magazine subscriber to White House Correspondents’ Association dinner, was found to violate the association’s rules.

headline: Seeing Red Flags Where None Exist
abstract: As we near the 10th anniversary of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, there seems to be an overzealous effort to point to red flags that corporate boards may have missed even when there is no evidence of illegal intent or bad faith, the author writes.

headline: Business Day Live: Old Money in New Tech
abstract: Why markets reacted negatively to comments by the Federal Reserve; Kevin Roose lives like a billionaire for a day; and heirs to old money are plunging into technology.

headline: France, and the World, Drinks More Pink
abstract: French consumption of white and red wines – especially the latter – has been falling steadily in recent years, but sales of rosé continue to soar. And although most French rosé is drunk in France, exports have risen too.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Spotlight on Rupert Murdoch, and Surfing YouTube’s Channels
abstract: Also, an investigation into whether Hollywood made illegal payments to China, and Jimmy Kimmel talks about his newest hosting job.

headline: The Best Countries to Be a Woman — and the Worst
abstract: India is last among the G20 and the United States didn’t crack the top five in the latest survey to reflect poorly on the situation of American women.

headline: American Lawyer to Revise Dewey’s Financials
abstract: The American Lawyer magazine plans to revise the last two years of financial results for Dewey & LeBoeuf, the New York law firm struggling with a wave of partner departures.

headline: Signs of a Shift as ‘G.M.A.’ Again Leads ‘Today’ in Viewers
abstract: Two weeks ago, “Good Morning America” finally topped the “Today” show, ending a 16-year winning streak. This week, it appears that “G.M.A.” will win again, and by a bigger margin.

headline: Readers React to Surveillance Software for Parents
abstract: The issue sparked a spirited conversation among Times readers, who were largely split into two camps: those who thought that monitoring would damage the trust between parents and their children, and those who feel that the Internet raises new challenges that require new tools.

headline: Boombox Provides Fun in the Sun
abstract: Etón’s Rukus is a lightweight, portable sound system that works with any Bluetooth-enabled device or computer. Staying true to its belief in green technology, Etón offers a solar-powered version as well.

headline: Former Facebook Executive Joins General Catalyst
abstract: Kevin Colleran is joining General Catalyst Partners as a venture partner, becoming the latest executive to leave Facebook in order to tackle venture capital.

headline: An Earlier Housing Bubble
abstract: On the 17th-century Dutch craze for dollhouses.

headline: Barclays Names Chief Strategy Officer and New Heads of Global Finance
abstract: Barclays has named Larry Wieseneck as its chief strategy officer for corporate and investment banking, a newly created role, according to an internal memorandum. He will be succeeded by John Langley and Joe McGrath.

headline: The World’s Unbanked Poor
abstract: A World Bank report finds little access to financial services among much of the world’s population, a condition that itself may perpetuate poverty.

headline: Agency Competing on ‘The Pitch’ to Make a Pitch for Diversity in Advertising
abstract: Muse Communications, which is led by an African-American, plans to take an ad out during the AMC show it is competing on, to call for more diversity in advertising.

headline: Daily Report: A Corporate Web Makeover How-To
abstract: Despite high hopes and careful planning, the Newark Nut Company’s Web traffic took a dive after changing its online name to Nuts.com.

headline: Glaxo to Make Hostile Bid for Human Genome Sciences
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline plans to take its bid for Human Genome Sciences directly to shareholders this week, after being rejected by the biotechnology company last month.

headline: No-Foreign-Fee Cards Still Best for Overseas Spending
abstract: The average credit card fee for foreign transactions has fallen from a year ago, a Card Hub analysis finds.

headline: What They Said: India Tests Agni V Nuclear Missile
abstract: India’s scientists have “done the country proud,” the Prime Minister says.

headline: Government Makes Case for Wiretaps Against Gupta
abstract: Prosecutors are seeking to have three wiretap recordings featuring the convicted hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam admitted as evidence at the trial of Rajat Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs board member.

headline: Image of the Day: April 20
abstract: Paramilitary soldiers removed a barbed wire fence during the demolition of a security bunker in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Verizon Clarifies: Unlimited Data Plans to Die Slow Death
abstract: Verizon said Thursday that customers with unlimited data plans would no longer be grandfathered in if they wanted to buy a discounted new phone. The company clarified its position after some publications incorrectly reported that it would kill unlimited data the instant shared data plans were introduced.

headline: Daily Report: Google to Make Zagat the ‘Cornerstone’ of Local Search
abstract: Google announced Wednesday that it is planning to make Zagat, the restaurant-ratings publisher that it bought last year for $151 million in cash, the cornerstone of a new free service, Google Plus Local, reports Glenn Collins of The New York Times. The new service is intended to enhance Google’s growing, potentially lucrative local information offerings.

headline: An Advance Toward the Front Lines for Female Marines
abstract: The Marine Corps is bringing women into units that had been male-only, starting with its infantry officer school at Quantico, in Virginia, and some ground combat battalions.

headline: U.S. Said to Have Picked an Ambassador to Myanmar
abstract: The United States will soon name Derek J. Mitchell as the new ambassador to Myanmar, according to two news reports. Mr. Mitchell is currently the administration’s special envoy to the country, which it still calls Burma. Washington has not had a full-fledged ambassador there since 1990.

headline: New York Radio Rivals Kiss-FM and WBLS to Merge
abstract: The merger is part of a shuffle involving three broadcasters that will give ESPN radio a stronger frequency. KISS, a bastion of black music for three decades, will merge onto WBLS.

headline: The Challenges in Hedging Tail Risk
abstract: Alan Gerstein of BlueMountain Capital Management notes that fewer and fewer market participants are willing or able to sell long-term put options despite demand from investors.

headline: The Flaws in the New Liquidation Authority
abstract: Congress could have enacted an insolvency process that was comprehensive, but instead the Dodd-Frank liquidation authority still does not cover major parts of a large financial institution.

headline: Friday Reading: Why a Large Soft Drink Can Look So Small
abstract: Why a large soda can look so small, a new debate among women about having it all, Facebook alters its policy for its “like” button and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Milken Conference Kicks Off With Panel on Global Growth
abstract: Representatives from Wall Street, including Vikram Pandit of Citigroup and Leon Black of Apollo Global Management, are planning to attend what has become a West Coast Davos.

headline: Your Tech Questions Answered, Part 5
abstract: Sam Grobart, writer of the new tech-help column Tool Kit, answers readers’ questions that have been posted online.

headline: Hollywood to Back Effort to Aid Veterans’ Return to Civilian Life
abstract: The program, Got Your 6 — military slang for “I’ve got your back” — will involve all six major movie studios, the four big broadcast networks, Hollywood’s largest talent agencies and a slew of cable channels.

headline: Apple Chief’s Offhand Comment Spawns Internet Quip
abstract: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, made an easily overlooked comment in Apple’s conference call with Wall Street analysts on Tuesday evening during the discussion of impressive quarterly sales and profits. But, of course, the Internet overlooks nothing, and so begin the tweets from the toaster-fridge.

headline: In Case Against Philip Falcone, a Warning to Others
abstract: Securities fraud charges filed against Philip Falcone and his firm, Harbinger Capital Partners, are a warning that hedge funds can now expect the same scrutiny that Wall Street banks and brokerage firms receive.

headline: Parent of Outback Steakhouse Plans to Go Public
abstract: Outback’s parent company, which is owned by private equity firms, has filed to go public. Buyout shops have been seeking to take advantage of improving market conditions to generate real gains for themselves and their investors.

headline: Insider Trading Crackdown Ensnares Hollywood Producer
abstract: The agency says Mohammed Mark Amin, a producer of such films as “Frida” and “Eve’s Bayou,” and several of his family members traded on insider tips he learned about DuPont Fabros Technology, a publicly held company that operates and manages data centers.

headline: Goldman’s Muni Chief Heads to Fundamental Advisors
abstract: Hector Negroni, the head of municipal bond trading at Goldman Sachs, is leaving the firm to set up a new investment fund at Fundamental Advisors, the private equity firm said on Tuesday.

headline: Talk of Facebook Interest Drives Shares in European Web Browser
abstract: Shares in the Norwegian Internet browser company Opera Software rose by as much as 22 percent on Tuesday after reports surfaced that Facebook might be looking to buy the company.

headline: Digital Notes: ‘Weird Al’ Yankovic Sues Sony for $5 million
abstract: The performer ‘Weird Al’ Yankovic sues Sony for $5 million in unpaid royalties and money from the music industry’s deal with Google. Also, songwriters in Britain now make more money from digital music than in pubs.

headline: Univision Takes a Few Shots at NBC in Seeking Advertisers’ Dollars
abstract: A Univision executive’s presentation noted that the network had beaten NBC 195 nights in prime time last year, and included a slide that showed the peacock symbol keeling over.

headline: Chinese Companies on an Overseas Shopping Spree
abstract: Foreign acquisitions by Chinese companies more than doubled in the first quarter, with South America and Europe being the main targets and most money going into deals in the resources and energy sectors.

headline: Business Day Live: Euro Bonds
abstract: Hunting for new bank customers on college campuses. After Facebook, enthusiasm ebbs in the I.P.O. market. Could the euro bond ever be more than an idea?

headline: Image of the Day: June 19
abstract: Badminton player Saina Nehwal displays the medals she won at the Indonesia Open and the Thailand Open.

headline: Social Drawing, an Up-and-Coming Marketing Tool
abstract: To promote the new season of “Cake Boss” on TLC, there will be contests to design a cake using Doodle.ly, a social-drawing app.

headline: Have You Tried to Refinance Your Underwater Mortgage?
abstract: This week’s Your Money column looks at the government’s latest attempt to help some homeowners refinance mortgages, even though they owe more than their homes are worth.

headline: Senate to Hold Antitrust Hearings on Universal-EMI Deal
abstract: The proposed $1.9 billion takeover of EMI’s recorded-music division by Universal Music Group has been criticized by advocacy groups and rival music labels as resulting in too much market concentration.

headline: Canada Seeks to Turn Coins Into Digital Currency
abstract: Last month, Canada announced that it would eliminate its penny. Now the Royal Canadian Mint is using one of the oldest forms of currency, gold, to attract software developers to its project, the MintChip Challenge, to transform the country’s remaining coins into digital currency.

headline: ‘Devious Maids,’ Rejected by ABC, Ends Up on Lifetime
abstract: The show was expected to land on the fall ABC schedule because of its pedigree: it is the latest comedy-drama from one of ABC’s biggest hit makers, Marc Cherry of “Desperate Housewives.”

headline: What Must-Have Apps Is Microsoft Missing?
abstract: It is not yet clear whether the selection of apps in the Windows Phone Marketplace will be enough to convince smartphone shoppers to come on board. While many of the must-have mobile applications are available, many are missing. What are your must-have apps?

headline: Lionsgate Chief Marketing Officer Will Stay in Role ‘Long Term’
abstract: Lionsgate said on Wednesday that Tim Palen would continue “long term” as chief marketing officer, ending a power struggle over marketing duties resulting from the studio’s acquisition of Summit Entertainment.

headline: What Rule Should the Fed Follow?
abstract: Conservatives seem determined to try to bar the Federal Reserve from exercising judgment on monetary policy, asserting that it should focus solely on preventing inflation, an economist writes.

headline: Congressman and Privacy Group Call for Google Inquiry
abstract: The Electronic Privacy Information Center, based in Washington, asked the Department of Justice to investigate Google on Tuesday, after more news emerged surrounding Google’s collection of personal information from wireless home networks in 2010.

headline: News Corporation’s Big Move: Murdoch Informs the Staff
abstract: After a vote by the board of directors Wednesday night, the company confirmed it would spin off its newspaper unit as a separate company.

headline: Goldman Stuck With a Defense Tab, and Awaiting a Payback
abstract: Goldman Sachs must continue to pay Mr. Gupta’s bills until the case is completely resolved, a process that could take a couple of years.

headline: A Conversation With : Urban Planner Rahul Mehrotra
abstract: The Harvard professor and architect talks about India’s urban challenges.

headline: Panel Rejects Proposal to Allow Election-Related Trading
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission rejected a plan for so-called political event contracts, wary of mixing politics and trading. The agency ruled, in part, that such trading amounted to gambling — and that it could unduly influence election results.

headline: In Judging Hostile Bids, Look at How Recent Targets Fared
abstract: Companies that have prospered by spurning offers and remaining independent usually have a strong, informed board that is willing to stand up to both its chief executive and a hostile raider.

headline: Airbnb and the Big Liability Insurance Questions
abstract: Should all Airbnb and HomeAway hosts have a separate liability insurance policy on top of their homeowner’s insurance? If so, shouldn’t the rental companies sell it to them?

headline: UBS Banker Joins TAP Advisors
abstract: Omar Jaffrey, who spent nine years as a managing director at UBS, will focus on advising technology and media clients at TAP, a boutique investment bank.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: AstraZeneca Reaches $1.26 Billion Deal for Ardea Biosciences
abstract: The European drug maker AstraZeneca agreed on Monday to buy the biotech company Ardea Biosciences for $1.26 billion, the latest in a recent series of deals in the global pharmaceutical industry.

headline: Indian Executives Vouch for Rajat K. Gupta in Court
abstract: Mr. Gupta “inspires trust” and was a mentor, witnesses say.

headline: A Filmmaker Chases an Israeli Spy Story
abstract: Elan Frank wants to make a film about Arnon Milchan, a Hollywood film producer who moonlighted for an Israeli intelligence agency, but Mr. Milchan has declined interview requests.

headline: The Tension of Teaching Journalism in China
abstract: Western foreign correspondents — Peter Arnett, the Pulitzer Prize-winning war correspondent among them — are increasingly becoming university professors in China, in a nation that wants international expertise but also grapples with its own issues with free speech.

headline: Banks Tread a Fine Line in Trading
abstract: Widespread trading practices are creating a headache for regulators who are trying to devise rules to prevent another financial crisis.

headline: Icahn Discloses Stake in Chesapeake Energy
abstract: Carl C. Icahn reported on Friday that he held a 7.56 percent stake in Chesapeake Energy and called for a board shake-up.

headline: Where Enterprise Enemies Hug
abstract: A project called OpenStack has the backing of over 160 companies, including some more used to competing, like Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Dell. The sudden love is all about the threat they all face from Amazon. Looking at the structure of the deal, it is hard to see how anyone will stay friends for long.

headline: Young Women Are More Career-Driven Than Men
abstract: Women 18 to 34 years old now place more importance on having a high-paying career or profession than their male counterparts do, according to survey data from the Pew Research Center.

headline: Titanic Commerce or Family Heirlooms?
abstract: Descendants of the doomed ship’s victims complain that auctioning off their ancestors’ personal effects is a violation of the families’ rights.

headline: ’30 Rock’ Will Return, but Only for 13 Episodes, NBC Says
abstract: The show was not given a full run, but the shorter run will be enough to guarantee the comedy continues to make profits for its owner in sales in syndication — NBC.

headline: Deutsche Bank Earnings Fall 34%, Worse Than Expected
abstract: The bank said its first-quarter profit fell as the European debt crisis continued to depress fees from trading and other investment banking activities.

headline: Green Mountain Replaces Chairman After Margin Call
abstract: The founder of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, Robert P. Stiller, was replaced as chairman after he sold five million shares, worth around $125.5 million, to pay off loans he had taken out against his sizable stock holdings in the company.

headline: Beauty, Height and Success
abstract: Being tall and good-looking can provide advantages in life, but mostly for those vastly taller or better-looking than others, a researcher has found.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: U.S. Offers $10 Million Reward for Pakistani Militant
abstract: The reward for the capture of the militant leader Hafiz Saeed, accused of orchestrating the 2008 Mumbai attacks.

headline: Bernanke Quietly Criticizes Lack of Repo Reforms
abstract: In a speech Monday night, the Federal Reserve chairman highlighted the lack of progress in overhauling something called the tri-party repo market, through which banks and other financial firms borrow and lend money.

headline: USA Network Asked Squealing Fans to Show Up at Upfront
abstract: The network managed to attract a huge, raucous crowd for stars who are less than household names.

headline: CW Network Unveils a Remake of Its Schedule
abstract: The network will fold in new shows and move existing ones in its fall lineup, which will start in October. One new drama, “Emily Owens, M.D.” will feature a surgical intern at a hospital that seems more like a high school.

headline: Smartphones: The New Post-Coital Cigarette?
abstract: Americans are addicted to their smartphones. The latest confirmation comes from a Harris Interactive survey of more than 2,000 smartphone owners, which shows the first thing Americans do after sex is reach for their cellphone. Twice that many said they couldn’t use the bathroom without them.

headline: Business Day Live: Jobless Benefits Stopping Early
abstract: The long-term unemployed face the end of benefits. Microsoft still working to integrate Skype. After Facebook’s troubled debut, smaller investors shy away from stocks.

headline: Young and Restless Students Race Sophisticated Mini-Machines in Detroit
abstract: St.Columba’s School in New Delhi was one of the winners at a student automotive design challenge in Detroit.

headline: Sun Rises, and There Will Be a ‘Law & Order’ on NBC
abstract: The “Law & Order” franchise began in 1990, ultimately leading to four different versions. The last one standing, “S.V.U.,” was just renewed for its 14th season.

headline: Oracle Buys Collective Intellect to Bolster Social Media Analysis
abstract: The technology giant said it had acquired Collective Intellect, a social media analysis firm, just a day after Salesforce.com agreed to buy Buddy Media for $689 million.

headline: Turntable Setup for the Obsessive
abstract: For people who are new setting up a turntable (and a bit obsessive about it) there Michael Fremer’s instructional DVD, “21st Century Vinyl,” which is a detailed video of how to configure a turntable.

headline: Martha Stewart Returns as Chairwoman of Her Namesake Company
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia said Wednesday that Ms. Stewart had been elected nonexecutive chairwoman of the company she founded.

headline: Borrowers Share Their Student Debt Stories
abstract: Borrowers’ struggles with private student loans are detailed in comments made to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Jewelers and Film Stars Align
abstract: Bollywood as a vehicle for Indian jewelry designers to attract customers.

headline: Mayor’s Feud With Press Is Escalating in Toronto
abstract: The cold war between Rob Ford, Toronto’s mayor, and The Toronto Star, the highest circulation newspaper in Canada, reached a new level last week after a complaint from Mr. Ford led to a police investigation of one of The Star’s City Hall reporters.

headline: Debating the Merits of Patent Warfare
abstract: In an often testy on-stage discussion at the D: All Things Digital conference in California, Nathan Myhrvold vigorously defended his business. The founder and chief executive of Intellectual Ventures has become one of Silicon Valley’s favorite villains, seen as little more than a shakedown artist.

headline: Image of the Day: June 4
abstract: Sachin Tendulkar enters India’s Parliament.

headline: Despite Nook, Barnes & Noble Sales Miss Expectations
abstract: For the first time, the company reported results for the Nook division separately. It recorded Nook sales of $933 million for the full fiscal year, an increase of 34 percent over the previous year.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Assistant Testifies in Gupta Trial
abstract: The former executive assistant for the hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam described a call she received from Rajat Gupta on Sept. 23, 2008, about 10 minutes before the market closed.

headline: An Ancient Civilization, Upended by Climate Change
abstract: The Indus Valley Civilization that existed nearly 4,500 years ago could have been destroyed by climate change, scientists say.

headline: Video: LinkedIn’s Bare Bones Approach to Security
abstract: While it is not surprising that LinkedIn was hacked, security experts were surprised at how weak the company’s defenses against breaches were. Nicole Perlroth and David Gillen discuss.

headline: IDC Says Nokia Shipped 2.2 Million Lumia Phones Last Quarter
abstract: Nokia’s new Lumia smartphones are widely regarded as the Finnish handset maker’s last stand before it cedes the smartphone battle to Apple and Google. But how are the phones selling? One estimate suggests that shipments so far are relatively small.

headline: The Children’s Investment Fund Wages Battle With Coal India
abstract: The Children’s Investment Fund, a minority shareholder, has threatened to sue unless the government-owned company makes decisions that consider minority shareholders’ interests.

headline: British Prosecutor Drops Suspect in Kaupthing Investigation
abstract: On Monday, Britain’s Serious Fraud Office dropped the property tycoon Vincent Tchenguiz as a suspect in its investigation into the collapse of Icelandic bank Kaupthing, less than a month after law enforcement agency admitted mistakes in the inquiry.

headline: Madonna’s Sprint to No. 1 Has Made the Fall Even Harder
abstract: The 86.7 percent drop in sales for “MDNA” is a symptom of music’s new promotional rhythm, which is coming to resemble the movie business, with an obsession on winning the opening weekend.

headline: From ABC News and Univision, an English-Language Channel for Hispanics
abstract: The channel — as yet unnamed — would start sometime in the first half of 2013 and include lifestyle, entertainment and health-related programming in addition to traditional news shows.

headline: Great French Debate, So Why Not Have More?
abstract: The two candidates for the French presidency held a bruising three-hour debate just four days ahead of the election. Should voters have had a chance to see them square off earlier in the campaign?

headline: Child Servants in India: Rare Case or Routine?
abstract: The case of the teenage maid who was allegedly locked in a New Delhi apartment has sparked a heated discussion about child labor.

headline: A Conversation With: Zuber Jafri
abstract: The youngest child of Ahsan Jafri, the member of parliament who was killed in the Gujarat riots, on the family’s fight and his father’s legacy.

headline: Flipboard Finally Reaches Android Users
abstract: Flipboard, the popular iOS social-news app, is now available as a preview to Android users.

headline: Facebook Shares Slump on Second Day
abstract: Facebook’s stock closed down 11 percent on Monday, to around $34 a share.

headline: Republican Keynesians
abstract: Republicans may regularly bash Keynesian economics, but they feel free to rely on it to justify policies they support, an economist writes.

headline: Facebook Raises Offering Share Price
abstract: Facebook says it will price its offering at up to $38 a share, which would value the social network at as much as $104 billion.

headline: Active Government Means More Lobbying
abstract: With government expanding its reach into new areas of activity, it is to be expected that the amount spent on lobbying and campaign finance will grow as well, an economist writes.

headline: Britain Fines Japanese Insurer $5.3 Million
abstract: The Financial Services Authority has fined the Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance Company of Japan £3.3 million for poor corporate governance practices at the insurer’s subsidiary based in London.

headline: Friday Reading: What the Health Care Ruling Means for Medicare
abstract: What the health care ruling means for Medicare, car rentals for the “eco-curious,” how to securely erase a hard drive and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Stimulus Even Republicans Can Support
abstract: Heading off scheduled cuts in military spending could appeal to both parties, and broadly defining such spending could make it a useful source of economic growth, an economist writes.

headline: Setting a Budget (Set to a Hip-Hop Beat)
abstract: A contest encouraged students to set their thoughts about money to a hip-hop beat.

headline: Wikipedia Kills Page Linking Obama Slogan to Socialist Movement
abstract: The page, which suggested that the slogan “Forward” was inextricably linked with far-left publications, became a cause among some right-wing commentators.

headline: Taking All Responsibility for What’s in Your I.R.A.
abstract: Self-directed individual retirement accounts hold the promise of better returns than traditional I.R.A.’s but also the possibility of deeper losses.

headline: Investor Group Buys Orange County Register and Other Newspapers
abstract: The group led by Aaron Kushner, a 39-year-old entrepreneur based in the Boston area, is buying several newspapers from Freedom Communications.

headline: China’s Bright Food Buys 60% of Weetabix
abstract: The transaction values the British cereal maker at $1.9 billion and marks the biggest overseas foray yet for Bright Food, after several unsuccessful attempts at foreign acquisitions.
