headline: In a Morning Media Blitz, Murdoch Defends His Newspaper Assets
abstract: “Dow Jones is a very viable company and The Wall Street Journal is a very viable newspaper,” Rupert Murdoch said in a phone interview with The New York Times.

headline: Ask About the Egyptian Election
abstract: Egyptians are going to the polls in the country’s first ever competitive presidential race, Do you have questions about the candidates and the stakes? Ask them here.

headline: At Best Buy, Lumia Is Selling O.K. but More Slowly Than Android
abstract: Nokia and AT&T have aggressively promoted the new Lumia 900 smartphone with a big marketing campaign, but at Best Buy, Lumia sales still pale in comparison to the hottest Android phones, an executive there says.

headline: MF Global Trustee Says Claims May Exceed $3 Billion
abstract: Louis J. Freeh, the trustee overseeing the bankruptcy of MF Global, estimates that creditors, including banks, big investors and service providers, could have more than $3 billion in claims against the failed brokerage.

headline: Seattle: Leave Our Amazon Alone!
abstract: As leading tech firms grow ever more prominent and pervasive, questions are increasingly being asked about their labor practices, attitudes toward customers’ data, unyielding competitive streaks and other aspects of their corporate DNA. Is creating jobs and wealth for stockholders enough? When Amazon was in the cross hairs, Seattle said, “Leave ’em alone!”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Your Tech Questions, Answered: Part 1
abstract: Sam Grobart, writer of the new tech-help column Tool Kit, answers readers’ questions posted online.

headline: Regulator Proposes New Rule for Large Derivatives Trades
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission voted to introduce a draft rule that limits how firms can qualify for exemptions through so-called block trades.

headline: Retirement, Slipping Farther and Farther Away
abstract: Over the last decade and a half, Americans’ expected retirement age has slowly risen to 67 from 60, according to a new Gallup survey.

headline: DirecTV and Tribune Fail to Reach Deal
abstract: DirecTV customers in 19 markets woke up on Sunday without Fox or the CW networks on their television sets, the result of a failed negotiation with Tribune Broadcasting.

headline: Obama Video on Fox News Criticized as Attack Ad
abstract: Conservative and liberal observers said the video had the hallmarks of a campaign attack ad, except that it was produced and paid for by a news network rather than a candidate or a political action committee.

headline: A Conversation With: Freida Pinto and Michael Winterbottom
abstract: The lead actress and director of “Trishna,” talk about the film based on Thomas Hardy’s novel “Tess of the d’Urbervilles.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter’s New Home and Electronic Eavesdropping
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes Google moving against a Web site that feeds on YouTube, the physical underpinnings of the Internet and GPS pictures made by pizza deliverers.

headline: Shell Lifts Cove Energy Bid to $1.8 Billion
abstract: Royal Dutch Shell has increased its offer for the oil and natural gas exploration company Cove Energy, in an effort to expand into the fast-growing natural gas industry in East Africa.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: New Entry in the Tablet Landscape, and a More Hip NPR
abstract: Microsoft unveiled a tablet called Surface, meant to compete with the iPad. NPR, with its core shows aging, is looking for some new programs aimed at younger, more diverse audiences.

headline: Goldman Executive to Join Bank of America
abstract: Diego de Giorgi is set to become the co-head of global corporate and investment banking for Europe at Bank of America.

headline: Westlake Abandons $1.2 Billion Bid for Georgia Gulf
abstract: The decision follows acquisition talks with Georgia Gulf’s management that had been aimed at creating one of the largest producers of building materials like olefins and vinyls.

headline: Your Choice for World Bank President?
abstract: The United States has been able to say who will lead the World Bank since its creation in 1944. But the world has changed since then. Is it time for the Bank to change too?

headline: Digital Notes: A Boss for ‘Six Strikes’ Copyright Enforcement
abstract: The Center for Copyright Information names an executive director and four board members to oversee its “six strikes” plan for controlling online piracy; Bono and the Edge of U2 invest in Dropbox.

headline: In TV Race, Microsoft Has Lead, Forrester Says
abstract: When it comes to the underlying technology providers that matter for mobile app developers, there’s Google and Apple, with Microsoft as an also-ran. But as television begins to resemble the mobile business, Microsoft is in the lead with the Xbox, according to a new report out Wednesday from Forrester Research.

headline: After Rapes Involving Children, Skout, a Flirting App, Bans Minors
abstract: After a spate of rape cases involving adults and minors in California, Wisconsin and Ohio who connected on Skout, the start-up is rethinking its business model as a flirting app for adults and teenagers. Christian Wiklund, Skout’s founder, is suspending its service for minors on Tuesday.

headline: Regulators Looking Into JPMorgan Trading Activities Before $2 Billion Loss
abstract: The Federal Reserve and Financial Services Authority of Britain have been in discussions with JPMorgan Chase since April about the trading group that on Thursday disclosed more than $2 billion in losses.

headline: What Must Be Done Now to Save the Euro?
abstract: Europe’s leaders and the European Central Bank must act aggressively and quickly to stabilize a perilous economic situation, an economist writes.

headline: Footing the Bill for MF Global’s Lawyers
abstract: As most large company do, MF Global bought insurance to pay for the expenses its employees might incur if they were investigated and found liable for actions taken while working for the firm. As unfair as it may seem, it is the company insurance that pays these legal costs, even in bankruptcy.

headline: Barclays Capital and Deutsche Bank Pick Up A.I.G. Assets
abstract: The MAX C.D.O. portfolio, which has a face value of $7.5 billion, was sold to the Barclays-Deutsche Bank group after an auction in which large rival banks teamed up to form bidding consortiums.

headline: Does Mitt Romney Really Abhor Europe?
abstract: Mitt Romney clearly thinks there are votes to be won by comparing President Obama with the interventionist, welfare-loving leaders of Europe. But does he really mean what he says about Europe or is it a campaign ploy? And why do Europe’s conservatives not like him?

headline: Happy Bloomsday! The World Celebrates James Joyce
abstract: Stout, grilled kidneys and public readings — a typical Bloomsday in Dublin — but this year expect a Joycean revival as the master’s works come out of copyright.

headline: A Worrisome Rise in Jobless Claims
abstract: The odds increased that the economy has fallen into a spring slowdown for the third straight year.

headline: Spotwag Helps Facebook Friends Find Pet Sitters
abstract: When a pet owner is heading out of town, Spotwag wants to help people find friends to look after their furry friends using Facebook and Twitter.

headline: As Income Inequality Grows, Some Movement at the Top and Bottom
abstract: Turnover in the different income brackets — some wealthy slide down, some lower-income people climb — helps mitigate the impact of income inequality, an economist writes.

headline: James Murdoch Is One of the Crowd at Fox’s Upfront Party
abstract: Coming off his recent TV appearance — giving testimony to a British inquiry on phone-hacking — Mr. Murdoch was taking in the sales pitch for the new Fox season.

headline: More Goldman Partners Head for the Exit
abstract: Muneer A. Satter, Hughes Lepic and Gerald J. Cardinale are all retiring from Goldman Sachs, according to a memo to employees.

headline: The ‘Heady Rush’ of Freedom in College, and How to Manage It
abstract: The author, a native of Mumbai studying at New York University, writes that her dreams of unlimited freedom were brought to earth by the realization that “real life isn’t set to music.”

headline: Raf Simons Takes on the Dior Mantle
abstract: The Belgian designer Raf Simons is expected to be named as the next artistic director of Christian Dior. The post has been empty for more than a year since the dramatic departure of John Galliano in March 2011.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Plan for Online Database of Political TV Ads
abstract: Moving the files collected by local TV stations onto the Internet was described by the commission’s chairman, Julius Genachowski, as a “common sense” step toward transparency.

headline: E.A. and Google Got Game
abstract: Electronic Arts is using Google’s big developer conference this week to showcase a high-quality multiplayer game written in HTML5 that can be played on phones, tablets, and PCs. E.A. hopes it lowers production costs and lures more developers to make games in HTML5.

headline: Business Day Live: How Apple Sidesteps Billions in Taxes
abstract: Charles Duhigg and David Kocieniewski answer questions and respond to reader comments about Apple’s efforts to minimize its taxes.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Many Workers Remain Underpaid and Underemployed
abstract: Many workers remain underpaid and underemployed, groups urge Facebook not to aim ads at preteens, missing the smell and feel of actual books and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Instagram Fatigue and iPhone Prototypes
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selection includes an experimental superfast wireless network, the experience of two Condé Nast magazines with Flipboard and how Hollywood used Nokia.

headline: Why Cisco Stopped Making Tablets
abstract: Cisco has dropped out of the tablet business, saying people inside companies bring their own devices to work. It was called the Cius and, no, you couldn’t have been expected to know that. That said, Cisco may not be giving up on the Chrome operating system.

headline: Digital Notes: After Springsteen Flap, Ticketmaster Settles in Canada
abstract: Also, TuneIn, the popular radio aggregator, adds CBS stations to its roster.

headline: Monday Reading: Tips for an Easier Family Getaway
abstract: Tips for an easier family getaway, wearable gadgets that upset F.A.A. rules on devices, mapping your end-of-life choices and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: The ‘Medicine Baba’ Goes Door to Door
abstract: Omkar Nath Sharma collects unused medicine from the rich, and distributes it to the poor.

headline: Why Jim Yong Kim Wants to Run the World Bank
abstract: A conversation with the president of Dartmouth College, one of three candidates to lead the bank, and President Obama’s nominee.

headline: Business Day Live: Anger Over Facebook Claims
abstract: Nasdaq tries to quell anger over Facebook’s flawed initial public offering. I.B.M. makes a deal with New York City to increase solar energy usage. Cutting pensions in California.

headline: Image of the Day: May 14
abstract: A makeshift hair salon in Mayaong reserve forest, Assam.

headline: Microsoft Enters Office Socializing in $1.2 Billion Deal
abstract: Microsoft agreed to buy Yammer, an operator of private social networks for business, for $1.2 billion in cash, signaling a change in the communication habits of big companies.

headline: What Do Music’s Corporate Bosses Make? All Eyes on Live Nation
abstract: Irving Azoff, Live Nation’s executive chairman, made $34.6 million last year, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. With the mergers in the music industry, Live Nation is among the last of these companies that must release this information.

headline: Tata Wins Land Appeal, Deals Blow to Mamata Banerjee
abstract: Tata Motors won the legal battle against the West Bengal government that had forced the company to return land acquired to build the Nano, an ultracheap car.

headline: Head of British Bankers’ Association to Step Down
abstract: The departure of Angela Knight comes as the financial industry is facing a major overhaul in how it operates and as the association itself is coming under scrutiny over how the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, is set.

headline: India Says Pakistan Supported Planner of Mumbai Attacks
abstract: A mastermind of the attacks had Pakistan state support, India’s home ministry said.

headline: The Weiwei Way on View in Paris
abstract: For all his renown as the bad boy of Chinese art, precious little of Ai Weiwei’s work has been seen in the outside world. An exhibit at the Jeu de Paume aims to change that.

headline: As One JPMorgan Trader Sold Risky Contracts, Another One Bought Them
abstract: A mutual fund in a different part of the bank owns about $380 million worth of insurance identical to the kind the “London whale” sold.

headline: Test Scores and Housing Costs
abstract: Parents hoping to enroll their children in the best public schools have long known that where you live matters. A new study quantifies the difference in housing costs between areas with high- and low-performing schools.

headline: Rubenstein Buys a Copy of the Emancipation Proclamation for $2 Million
abstract: It is the latest acquisition of rare Americana by David M. Rubenstein, a co-founder of the private equity giant Carlyle Group.

headline: Murdoch on the Stand, Politicians in the Dock
abstract: Media mogul Rupert Murdoch began his long-awaited testimony to Britain’s judicial inquiry into media ethics on Wednesday. Politicians of all parties were bracing for potentially embarrassing revelations about their past ties with the News Corporation boss.

headline: In Washington, Mixed Messages Over Tighter Rules for Wall St.
abstract: Calls for a crackdown, which come as regulators are putting the finishing touches on the Volcker Rule and other overhaul measures, may not find many sympathetic ears in Washington.

headline: It Is Not Cricket! (It’s Politics)
abstract: As Tendulkar joins Parliament, India Ink looks at the similarities between the two disciplines.

headline: Deciphering the Hidden Rules That Tempt China’s Officials
abstract: In today’s China, where millionaires seem to sprout overnight, temptation is great among poorly paid officials.

headline: Dot-Music, Dot-Sport and (Security Experts Hope) Dot-Secure
abstract: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, is about to throw open the floodgates to new top-level domain names. While most security experts have criticized the change, one group sees an opportunity by creating what it says will be a secure top-level domain.

headline: Political Cartoon Taking Aim at Pipeline Company Is Pulled
abstract: Accounts differ on why The Province in Vancouver, British Columbia, pulled an animated parody of an Enbridge ad from its Web site.

headline: Friday Reading: Tight Medical Marijuana Laws Draw Dispensaries to Arizona
abstract: Competition in the medical marijuana market, rising numbers of wheel and tire thefts, more investors engaging in activism and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Silicon Valley as the New Hollywood
abstract: As is evident by the recent coverage in the mainstream gossip press, technology is no longer just a technology story.

headline: Yahoo’s Former Chief to Leave Without Severance
abstract: Yahoo’s departing chief executive, Scott Thompson, will leave without severance pay after being forced out over an erroneous academic record.

headline: A Ratings Victory for ‘Good Morning America’
abstract: ABC’s “Good Morning America” won a ratings battle on Wednesday, beating the “Today” show on NBC by 87,000 viewers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: What That Speeding Ticket May Really Cost You
abstract: Insurance.com lets you calculate the anticipated increase in your insurance premium after getting a ticket.

headline: Films, Literature Devote Little Attention to Female Feticide
abstract: Media attention to female feticide contrasts with the subject’s marginal treatment in mainstream Indian literature and cinema.

headline: A Tough Road for Wal-Mart Shareholders
abstract: Unfortunately for shareholders, a recent complaint filed by a pension fund is unlikely to result in any significant changes at Wal-Mart Stores.

headline: Facebook on Track for I.P.O. Roadshow
abstract: Despite rumors of delays, Facebook could begin its roadshow as soon as early next week, according to two people briefed on the company’s plans.

headline: The Beginnings of a Succession Plan
abstract: I don’t want to be the guy who drops dead unexpectedly and leaves his family with a mess to figure out.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Knowing When to Put an End to Therapy
abstract: Knowing when to put an end to therapy, Social Security’s financial health worsens, the confusion of hospital pricing and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Google Developers’ Conference
abstract: Electronic Arts develops an HTML5-based video game, competitive sailing adapts new technology to attract television views and Reading Rainbow takes young readers on a new adventure. Plus, a big step forward for iPad apps in the kitchen.

headline: Live Blog: Senate Banking Hearing on JPMorgan
abstract: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, testified on Wednesday before the Senate Banking Committee about a failed derivatives trade that could cost the bank as much as $5 billion in losses.

headline: Europe Slips in World Influence Stakes
abstract: The rest of the world has traditionally looked up to Europe as an example to be emulated, but a new survey suggests its reputation is declining. Should nations worry about how much, or little, they are loved?

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Planning for Zimmerman Trial, and What Breitbart Wrought
abstract: News outlets are preparing for a televised trial in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, how Amazon benefits from the lawsuit over e-book prices, and a profile of Andrew Breitbart, the conservative provocateur who was “jacked into the Web early and never unplugged.”

headline: Banks’ Fire Drill for Greece Election
abstract: After being largely unprepared for the extreme stress of the 2008 crisis, big banks in the United States are determined to be ready this time.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Painful Online Updates, and Ending a What-I-Ate-at-School Blog
abstract: Also, Facebook begins to deal with shareholder lawsuits in wake of its initial public offering, and AOL shareholders reject an attempt to unseat three directors.

headline: Quietly, Lazard’s Ex-C.E.O. Returns to the Firm
abstract: William R. Loomis Jr., a former chief executive of Lazard, has returned to the firm as a senior adviser, about a decade after stepping down as the investment bank’s leader.

headline: Dimon and the Fed’s Legitimacy
abstract: It’s time for Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase to step down from the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, an economist writes.

headline: Facebook Begins Ad Bidding System
abstract: On Wednesday, Facebook announced it would begin testing a new advertising mechanism using a technology called real-time bidding, which allows advertisers to place bids on ad space for specific groups of users at specific times.

headline: Medical Costs Contribute to Credit Card Debt
abstract: Medical costs are a big contributor to credit card debt, a survey of low- and moderate-income households finds.

headline: The Top 10 Rookie Mistakes for Entrepreneurs
abstract: In sports, you are a rookie for one year. In entrepreneurship, it can last many years.

headline: Goldman Prepares for Worst-Case Outcome in Europe
abstract: Gary D. Cohn says that Goldman is currently examining all euro-denominated contracts to understand what the ability to pay in a different currency would be if the euro disappears.

headline: Leaderless for Months, CBS Films Appoints Co-Presidents
abstract: Terry Press and Wolfgang Hammer will run the studio, succeeding Amy Baer, who resigned in September.

headline: The Boom in Online Freelance Workers
abstract: Global networks make it possible to obtain work anywhere, enabling companies to hire many specialists for specific tasks at fixed amounts. Chances are this is only getting started. A survey by Elance of its customers found that on average they think more than half of their work force will be freelancers in five years.

headline: Your Suggestions on Force-Placed Insurance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their own proposals for improving banks’ dealings with consumers on the issue of force-placed insurance for homeowners.

headline: At Parris Island, Basic Training Pulls Lessons From Marines’ Real-World Lapses
abstract: Marine drill instructors at Parris Island incorporate real-world experiences, including mistakes, into ethics lessons for recruits, known as “value-based training.”

headline: MF Global and the Risks Looming in the Repo Market
abstract: MF Global’s crippling bets were only possible because the brokerage firm was able to borrow voraciously in a debt market that also played a big role in the collapses of Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns.

headline: Barnes & Noble Shares Surge 18% After Jana Takes a Stake
abstract: Shares in Barnes & Noble soared more than 18 percent on Monday after the hedge fund Jana Partners announced it had bought a 12 percent stake in the bookseller.

headline: Volcker Defends a Rule Bearing His Name
abstract: Paul A. Volcker told the Senate Banking Committee that the influence of a ban on proprietary trading went “far beyond the particular risks” and that it also addressed “a cultural issue” on Wall Street.

headline: The Fog of Bank Accounting Adjustments
abstract: The unusual prominence of these adjustments in first-quarter releases from Bank of America, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley deserves scrutiny.

headline: Loopholes Abound Despite New Rules
abstract: Regulators are trying to clamp down on rogue traders like JPMorgan Chase’s Bruno Iksil, nicknamed the London Whale, who amassed large positions in credit derivatives as part of a complex trading strategy that eventually soured.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Giving Patients Choices in Colon Cancer Screening
abstract: Giving patients choices in colon-cancer screening, lenders once again woo riskier borrowers, making math fun with bedtime problems and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Where Did Gawker Media Get the Idea for Branches?
abstract: During the time it was building its new commenting system, Gawker met with the founder of Branch, a tiny start-up, several times. When Gawker’s final product came out last week, it bore a striking resemblance to the company’s product, and even used the same name.

headline: A Rare Private Equity Chieftain in Obama’s Camp
abstract: Hamilton E. James Jr., the president of Blackstone and one of the few prominent Democratic supporters from the private equity world, will host a fund-raiser for President Obama in mid-May, Nicholas Confessore reports for The New York Times Caucus blog.

headline: Battling Over Budget Cuts
abstract: The brief truce between the Air Force and the Air National Guard over proposed budget cuts may already be unraveling in the Senate.

headline: From Las Vegas to the Philippines, Shock Over Pacquiao Loss
abstract: The undefeated American boxer Timothy Bradley scored a controversial upset over Manny Pacquiao of the Philippines on Saturday night in Las Vegas, winning a split decision that brought Pac-Man’s Filipino fans, celebrity supporters and even other boxers onto Twitter to register their deep outrage.

headline: Google Ventures’ Big Data Bet
abstract: The venture capital firm funded by Google is building up its data sciences team to increase the capabilities inside its companies and to look for new investments in the area. The firm is extending a thesis that was developed inside Google about finding patterns in big collections of data, which it hopes will work in other industries.

headline: Business Day Live: Markets Digest French Election
abstract: Disney and Univision to create news channel aimed at Hispanics; what the election of François Hollande means for markets; and graduates flock to unpaid internships.

headline: Business Day Live: Entrepreneur Moms
abstract: Sallie L. Krawcheck’s proposals for bank reform. Joseph E. Stiglitz on economic inequality. Balancing entrepreneurship and motherhood.

headline: ‘The Voice’ May Not Be a Blockbuster, but It Is a Lifeline for NBC
abstract: Coming out of the Super Bowl in February, the signing-competition appeared to be headed for ratings domination, but then the competition got stiffer. Still, “The Voice” has made NBC tops on Monday night, when it used to be invisible.

headline: New York Fed May Sell More of Its A.I.G. Assets
abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Wednesday that it was considering selling pieces of a final special entity created to hold assets once owned by the American International Group.

headline: News Roundup: Panetta Defends Drone Strikes in Pakistan; Courts India
abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta brushed aside concerns that America was violating Pakistan’s sovereignty and called on India to deepen its relationship with the United States.

headline: BTG Pactual Surges on Trading Debut
abstract: BTG Pactual’s chief executive, André Esteves, called the offering — the biggest Brazilian I.P.O. since 2009. — “an enormous vote of confidence in Brazil by the global financial community.”

headline: Father in Chinese Forced-Abortion Scandal Is Said to Be Missing
abstract: The Chinese man who published photographs online of his wife and their dead fetus — government officials forced her to submit to an abortion at seven months — has gone missing after being tracked by security officials and thugs, according to his sister.

headline: Pandora’s Siren Song: Imitators Want Its Audience, but Not Its Losses
abstract: Attracted by Pandora’s popularity and the way it handles music licenses, many online music services have developed similar services.

headline: ING Direct Adds Remote Check Deposit App
abstract: ING Direct introduces a mobile check-deposit feature.

headline: Daily Report: Google Employees Know Nothing
abstract: Workers at Google said they were not aware of the data collection in the Street View project either because it was not part of their job or they did not review the project documentation.

headline: Rebates for Some Who Buy Own Health Insurance
abstract: About one third of people who buy their own health insurance are expected to get premium rebates this summer, an analysis of state data finds.

headline: The Euro Zone Crisis: A Primer
abstract: Questions and answers about the latest flare-up in the European financial turmoil and who might pay the price.

headline: Business Day Live: Gupta Set to Stand Trial
abstract: A well-connected executive goes to court on insider trading charges and men begin flocking to fields dominated by women.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Prospectus Humor and 3rd World Start-ups
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes an explanation of the dreaded vertical video syndrome, Tony Fadel on creativity and a discussion on why there are not more technology start-ups in developing countries.

headline: In Europe, a Dispute Over Facts and Fairness
abstract: Part of Europe’s problem is that Europeans can’t agree on some basic facts about the continent’s financial crisis, as a new Pew poll makes clear. Many Europeans say Germans are the hardest-working Europeans. Greeks, by contrast, say that Greeks are.

headline: Google Tries Again With Google TV
abstract: With Apple widely expected to unveil a full-fledged television later this year, Google is determined to reintroduce Google TV, an effort that failed to gain traction when it was introduced in 2010. LG will start rolling out Google TV-enabled television sets later this month.

headline: The Billionaire Family Backing the Avon Bid
abstract: Through their holding company, Joh. A. Benckiser, the Reimanns own some of the world’s most recognizable consumer brands, including Coty, Bally, Derek Lam, and the Reckitt Benckiser Group, a giant maker of household cleaning supplies.

headline: Talks With Instagram Suggest a $104 Billion Valuation for Facebook
abstract: In negotiations to buy the photo sharing service Instagram, the parties are said to have valued Facebook at roughly $104 billion, which could offer insight into the potential for the social network’s highly anticipated initial public offering in May.

headline: Military News Roundup: Taliban Evolution, Veteran Disabilities and Homelessness, and Panetta’s Travel
abstract: Military news from The New York Times, from Afghanistan to California.

headline: Sister to Sister: Celebrities and Aid
abstract: As men fight over whether development aid really helps those in need, female celebrities like Annie Lennox are rolling up their sleeves and becoming donor-activists. What do you make of their efforts?

headline: Thursday Reading: Free Online Courses From Harvard and M.I.T.
abstract: Harvard and M.I.T. offer free online courses, air travel between smaller cities is a marathon, keeping secrets on Facebook and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: American’s Best Customers Want It to Stay Independent
abstract: The results of the Your Money questionnaire of American Airlines customers about a possible merger for the airline and what loyalty program rule changes might result.

headline: As China Marches Ahead, Is It On Solid Ground?
abstract: Reports of a weakening economy, combined with concern over moral decline, pose a question for China: Do Communist states, perhaps, have a natural lifespan?

headline: Slum Scenes in ‘The Avengers’ Criticized in India
abstract: Residents of Kolkata complain the movie only shows the city’s squalor.

headline: Facebook (and Microsoft) vs. Google
abstract: When a young tech company with outsized ambitions goes public, somewhere an older tech company dies a little on the inside. So it was eight years ago with Microsoft, when Google sold shares to the public. As Facebook inches toward an I.P.O., it’s Google’s turn to feel the sting.

headline: People With Individual Health Plans Would Save Out-of-Pocket Under Reform, Study Finds
abstract: Older and lower-income Americans who buy their own health insurance would save under health reform, a study finds.

headline: Falcone’s LightSquared Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: LightSquared, a broadband wireless company that aimed to connect millions of customers in a far-reaching satellite network, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Graphics: Mergers and Acquisitions, Top Financial and Legal Advisers
abstract: In the first quarter of 2012, mergers and acquisition activity was down 34 percent worldwide to $481 billion. The U.S. share was $146 billion. Goldman Sachs and Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer were the top financial and legal advisers.

headline: ’30 Rock’ Satire of Kraft Sponsorship Is Sponsored by Kraft
abstract: The live episode offered a wacky history of live TV, including a ’50s-era sitcom supposedly part of “The Kraft Product Placement Comedy Hour.” That inclusion, in the 21st century, is called branded integration.

headline: Baku Bets on Eurovision Songfest
abstract: As viewers tune into the Eurovision Song Contest this weekend, human rights activists want them to think about the dark side of modern, glitzy Azerbaijan.

headline: Ackermann Hands Over Reins of Deutsche Bank
abstract: Josef Ackermann bowed out Thursday as the chief executive of Deutsche Bank after more than a decade in which he transformed the institution into a global contender but also became a symbol to many Germans of the excesses of capitalism.

headline: In New Ad Campaign, Orbitz Comes Out as Pro-Vacation
abstract: The idea is to bring emotion back into online travel, Orbitz executives say, as a way to differentiate Orbitz from competitors like Expedia and Travelocity and speak about something other than price.

headline: Soho House Expansion Plans Include Mumbai
abstract: London-based members-only club will open in India.

headline: The Prius V and Its Entune System
abstract: The Prius V is the first Toyota to incorporate a new electronics system, which a new owner found to be a boon.

headline: Cissy Houston Plans a Book on Her Daughter, Whitney, a k a ‘Nippy’
abstract: The gospel singer has been meeting with publishers to shop a book about her daughter, who died in February. How candid she will be could determine how much publishers are willing to spend on the book.

headline: German Law, Not European, if a Central Bank Defaults
abstract: One court has “exclusive competence” if the various central banks get into a legal argument over cash flows between them and the European Central Bank. It’s a German one, of course.

headline: Credit Suisse Expects Profit in Second Quarter
abstract: The Swiss financial giant moved to calm investors’ fears on Friday by announcing it expected to report a second-quarter profit.

headline: Facebook Advisers Propose Ways to Allow Tweens on the Site Officially
abstract: What should Facebook do to safely and legally let children under 13 use the site? Its advisers offer a wish list that includes an advertisement-free environment — a costly proposition for Facebook — and a requirement that children “friend” their parents on Facebook, so that they can see what is posted.

headline: Amid Drumbeat of Bad News, Investors Bet Against Facebook
abstract: Judging by Facebook’s short-interest levels, a good number of investors seem to be betting that the social network’s shares will struggle for some time.

headline: Tip of the Week: Quick View Changes in Windows 7
abstract: Change the icon size and view in Windows Explorer with a shortcut.

headline: BlackRock to Shift Business if Moody’s Downgrades Banks
abstract: BlackRock, the giant money manager, said it would have no choice but to move some of its business away from certain Wall Street firms if Moody’s Investors Service went ahead with its threat to downgrade some of the country’s biggest banks.

headline: Watson Is Said to Bid $5.9 Billion for Actavis
abstract: Watson Pharmaceuticals is expected to offer 4.5 billion euros for the Swiss drug maker Actavis Group, in a deal that would create one of the world’s largest generic drug manufacturers.

headline: Struggles at Oprah’s Network Drag Down Discovery’s Results
abstract: The company has spent more than $300 million on OWN but the network is losing more money than expected.

headline: Tip of the Week: Speed Dial for the Web
abstract: Visual bookmarks of your regularly visited sites can save time by letting you click a page thumbnail to start making your rounds on the Web.

headline: Graff Diamonds Said to Move Closer to $1 Billion I.P.O. in Hong Kong
abstract: By choosing Hong Kong for its initial public offering, the British diamond retailer, which has more than 30 stores around the world, is positioning itself near to its most important future growth market: China.

headline: Panetta Proposes New Sexual Assault Rules for the Military
abstract: Under pressure from Congress and veterans advocates, Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta on Monday announced new policies to combat sexual assault in the ranks.

headline: Software Service in India Tumbles After Forecast
abstract: The share price of software giant Infosys fell 13 percent on Friday.

headline: Video: Three Small Steps for Kitchen Technology
abstract: Three gadgets represent small steps by technology into the kitchen: a rice cooker, a kitchen thermometer and an espresso coffee maker.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Court Rules Against Assange and ‘Hatfields & McCoys’ Pulls in Viewers
abstract: Also, the show “Dirty Jobs” has inspired a line of cleaning products that will be available online and in stores including Walmart.

headline: A Swiss-E.U. Battle Over (European) Immigrants
abstract: Under its agreement with the European Union, Switzerland was supposed to abandon immigration restrictions on eastern E.U. members. After a big jump in immigrants, the Swiss are reconsidering.

headline: Will Rich People Desert the U.S. if Their Taxes Are Raised?
abstract: Americans renounce their citizenship for a variety of reasons, not solely to avoid United States taxation, an economist writes.

headline: Kutcher’s Arrival Helps Revive a Comedy
abstract: CBS announced that the reconstituted “Two and a Half Men” would be back for its 10th season in the fall with its new star, Ashton Kutcher, and the rest of the cast.

headline: Introducing Beth Shaw, a New Business Group Member
abstract: YogaFit faces several challenges. Annual sales are down from a high of $5 million in 2009, a drop the owner attributes partly to a more crowded market and partly to the company’s unprofitable merchandise division.

headline: Business Day Live: Sipping Less Sugar
abstract: Why states use cash meant for homeowners to plug budget gaps. | A look at Eduardo Saverin, Facebook’s co-founder. | How soft-drink makers cope with a decline in sales.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Touch-Ups at Teen Magazines, and Goldman’s Friendly Face
abstract: Also, The Daily branches out from the iPad, and the “Fox Mole” has a book contract.

headline: Celebrating Puerto Rican Day Parade, Daily News Unfurls Cuban Flag
abstract: In an ad for the parade, of which the newspaper is a sponsor, the Cuban flag flies over the head of Victor Cruz of the New York Giants.

headline: India, Spain and Singapore Win Awards in International Yoga Competition
abstract: Entrants from 24 countries competed in Los Angeles.

headline: Ryan Seacrest to Remain as Host of  ‘American Idol’
abstract: Ryan Seacrest has agreed to continue as the master of ceremonies on “Ametrican Idol,” earning $15 million a season.

headline: Hong Kong Regulator Defends Tougher I.P.O. Proposals
abstract: After a series of accounting failures and other scandals, Hong Kong’s top securities regulator on Tuesday defended new proposals that could subject bankers to civil or criminal prosecution over misleading statements in I.P.O. documents.

headline: New York Times Co. Lays Off 50 in Non-Newsroom Jobs
abstract: The layoffs came from human resources, legal, finance and other corporate departments, the company confirmed on Friday.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Silver Lake Takes Stake in William Morris Endeavor
abstract: The private equity firm Silver Lake has acquired a minority stake in the William Morris Endeavor Entertainment talent agency, the two announced on Wednesday, in a move to expand their presence in new media.

headline: Panel Finds U.S. and Europe Behind Schedule on Financial Rules
abstract: In a report to Group of 20 leaders, regulators and central bankers found that the United States, the European Union and Japan are behind schedule on measures that were adopted as part of an effort to avert future banking crises.

headline: In India, More Food and More Suffering
abstract: A new poll shows a rise in the percentage of Indians classified as “suffering” even as more food is available.

headline: As Facebook’s Stock Struggles, Fingers Start Pointing
abstract: Much of the blame for Facebook’s initial public offering debacle is landing on Morgan Stanley, the lead banker.

headline: Business Day Live: A Ballooning Megabyte Budget
abstract: Efforts to curb over-prescribed prescription drugs; Sam Grobart on how much data you use on your smartphone; and David Carr looks at the return of newspaper barons.

headline: Daily Report: Unanswered Questions About Google
abstract: An investigation into Google’s Street View project was left unresolved because the engineer in charge declined to talk, according to an interim report.

headline: Gene Sykes Named to Goldman’s Management Committee
abstract: Gene Sykes, who specializes in technology, media and telecommunications companies as well as health care firms, is one of Goldman’s best-known bankers.

headline: Wearable Computers Are the Next Big Devices, Report Says
abstract: The wearable computing wars are about to begin, a report released Tuesday by Forrester Research says, predicting that Apple, Google, Microsoft, Amazon and Facebook will help usher in the new era of computing.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Noisy Creativity, and Drunken Texts
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes electric guitar bodies made with a 3-D printer, an analysis of the prospects for Microsoft Surface and a stand-up desk that can be built inexpensively.

headline: How Big Data Gets Real
abstract: Big Data is moving up a classic modern curve, from discovery to science, and on to engineering and mass use. We are not as far along as a lot of people selling the boom would have you believe, but lots of good businesses are being built that will make a revolution.

headline: A Few Good Ideas for Products
abstract: David Pogue gets bombarded by product pitches. Here are 300-character versions of some of the more interesting ideas that he has seen recently.

headline: MF Global Hearing Addresses Recovery of Missing Client Money
abstract: Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, asked James W. Giddens pointed questions about efforts to recover missing money for MF Global customers.

headline: Barnes & Noble Argues Book Settlement ‘Punishes Consumers’
abstract: The bookseller also said Justice Department officials did not take the company’s objections seriously before the settlement, saying that they were only “checking the box.”

headline: Regulators Penalize JPMorgan Over Lehman Ties
abstract: More than three years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has penalized JPMorgan Chase for its ties to the bankrupt firm.

headline: App Smart Extra: Direct Your Dreams but Avoid Walruses
abstract: The app is designed to speak your chosen words when you’re in your R.E.M. sleep stage, and when, presumably, the noise won’t wake you.

headline: Apple Strikes Back at Government E-Book Lawsuit
abstract: The gist of Apple’s is the same as its previous comments on the case. The company denies that it conspired with book publishers to raise e-book prices in a bid to give Apple’s new iPad a boost and to thwart the low e-book pricing of Amazon. But Apple put its objections to the case in somewhat sharper terms in the new filing.

headline: Assessing a Case Against MF Global Executives
abstract: An analysis of the mismanagement of MF Global provides a damaging look at how the firm was pushed to collapse, but whether prosecutors have enough to pursue criminal charges is a different question.

headline: JPMorgan’s New Asia Chief Sees Growth Opportunities
abstract: In describing his impending move to Asia, JPMorgan Chase’s global head of investment banking says that his top mandate remains making the firm a top player across all regions of the globe.

headline: Once Shorting Subprime, Bass Now Bullish on Mortgage Bonds
abstract: Kyle Bass, a Texas hedge fund investor who profited from betting against the mortgage market, now thinks some of the worst bonds could yield 14 percent in the coming years.

headline: An MF Global Trustee Defends His Inquiry
abstract: Louis J. Freeh, the trustee, told a Senate committee he would not pay bonuses to MF Global executives.

headline: Pakistan Says It Test Fires Nuclear-Capable Missile
abstract: The launch of an intermediate range nuclear capable missile comes six days after India test-fired a long-range missile, Agni 5.

headline: Private Goldman Exchange Officially Closes for Business
abstract: With Thursday’s initial public offering of the Oaktree Capital Group, a once-promising private Goldman Sachs stock exchange has officially come to an end.

headline: Will Disney’s Swampy Gator Be the Next Angry Birds?
abstract: Disney is capitalizing on Swampy, the alligator from the popular Where’s My Water? game, introducing merchandise at Toys ‘R’ Us and featuring the character in a Web series.

headline: In Detroit, the Green Garage Is a Different Kind of Incubator
abstract: Tom Brennan would like to see a start-up culture that’s a rough analogue of the slow-food movement: intimate, deliberate and unhurried.

headline: Google Makes Push Into E-Commerce With New Online Store
abstract: Google made a push into e-commerce Tuesday with the introduction of a new online store, Google Play, through which it will start selling its Galaxy Nexus smartphone directly to consumers. This is not Google’s first direct-to-consumer play. Two years ago, the company tried, and failed, to sell its Nexus One phone direct to consumers online.

headline: Jewelry With a Glimmer of Rock Star
abstract: Jade Jagger held her first fine-jewelry trunk show in India.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Do You Expect Europe’s Problems to Affect Your Business?
abstract: A weaker Europe has meant a stronger dollar, making American products more expensive.

headline: The Shut-Up Gun
abstract: An interview with the inventor of a device that causes people to stop talking by repeating their speech back to them with a split-second delay — with a goal, among others, of conflict resolution.

headline: Share Your Family’s Titanic History
abstract: Did you have an ancestor on the Titanic? As the 100th anniversary of the disaster at sea approaches, we invite readers to share recollections of their own families whose lives were inextricably linked with the ship.

headline: Friday Reading: Does Facebook Make You a Narcissist?
abstract: Does Facebook make you a narcissist, tracking your smartphone data usage, revived by music and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Skydiving Glasses and Sympathy for a Twitter Bot
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a robot that mimics a human hand in rock, paper or scissors and the receding need for rebooting computersthat have crashed.

headline: Shapeways, Having Printed 1 Million Objects, Secures More Financing
abstract: Shapeways, a company that enables people to print 3-D objects, announced on Tuesday that it had completed a $6.2 million series B round of funding and had printed more than one million 3-D objects.

headline: Rice, a Private Equity Pioneer, to Step Down
abstract: Joseph L. Rice III plans to step down as chairman of Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, his firm announced in a letter to clients on Wednesday.

headline: Digital Notes: Liberty Media Keeps Sirius XM in Its Sights
abstract: Liberty Media lays out its plans, which include buying more stock and replacing the members of the board. Also, Megaupload asks a court to release more assets, and digital musical now represents more than half of recorded music sales in Britain.

headline: A Free Photo Lighting Lesson
abstract: Scott Kelby’s Lighting Recipes is an iPad app that contains 13 demonstrations on how to light photos, from studio glamour shots to outdoor sports portraits.

headline: How One Hospital Bent the Cost Curve
abstract: Many economists and specialists think that changes made by insurers, hospitals and doctors to emphasize the quality of care rather than the quantity of care is a factor in slowing health care costs, and Children’s Hospital Boston offers a good test case.

headline: Square Said to Seek $250 Million Investment
abstract: The investment would increase the company’s value to as much as $4 billion.

headline: Can Securitization Live With Volcker?
abstract: Some recent mortgage-backed securities deals by Credit Suisse show how Wall Street may adapt to a more regulated era.

headline: Revenue Drops at GE Capital
abstract: The unit, which had been a strong performer in recent quarters, reported on Friday that revenue was down 12 percent from the same period a year ago.

headline: What the Jobs Report Means for the Fed
abstract: The Federal Reserve is the only plausible source of significant government action to bolster the economy in the foreseeable future. Will it decide to take action?

headline: A Black Student Journalist Discovers in Turkey Her Color Is the Story
abstract: Tolu Taiwa, a University of Illinois student, found it far more challenging than her classmates to blend in, observe and report — in fact, she found it impossible.

headline: Going Social, but Not Creepy, in the New Bing
abstract: Microsoft rolled out a new version of its Bing search engine with new features aimed at weaving together the experience of Internet searching and social network sharing, but it omitted one eyebrow-raising new Bing feature that would share searches with friends on Facebook.

headline: Africa’s Second Female President Delivers
abstract: Joyce Banda’s early policy shifts bring foreign donors back to Malawi. Is she an example for Africa and will the money be enough?

headline: Investing With Your Heart, as Well as Your Head
abstract: Paul Sullivan begins a series of Wealth Matters columns on people who have followed their passions with their investments. This week: putting money into films.

headline: Ask About the Greek Elections
abstract: When Greeks return to the polls, the future of their participation in the euro — and perhaps the nature of the currency union itself — will hang in the balance. Niki Kitsantonis takes readers’ questions.

headline: After Article on ‘Kill List,’ Rumors Fly Fast
abstract: Last Tuesday, The Times published an article on President Obama’s counterterrorism record. That article was misconstrued by bloggers, and their errors were repeated in thousands of postings across the Internet.

headline: Scuttlebot Special Edition–Facebook I.P.O.
abstract: With Facebook’s initial public stock offering looming, the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times found an abundance of important and peculiar items about the company on the Web on Wednesday, including some early investors planning to sell larger stakes, the chances of meeting a new millionaire in the Bay Area and a comparison of Facebook with Google before its I.P.O.

headline: An Outpost of Afghan Dining Inside an American Military Base
abstract: At a United States military base in the eastern reaches of Afghanistan, one Afghan brings local flavor to American palates.

headline: Oaktree Prices I.P.O. at $43, at Bottom of Range
abstract: The Oaktree Capital Group priced at $43 a share, at the bottom of the expected range for the investment giant, as the underwriters also cut the size of the initial public offering.

headline: Moody’s Cuts Credit Ratings of 15 Big Banks
abstract: After putting banks on watch four months ago, Moody’s Investors Service on Thursday cut the credit ratings of 15 large financial firms, in a move that could do lasting damage to their bottom lines and weigh on the markets.

headline: Delhi Doctor Couple Denies Charges of Maid Abuse
abstract: Two Delhi doctors who allegedly left their 13-year old maid locked in their home during a vacation say the accusations are false.

headline: Daily Report: Old Money, New Tech
abstract: Fresh from college and graduate schools, the children of some prominent dynasties are taking a different career path, spurning their legacies in retailing, real estate and finance for a future in technology, reports Evelyn M. Rusli in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: Verizon Unveils Wireless Plans That Cover Several Devices
abstract: Verizon said its shared plans would become available to customers this month. The new plans will allow customers to pay monthly fees to share data, voice minutes and text messages across multiple devices, like smartphones, tablets and notebooks.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Facebook’s Billions, and Political Blowback for a Billionaire
abstract: Also, Bono is about to become the world’s richest musician (thank you, Facebook), and it’s not too early to book TV ad time for the fall political campaign season.

headline: Evangelist for Al Qaeda Said to Be Killed
abstract: In the world of violent global jihad, Abu Yahya al-Libi, who U.S. officials say was killed in a drone strike Monday, was an evangelist, a philosopher and a social media rock star. He was even mentioned as a candidate to lead Al Qaeda.

headline: JPMorgan Appoints Senior Investment Banker
abstract: Joseph A. Walker will become a senior vice chairman of investment banking at JPMorgan, according to an internal e-mail obtained by DealBook.

headline: Facebook Says, Lower Your Expectations About Mobile
abstract: Facebook amended its public offering prospectus on Wednesday to note that it is showing fewer ads per user on the site because of its lack of vibrant mobile applications.

headline: Obama’s Ad Campaign Targets Indian Call Centers
abstract: A $25 million advertising blitz connects presidential rival Mitt Romney with outsourcing jobs to India.

headline: Taylor Gone, but Blood Diamonds Are Forever
abstract: Charles Taylor’s lust for diamonds fueled a bloody conflict in which thousands were killed or mutilated. As he awaits sentencing in The Hague, activists say the campaign against conflict diamonds continues.

headline: Why European Bank Buffers May Not Be Quite What They Seem
abstract: A close look at Credit Suisse’s capital illustrates the pitfalls of assuming that Europe’s banks are girded against the continuing debt crisis.

headline: India’s Tax Plan Troubles Foreign Investors
abstract: India would lose significant ground as a destination for international investment, if the new tax regime is implemented.

headline: Friday Reading: Facebook Complicates Family Estrangements
abstract: Facebook can complicate family estrangements, job forecast steady but stay tuned, government expands inquiry into Jeep Grand Cherokee fire risk and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: No Fanfare for China’s Female Astronauts
abstract: Nearly half a century after the Soviet Union sent the first woman into space, China appears ready to send its first female astronaut aloft. But the Chinese space program, rarely one to miss a chance at some good publicity, isn’t talking about its women fliers.

headline: CBS, Already Strong on Comedy, Will Add Three Dramas in Fall
abstract: The most-watched American television network is also moving one of its benchmark Monday night comedies, “Two and a Half Men,” to Thursday night.

headline: Final Installment of ‘Hatfields & McCoys’ Draws Biggest Audience
abstract: The miniseries about the legendary family feud reached a new audience high of 14.3 million viewers on Wednesday night. The totals for all three nights were enough to make the shows among the most-viewed entertainment programs ever on cable TV.

headline: After Long Resistance, Pynchon Allows Novels to Be Sold as E-Books
abstract: Thomas Pynchon, author of “Gravity’s Rainbow” and “The Crying of Lot 49,” characteristically declined to speak about his decision. But Ann Godoff, the editor in chief of Penguin Press, explained his motivation: “I think he wants to have more readers.”

headline: After Delay and Debate, Regulators Support New Rule
abstract: Regulators agreed to support a draft proposal to regulate overseas derivatives trading, a move that comes just days after internal wrangling delayed the plan and prompted several last-minute changes.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Bin Laden’s Death Made U.S. Safe, Panetta Says, Recalling ‘Nail-Biting Moments’ of Raid
abstract: In comments ahead of the first anniversary of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said on Friday that the death had weakened Al Qaeda and made the United States safer.

headline: Apple’s Maps Don’t Look So Bad
abstract: Side-by-side comparisons of Apple’s mobile map and Google maps have been moving around the Internet, and Apple’s map looks terribly light on information by contrast. That is not the final product, though. Apple skinned data off the maps it showed developers. The question is, why?

headline: Facebook to Buy Photo-Sharing Service Instagram for $1 Billion
abstract: Facebook, the world’s largest social network, has agreed to buy Instagram, the popular mobile-centric photo-sharing network. Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, announced the acquisition on his Facebook page.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Regulators Adopt New Tools to Prevent Another Flash Crash
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted measures that would enforce marketwide circuit breakers and prevent erroneous trades from entering the system.

headline: Cuba May Be the Most Feminist Country in Latin America
abstract: Cuba, although poorer, has a better record on women’s status and advancement than the economic behemoth of Brazil, not to mention the rest of Latin America. But will the economic liberalization on the island reverse women’s progress there?

headline: Tech World Double Standard for Women Entrepreneurs?
abstract: Perhaps it’s not surprising in the estrogen-challenged tech world, but Hannah Seligson reports that pregnant entrepreneurs cannot get financing, even while ensuring the continuity of markets…er, the species.

headline: The Real Reasons Why You Buy
abstract: If you think a purchase will ultimately save you money, ask yourself whether that’s a story you’ve invented to justify something you’re buying for more emotional reasons.

headline: From ‘Incredible India’ to the ‘Incredible Tiffin’
abstract: Showcasing India through the country’s varied cuisine.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: E-Book Covers and Digital Resurrection
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selection includes trying to come up with a digital analog to the book cover, Google notifiying more than 20,000 Web sites that they may have been hacked and Google’s challenge to Dropbox.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Finnish Broadband, and Buying Facebook
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes a report criticizing venture capital investing, an academic study of the popularity of LOLCats and a reported sighting of a prototype for Apple’s HDTV.

headline: Round-Trip Tickets for Chen Could Upgrade U.S.-China Relations
abstract: The China scholar Orville Schell suggests that Beijing might do well to offer assurances to the human rights lawyer Chen Guangcheng that he and his family will be able to return home after he goes abroad for legal studies. Such a gesture would be welcomed by Washington and a possible boon to U.S.-China relations.

headline: Disney to Team With Chinese Company to Make ‘Iron Man 3’
abstract: Disney-owned Marvel Studios will become partners with DMG Entertainment on the film, which is set to be released next year. Bringing in a partner on such a successful franchise is considered unusual.

headline: Google Plus Gets a Makeover
abstract: Google introduced a new design to Google Plus, its social network, on Wednesday. The new design is clean and smooth, with soft gray tones that flow into a central stream of updates from users. The company, however, did not apply the design changes to its mobile experience despite the growing importance of mobile devices for social networking.

headline: Q&A: Scanners on the Small Side
abstract: Why are business-card scanners more than $100 while you can find larger photo and paper scanners for much less?

headline: Immigrants Say ‘Non’ to Sarkozy
abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy’s bid for National Front votes may backfire. But the rise of the far right will be one legacy of the 2012 French presidential election.

headline: The Right Way to Try to Buy Happiness
abstract: By using money to create memories with your family, build things with your hands or even sleep more, you stand a pretty good chance of being happier.

headline: Facebook Shares Falter as Analysts Split Their Verdicts
abstract: Shares of Facebook tumbled as much as 3 percent on Wednesday after the first big wave of analyst reports on the social network arrived, with largely mixed feelings about the stock.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Business Day Live: Amazon’s Robots
abstract: JPMorgan faces penalties over Lehman’s collapse; a look at Amazon’s robots, with Nick Bilton; and Eduardo Porter on promising growth in the manufacturing sector.

headline: Comcast Is Said to Be Mulling Bid for BSkyB
abstract: News Corporation wanted to own the British satellite broadcaster outright but its stake has been threatened by the phone-hacking scandal at one of its newspapers.

headline: Image of the Day: June 11
abstract: The 18th chief election commissioner of India took office on Monday.

headline: Female Sergeant Major Claims Gender Discrimination
abstract: A retired command sergeant major has come forward to say that she was the victim of gender discrimination by her superiors while she was commandant of the 3rd Infantry Division.

headline: L.A. Law and the Fake Picasso
abstract: A dispute over a fake Picasso brings a courtroom appearance — via video — by Ryan Kavanaugh, the head of Relativity Media.

headline: Fox News Is Said to Have a Mole
abstract: The news and gossip Web site Gawker posted a column on Tuesday from a person who it says is a “longstanding, current employee of Fox News Channel.” In the past, Fox News has tried hard to plug any leaks.

headline: A Deal on Lease Accounting
abstract: Many corporate balance sheets are about to grow much larger, even if nothing has really changed.

headline: Rothschilds to Combine French and British Assets
abstract: The Rothschild family will consolidate its French and British operations in a move to increase capital reserves and operational efficiency while maintaining control of a financial institution that dates back to the 18th century.

headline: Apps I Want to Go Away
abstract: Apple’s iOS comes with more than two dozen apps that cannot be deleted. Some apps, like Mail, are essential, but why are some nonessential apps so immovable?

headline: Should I Stay or Should I Go?
abstract: There will always be those moments when you are torn between your responsibilities at home and at work. If you find yourself struggling with these decisions too often, it may be a sign of bigger problems with your business.

headline: Weighing the Legal Ramifications of the Wal-Mart Bribery Case
abstract: Indications that Wal-Mart Stores may have taken steps to keep an internal investigation from digging deeper into $24 million in questionable payments may affect how the government decides to proceed against the giant retailer.

headline: Nepal, on the Brink of Collapse
abstract: Nepal’s inability to write a constitution could turn it into a failed state.

headline: Image of the Day: April 18
abstract: Students in Uttar Pradesh celebrate World Heritage Day.

headline: Wiretaps Remain Crucial Evidence
abstract: Prosecutors may be able to get wiretaps admitted in their case against Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, because the rules of evidence allow the statements of one conspirator to be used against another.

headline: Image of the Day: June 1
abstract: A railway worker repairs a damaged track at the site of the wreckage of a passenger train in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Angry Birds Maker Posted Revenue of $106.3 Million in 2011
abstract: Rovio Entertainment earned $67.6 million last year, capitalizing on the strong growth of its Angry Birds franchise.

headline: Wall Street Examines Fine Print in a Bill for Start-Ups
abstract: The JOBS Act would roll back some major securities regulations.

headline: Debating the Right Way to Change a Domain Name — and Brand a Nut Retailer
abstract: The owner of the Newark Nut Company talks about what he might have done differently.

headline: ‘London Whale’ Said to Be Leaving JPMorgan
abstract: Bruno Iksil, the so-called London whale at the center of the trading debacle, is expected to depart the bank, according to current and former colleagues.

headline: Image of the Day: June 15
abstract: Anchored fishing boats at a seashore in a village in Maharashtra.

headline: Popchips Pulls Ashton Kutcher Ad Over Charges of Racism
abstract: Part of an advertising campaign for Popchips snacks featuring Ashton Kutcher has been withdrawn amid complaints that Mr. Kutcher’s performance as an Indian named Raj was racist.

headline: Fairness Can Pay Economic Dividends
abstract: With two big elections coming up in France and the United States, much attention is being paid to questions of economic fairness. The latest research suggests it should be.

headline: Daily Report: Considering the Spectrum ‘Crisis’
abstract: Wireless carriers say they need more spectrum to accommodate our growing hunger for mobile data, but some scientists and engineers question say the so-called spectrum shortage is really just a way for the companies to protect themselves from competitors, reports Brian X. Chen on Wednesday in The New York Times.

headline: Unemployment, Beyond the Rate
abstract: By a broad measure of unemployment, including discouraged and underemployed workers, 23 million Americans are looking for jobs.

headline: The Times Is Introducing a Chinese-Language News Site
abstract: The site, cn.nytimes.com, will feature 30 articles a day, the bulk of them translated from Times articles, but it also will feature original content from China.

headline: Twitter Implements Do Not Track Privacy Option
abstract: In stark comparison to Facebook, Twitter said Thursday that it will begin implementing the Mozilla Do Not Track feature in the Firefox Web browser that allows users to opt-out of cookies that collect personal information and any third-party cookies, including those used for advertising.

headline: Video: Hulu’s Evolution
abstract: Online television site Hulu is coming of age. Amy Chozick, of The New York Times, explains how and why.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Instagram’s Direction, and Amazon on Tumblr
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes adjusting to Facebook’s acquisition of Instagram, exporting your photos from Instagram, and how Amazon marketed itself on Tumblr.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Goldman Executives Reappear on Real Estate Scene
abstract: A number of former Goldman Sachs executives who worked at the firm’s real estate investment arm Whitehall have found second acts in private equity.

headline: Apple Steps Further Into the Business Market
abstract: Apple’s new releases are usually sold for their effect on consumers and educators. With iPhones and iPads increasingly making their way into offices, however, and cloud computing blurring the line between work and home, Apple is becoming an enterprise device company, too. Some of the new features show how.

headline: Parsing a Fed Official’s Speech
abstract: Janet L. Yellen indicates that even if growth accelerates well beyond the Fed’s expectations, it would make sense to maintain the central bank’s current policies for several years.

headline: Prismatic Hopes to Create a New Category of Social News
abstract: Prismatic, a new social news discovery site, helps people find news topics on Twitter that they might normally not be able to find. An artificial intelligence program combs through the content being shared on social media.

headline: ‘Comfort Women’ Controversy Comes to New York
abstract: A New York City councilman and his colleagues have been inundated with letters from angry Japanese after proposing a monument and a street to memorialize the plight of Asian women forced into prostitution by Japan.

headline: Microsoft and Facebook Align Further With Patent Deal
abstract: Less than two weeks after Microsoft paid AOL more than $1 billion for a trove of its patents, Microsoft is selling or licensing those same patents to its online ally, Facebook, for $550 million.

headline: An Institutional Flaw at the Heart of the Federal Reserve
abstract: The selection and duties of board members of the Fed’s regional banks leave too much room for the appearance, if not reality, of conflicts of interest, an economist writes.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Publishers Blame Amazon, and a ‘Mental Mincemeat’ Maker
abstract: Also, more questions in Britain over News Corporation’s bid to own BSkyB, and a first-edition copy of “The Book of Mormon” has been stolen.

headline: Germany and China: Too Close for Some
abstract: Germany and China are building a ‘special relationship’ that risks undermining Europe’s overall position with the rising Asian giant.
