headline: The Probability of a Private Equity Play for Best Buy
abstract: With Best Buy’s chief executive, Brian Dunn, unexpectedly stepping down, an analyst suggested that the ailing retailer could be ripe for a buyout, but a deal could present some challenges for private equity.

headline: Problems With Online Bill Paying at Big Banks
abstract: Customers of at least two big banks reported problems with online bill payment services this week.

headline: Data Scientists Get Ranked
abstract: Kaggle, which attracts thousands of statisticians in predictive pattern-finding contests, has started a ranking system that rates top performers. They come from around the globe, are notably brainy, and tend to see one subject area pretty much like another. Whether it’s traffic or black holes, it’s all information. Also: some of them pay for their e-mail.

headline: Using a Mobile Phone to Curb Domestic Violence
abstract: Women’s lives are improved in unexpected ways by mobile phones.

headline: Glaxo Amends Its $2.59 Billion Bid for Human Genome Sciences
abstract: The British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline has changed the terms of its proposed takeover offer for Human Genome Sciences in response to the poison pill adopted by the biotechnology company.

headline: Daily Report: Nokia Cuts 10,000 Jobs
abstract: Nokia will slash 19 percent of its work force by the end of 2013 as part of an emergency overhaul that includes closing research centers and a factory in Germany, Canada and Finland, and the departures of three senior executives.

headline: Audi Agrees to Buy Ducati
abstract: Audi, the luxury car unit of Volkswagen, said Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire Italian motorcycle maker Ducati, gaining a foothold in a growing market as well as expertise in building small, high-powered motors.

headline: Q&A: “Unplaying” an iTunes Podcast
abstract: How to reset a podcast’s status so that iTunes properly syncs it to an iPod as an unplayed episode.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Some Libraries Forgo Popular Erotic Novels
abstract: Some libraries forgo “Fifty Shades of Grey” series, public money is funneled to private schools, why you should wait after eating before brushing your teeth and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Google’s Washington Night
abstract: A few media executives, still smarting over the role Google played in defeating antipiracy legislation this year, see its presence at the White House Correspondents’ Association annual dinner as a victory lap.

headline: Marubeni of Japan to Buy Gavilon for $3.6 Billion
abstract: The Japanese trading house has agreed to buy the grain merchant Gavilon Group for $3.6 billion, as Marubeni looks to gain access to American agriculture markets.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google Translation and a Robot Weaver
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selection includes fostering innovation through comfort and lack of conflict, the quantity of translations by Google and a lab at M.I.T. training a robot to weave weblike architecture.

headline: Republican Lawmaker Questions Uproar Over JPMorgan Loss
abstract: Representative Spencer Bachus of Alabama played down the event’s significance for Wall Street and the broader economy, arguing that the loss will barely dent JPMorgan’s bottom line.

headline: How to Help Aparna and Girls Like Her
abstract: Several readers have offered to help the 16-year-old daughter of a sex worker, who aspires to be a doctor.

headline: The Declining Role of Start-Ups
abstract: Business leaders and politicians often laud the United States for its entrepreneurial culture, but start-up activity has been falling since the 1980s, a new report shows.

headline: Turner Broadcasting Invests in Funny or Die
abstract: The deal with the producer of online comedy videos includes collaboration with two Turner brands, TBS and Adult Swim, on both content and advertising sales.

headline: The Risks of Restaurant Investing
abstract: Investing in a restaurant, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column, can be a risky undertaking. But the most successful investors always keep a focus on the numbers.

headline: At Milken Conference, Status Counts
abstract: An entire constellation of events are reserved for only the most powerful attendees of the Milken Institute Global Conference.

headline: Fandango Adds MSN to Its Ticket-Sales Portals
abstract: In the coming months Fandango will focus more on improving its nonticketing offerings, including better use of content from its corporate sibling, Universal Pictures.

headline: What 23 Years of E-Mail May Say About You
abstract: Researchers using themselves as guinea pigs have analyzed huge amounts of their personal data, seeking meaningful and useful patterns.

headline: Cambodia Ambiguous on Plans for French Architect
abstract: Cambodia’s Foreign Ministry said Friday it had no plans to extradite Patrick Devillers, a French architect with links to the disgraced Chinese politician Bo Xilai and his wife.

headline: A ‘Real’ Video Helps Fight Against Premature Births
abstract: The March of Dimes uses a YouTube video to help illuminate its campaign to prevent preterm births.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: Mary Cadwallader joined the Washington office of TPM Media, the publisher of Talking Points Memo, as vice president for advertising sales.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

headline: Japan Reactor Building Is Tilting but Not a Risk, Operator Says
abstract: A heavily damaged reactor building at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has a slight tilt, but the tilt does not pose a risk to the integrity of the building, according to the plant’s operator.

headline: Assad Supporters Suspected in New Beirut Incidents
abstract: Gunmen threw up roadblocks early Tuesday morning manned by young men who were apparently supporters of President Bashar al-Assad’s regime in Syria.

headline: A Village Embraces Its Haunted Legacy
abstract: Dozens of descendants of the Titanic passengers are seizing their Titanic history as an economic lifeline that might help hold on to the younger generation.

headline: Chinese Media Fight Scandal Fallout; Focus on Bo’s Family
abstract: China intensified a propaganda campaign to paper over a split in the Communist Party as hints emerged of the wealth amassed by relatives of Bo Xilai, a deposed official.

headline: British Hacking Scandal Suits to Be Filed in U.S.
abstract: Mark Lewis, a British lawyer, said he planned to sue in the United States on behalf of victims who allege they were the subject of phone hacking by Rupert Murdoch’s British tabloids.

headline: In Speech, Obama Says U.S. Will Stand by Afghans After Troop Withdrawal
abstract: Speaking near Kabul after a surprise night visit to Afghanistan on the anniversary of Osama bin Laden’s death, President Obama said that “we have a clear path to fulfill our mission in Afghanistan.”

headline: Wreckage of Russian Aircraft Found in Indonesia
abstract: The wreckage of a Russian-made Sukhoi Superjet 100 was found on Thursday on the side of a mountain volcano shrouded in mist.

headline: Putin Sees Worsening Conflict in Syria but Rejects Outside Intervention
abstract: Vladimir V. Putin has emerged as the fulcrum in efforts by Western nations and Arab foes to force President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to step down.

headline: Italy Tries to Fathom Roster of Damage
abstract: For nearly two weeks now, on-site teams have been charting the extent of the damage to historic buildings caused by two strong earthquakes in the Emilia-Romagna region on a disaster map that continues to grow.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: Adam & Eve, London, an independent agency opened in 2008, was acquired by DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, which will merge the agency with DDB United Kingdom, London.

headline: Pakistani Court Bars Interior Minister Over Dual-Nationality Claim
abstract: Rehman Malik, a close aide of the president, said that he had surrendered his British nationality, but that he could not provide the necessary proof on Monday.

headline: Ads Seek to Light a Match Under Would-Be Volunteers
abstract: A new campaign seeks recruits for New York State’s volunteer fire departments.

headline: Canada: Suspect Arrested in Mall Shooting
abstract: The Toronto police on Monday arrested and charged a man with first-degree murder and six counts of attempted murder in connection with a shooting in a downtown Toronto shopping mall.

headline: Burmese Democracy Leader Set for Triumphant Return to Europe
abstract: The activist, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, will be welcomed in European capitals with the pomp and circumstance normally reserved for a visiting head of state.

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Earnings Slip
abstract: Revenue was affected by lower foreign-exchange trading and the sale of the shareholder services unit.

headline: Yum’s Profit Jumps 73%, Helped by Taco Bell Sales
abstract: The company’s net income rose to $458 million, and revenue rose 13 percent, to $2.74 billion, in the first quarter.

headline: Qualcomm Beats Forecast, but Strains to Get Chips
abstract: The chip maker says it needs to spend more to meet demand for smartphones.

headline: Rising Demand in U.S. Helps 3M Beat Earnings Estimates
abstract: Earnings per share were $1.59, above analysts’ prediction of $1.49, as industrial demand in the United States helped offset slowing foreign markets.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

headline: A Europe Tired of Cutbacks Has Few Alternatives
abstract: Budget-cutting pain is fueling support for far-left and nationalist parties, but many European leaders simply cannot afford to spend more.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: The 2012 B2B Ace Awards, sponsored by the Business Marketing Association of New York, were presented earlier this month.

headline: Japan Seeks to Restart Some Nuclear Power Plants
abstract: Safety concerns after the disaster at Fukushima Daiichi last year have led to a gradual shutdown of nearly all Japan’s nuclear reactors, prompting fears of power shortages.

headline: Amid Proxy Fight, Canadian Pacific Profit Rises
abstract: The Canadian Pacific Railway reported Friday that it had a first-quarter profit of 142 million Canadian dollars, a 318 percent increase from the same period a year before.

headline: Broadcaster Distances Itself From News Corp.
abstract: A day after a British parliamentary panel castigated Rupert Murdoch, BSkyB insisted on Wednesday that it was a “fit and proper” company to hold a broadcasting license.

headline: Syrian Arrests Are Said to Have Snared Tens of Thousands
abstract: An unrelenting campaign of arrests by the Syrian government since the start of the uprising has focused on two groups: men and boys from besieged towns, and secular activists.

headline: Deadly Day for Afghan Police
abstract: Ten police officers were killed in ambushes and explosions in Afghanistan, mostly in the country’s south and west.

headline: Russia: Downed Jet was Backup Model
abstract: The Russian passenger airliner that crashed during a demonstration flight in Indonesia last week was a backup the manufacturer had sent to complete a promotional tour though Asia after the first airplane broke down.

headline: Iran: Advocacy Groups Join in Drive to Tighten Sanctions

abstract: Domestic stocks, though stumbling, still benefit from investors’ belief that the American economy has been more resilient than others.

abstract: Spain and Cyprus may be the current locus of European anxiety, but many other banks are in a weakened state, cut off from money markets because investors do not trust them.

abstract: In a signed deal, Israeli authorities agreed to provisions like returning those in solitary confinement to the general prison population.

abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: U.N. Report Says Rwandans Recruited to Fight in Congo
abstract: The report says that Rwandan authorities have been seemingly complicit in recruiting soldiers for a Congolese rebel leader.

headline: Dutch Austerity Talks Fail as Geithner Prods Europe
abstract: The Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, said he expected new elections, and the United States Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, urged European leaders to be aggressive.

abstract: The Chinese authorities said they had detained 23 suspects in Shanghai and seized more than 100 guns and gun parts.

abstract: Measuring what huge financial institutions do is difficult, but their being oversize seems to add little to society.

abstract: As American and Chinese officials convene talks, Treasury officials are vowing to press China to make its currency and financial systems more responsive to market forces.

headline: Reporter in Azerbaijan Beaten After Filming Dispute

abstract: The Pirate Party has built its success on little more than a vague platform of greater openness in government, using technology.

abstract: The new charges against Gamal and Alaa Mubarak come days before they are expected to hear a verdict in an earlier corruption trial.

abstract: A 144-page indictment package prepared by a Turkish prosecutor could further strain Turkey-Israel relations.

abstract: The entertainment entrepreneur Peter Chernin has made an arrangement with investors, who are taking a stake in the future earnings of his films and television shows and channeling him the money now.

abstract: Chen Guangfu, the older brother of Chen Guangcheng, is back in the family’s home village after evading guards there to travel to Beijing to meet with a lawyer, an American legal scholar who is advising Mr. Chen said Sunday.

abstract: Bank of America and Citigroup have plenty in common, and when bank earnings are revealed in the coming weeks, investors will be watching to see how the two match up.

abstract: Professor Greenewalt, an archaeologist, transformed scholars’ understanding of Sardis, now western Turkey.

abstract: For novice investors in racehorses, buying into a syndicate with several horses is a good way to learn an unpredictable business without huge financial losses.

abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: China: Tycoon Gets Reprieve
abstract: A self-made tycoon sentenced to death for financial fraud has been resentenced to death with a two-year reprieve, meaning her sentence will probably be changed to life after two years of good behavior.

headline: French Face a Battle to Control Parliament
abstract: The fate of François Hollande’s young presidency rests largely on legislative elections that begin Sunday, as he seeks a large majority and the right tries to deny him one.

headline: Marina Keegan, Journalist and Playwright, Dies at 22
abstract: Ms. Keegan, a Yale graduate, encouraged students to resist careers in finance.

headline: Suspected Sale by China Stirs Concern at White House
abstract: The Obama administration says it believes that a Chinese manufacturer sold North Korea the chassis and other parts for a missile-transport vehicle, a senior official said.

headline: Pakistan Court Orders Arrest of Presidential Ally in a Drug Inquiry
abstract: The arrest warrant effectively blocked a bid by a close ally of President Asif Ali Zardari to be the next prime minister.

headline: Technology Reaches Remote Tibetan Corners, Fanning Unrest
abstract: The technology revolution has transformed ordinary life and helped raise a political consciousness that has found expression through a campaign of self-immolations.

headline: ‘Princelings’ in China Use Family Ties to Gain Riches
abstract: The authorities are eager to paint the fallen official Bo Xilai, whose family has a substantial fortune, as a rogue operator. But other officials’ relatives have also amassed vast wealth.

headline: Drug Helps Defense System Fight Cancer
abstract: An experimental drug shows promise in harnessing the immune system to fight cancer, but it is not clear whether the drug will actually help people live longer.

headline: Chicken Scratches vs. Electronic Prescriptions
abstract: Studies show that errors are much less likely when doctors send prescriptions to the pharmacy via computer. But the move to such e-prescriptions has been relatively slow.

headline: From Dot-Com to Dot-Co
abstract: The chief executive of .CO Internet SAS, an Internet domain company, describes his journey from selling sandwiches in Colombia to leading tech businesses.

headline: For Oreo, Cadbury and Ritz, a New Parent Company
abstract: Mondelez International, whose meaning is a combination of “world” and “delicious” in several romance languages, will adorn packages only in small print.

headline: Russia Arrests 5 in Inquiry on Protest
abstract: Russian authorities are examining clashes between protesters and riot police at a demonstration on May 6, the day before Vladimir V. Putin’s inauguration for a third term as president.

headline: China Buys Inroads in the Caribbean, Catching U.S. Notice
abstract: China’s economic might has rolled up to America’s doorstep, with loans from state banks, investments by companies and outright gifts from the government.

headline: Three Months in Customer Service Limbo
abstract: A reader has been trying to have his Hewlett-Packard Envy laptop repaired for more than three months, and has yet to see results.

headline: Bankers Call for Wider Measures to Stem Crisis
abstract: An organization that serves as an umbrella for the world’s largest central banks warned that they could not cope with the euro zone crisis alone.

headline: Israel Moves to Block Activists From Entering
abstract: In a replay of an attempt by pro-Palestinian activists to reach Bethlehem last July, most appeared to have been stopped before they boarded flights to Israel.

headline: Bank of America Accord in Lawsuit Is Challenged
abstract: Lawyers have agreed to settle a lawsuit against the company’s directors over its purchase of Merrill Lynch for $20 million, even though damages could reach $5 billion, according to plaintiffs of a parallel suit in Delaware.

headline: Tough Questions for Cameron on Ties to Murdoch
abstract: The widening scandal involving Murdoch media interests is seen as having potentially serious political repercussions for the Cameron government.

headline: Energy Dept. to Revitalize a Loan Guarantee Program
abstract: Six months after the expiration of a program that backed $16 billion in loans, the Energy Department is subsidizing an existing loan guarantee program to encourage more applications.

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Cut 30,000 Jobs
abstract: The tech giant will refocus on product development and sales, executives say, and operations in China will most likely be spared.

headline: French Data Regulator Chides Google
abstract: After a meeting with Google executives on Wednesday, the regulator said the company’s answers to a questionnaire about the new policy had not addressed many of its concerns.

headline: Deadly Bombing Strikes Police Bus in Pakistan
abstract: An explosion killed at least 19 people and wounded dozens in the deadliest attack in Peshawar in months.

headline: As a Defendant Bullies and Boasts, Questions Arise on a Court’s Limits
abstract: The case of Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian politician, has ignited a debate on whether the rules should be changed to rein in high-profile defendants in international tribunals.

headline: Death of Rape Victim in Morocco Sparks Calls for Legal Reform
abstract: Amina Filali, 16, committed suicide after being forced to marry her rapist to protect him from prosecution, under a law designed to safeguard female, and family, honor.

headline: South Korea Postpones Military Pact With Japan
abstract: Faced with mounting political pressure, the South Korean government abruptly delayed the signing of its first military cooperation pact with Japan since World War II.

headline: New Worries About Women’s Rights and Ethnic Tensions Emerge in Afghanistan
abstract: An official’s comments on women’s shelters and a new national almanac’s estimates on Afghanistan’s ethnic breakdown have stirred tensions.

headline: Russia: Ukraine Rejects a Putin Offer
abstract: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday said Ukraine’s former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, was welcome to receive medical treatment in Russia.

headline: Japanese Shareholders Starting to Show Their Teeth
abstract: An emerging breed of individual Japanese investors is starting to break from the traditionally docile ranks of shareholders and hold company managers accountable on a range of issues.

headline: Fearing Harm to Myanmar Ties, Thailand Limits Visiting Opposition Leader
abstract: The Thai government tried to subdue the weekend visit of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, curtailing her activities amid a fragile relationship with the Myanmar government.

headline: Argentina to Seize Control of Oil Company
abstract: The expropriation would reassert state control over a pillar of Argentina’s economy but also increase diplomatic tensions with Spain and the European Union.

headline: At JPMorgan, the Ghost of Dinner Parties Past
abstract: The $2 billion trading loss disclosed last week by JPMorgan Chase shows how the tables have turned on the bank and its chief executive, an industry point man against tighter regulation.

headline: In Struggling Spanish Town, Hopes of Reopening Mine Are Delayed
abstract: A plan to reopen a mine in Spain has been stalled, angering local residents in need of jobs while leaving environmentalists worried that economic priorities will trump safety concerns.

headline: Tomás Borge Martínez, Sandinista Rebel and Nicaragua Interior Minister, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Borge, the last surviving founder of the Sandinista rebel group that toppled Nicaragua’s dictatorship in 1979, went from student radical to one of the leading officials of his nation’s government.

headline: Europe Preparing to File Charges in Universal-E.M.I. Deal
abstract: The $1.9 billion deal would give Universal Music Group 40 percent of the recorded music market, which regulators say could alter the industry’s landscape.

headline: U.N. Team In Syria Is Imperiled, Leader Says
abstract: Maj. Gen. Robert Mood said Friday that “violence over the past 10 days has been intensifying willingly by both parties, with losses on both sides and significant risks to our observers.”

headline: Auto Sales Rose in May, Continuing a Bright Trend
abstract: Chrysler reported a 30 percent gain in new-vehicle sales for May, Ford said its sales climbed 13 percent and General Motors reported an 11 percent increase.

headline: A Race Recast by YouTube and Twitter
abstract: A law passed in 2007 that was intended to keep campaigning orderly and clean has been undercut by the unpredictable and uncontrollable Web.

headline: Named Egypt’s Winner, Islamist Makes History
abstract: Mohamed Morsi’s recognition as president handed the Muslim Brotherhood a new weapon in its struggle for power with Egypt’s ruling military council.

headline: Facing Popular Competitors, Twitpic Releases Free iPhone App
abstract: TwitPic, the photo sharing service for people who use Twitter, announced Monday that it had released its first application for the iPhone.

headline: Kidnapped American Makes Appeal to Obama in Qaeda Video
abstract: The hostage, Warren Weinstein, a 70-year-old development consultant, was shown making an emotional appeal to President Obama to negotiate for his release.

headline: Senate’s Vote Ousts Leader of Paraguay After a Clash
abstract: The vote to remove President Fernando Lugo from office, after a deadly clash between squatters and the police, plunged the country into a political crisis.

headline: Italy Surveys Damage Amid Dozens of Aftershocks
abstract: Officials said damage from Sunday’s earthquake in the Emilia-Romagna region would be significant financially and culturally.

headline: Vatican Inquiry Reflects Wider Focus on Legion of Christ
abstract: The investigation into alleged sexual abuse of minors casts a new shadow upon a powerful but troubled worldwide religious order, whose late founder became enmeshed in a similar sex scandal years ago.

headline: Miguel de la Madrid, President of Mexico in 1980s, Dies at 77
abstract: His tenure marred by economic crisis and an earthquake, Mr. de la Madrid is credited for setting Mexico on a path to a free-market economy and, inadvertently, multiparty rule.

headline: The Calming Effect of Central Banks
abstract: Despite recent news from Europe that could have shaken investors, the markets have remained relatively steady.

headline: Syrian Forces Shell Cities as Opposition Picks Leader
abstract: Government forces attacked rebel strongholds across the country while the main opposition group in exile, the Syrian National Council, chose a new Kurdish leader.

headline: For China, a Dissident in Exile Is One Less Headache Back Home
abstract: Once exiled, nettlesome prisoners of conscience, like Chen Guangcheng, almost invariably lose their ability to grab headlines in the West and to command widespread sympathy both in China and abroad.

headline: At Network TV’s Gathering, Web Is Central
abstract: At last week’s upfront presentations, network television executives spoke the languages of social media and Web science to a greater degree than ever.

headline: I.B.M. Aims to Sharply Simplify Corporate Data Center Technology
abstract: I.B.M. is introducing bundles of server hardware and software packaged in simplified systems, with setup and maintenance automated by intelligent software.

headline: Selling America Abroad
abstract: The United States’ share of the total travel market is down, to 11.2 percent in 2010 from 17.3 percent in 2000, and a marketing group is pushing to change that.

headline: In Vast Jungle, U.S. Troops Aid in Search for Kony
abstract: A hundred of America’s elite Special Operations troops are helping African forces find a wig-wearing, gibberish-speaking rebel commander named Joseph Kony.

headline: Britain Celebrates Queen’s 60-Year Reign
abstract: A flotilla of 1,000 boats in celebration of Queen Elizabeth II’s diamond jubilee set off down the Thames on Sunday in an extravagant royal pageant of a kind last seen 350 years ago.

headline: Syria Talks Won’t Include the Saudis or Iranians
abstract: Iran, the strongest regional ally of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, and Saudi Arabia, a prominent supporter of Mr. Assad’s enemies, will be absent from a meeting in Geneva on Saturday to revive a paralyzed peace plan for Syria.

headline: Rocket From Sinai Lands in Israel
abstract: At least one rocket fired from the Egyptian Sinai peninsula struck Israel’s southern resort city of Eilat Thursday, causing alarm but no injuries,

headline: Fierce Clashes Erupt in Egypt Ahead of Presidential Vote
abstract: Violence killed at least 11 people and threw the race into disarray as some candidates blamed the military for the deaths and said they were halting their campaigns.

headline: Libya Postpones National Election Until July, as Preparations Lag
abstract: Libya’s transitional government postponed the first national election since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, moving it from June 19 to July 7 to continue preparations.

headline: Libyan Militias Turn to Politics, a Volatile Mix
abstract: Local brigades claim the mantle of guardians, but many civilians worry that they could bully voters, suppress votes or otherwise dominate upcoming elections.

headline: Recovered Bin Laden Letters Show a Divided Al Qaeda
abstract: Al Qaeda’s senior leadership was split by debates on tactics, strategy and even marketing in the months leading up to the raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

headline: Deal Expands Chinese Influence on Hollywood
abstract: The Wanda Group will buy AMC Entertainment, making the world’s largest theater group, the companies said.

headline: Syrian Groups Say Violent Day Left High Civilian Toll
abstract: Rebel fighters reported the deadliest 24 hours of the uprising as Kofi Annan, the special envoy for the United Nations, said he was hopeful about talks on Saturday.

abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: What’s Your Story? Tell It, and You May Win a Prize
abstract: Russell Goldsmith of City National Bank in Los Angeles says it offers “Story Idol” competitions, “a way to give colleagues a pat on the back and a moment in the sun for doing the right thing.”

headline: Chinese Court Overturns a Young Tycoon’s Death Sentence
abstract: The Chinese tycoon’s conviction ignited an outcry in China, especially on the Internet, and strengthened public criticism of the death sentence.

headline: Blast in Afghan Market Kills 9
abstract: Nine civilians were killed on Monday when a bomb exploded in a crowded bazaar in northern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said.

headline: Saudi Ambassador Returns to Egypt
abstract: The ambassador had been recalled and missions were closed after a wave of protests by Egyptians against the detention of an Egyptian lawyer in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Disgraced Chinese Official’s Son Tries to Defuse Sports Car Scandal
abstract: Bo Guagua, whose mother and father are at the heart of a corruption inquiry, defends himself and calls for privacy.

headline: The Betting Window Is Open for Greece’s Future
abstract: Just about everyone agrees that the chance of Greece abandoning the euro has risen of late. It’s now the topic of speculation on an online betting market.

headline: Engineers Convene to Seek Ways to Strengthen New York State’s Power Grid
abstract: The state’s energy infrastructure is ailing, said Gil C. Quinones, chief of the New York Power Authority.

headline: Junta in Mali to Step Down
abstract: The agreement by the coup leaders to yield power should free Mali to focus on its other big problem: a rebellion in the north.

headline: South Korea to Sign Military Pact With Japan
abstract: A treaty between South Korea and Japan will encourage the sharing of military data on their common concerns: North Korea’s threats and China’s military expansion.

headline: U.S. Stresses Concessions From China
abstract: For the first time, according to senior American officials, Chinese policy makers said they would commit to removing advantageous financing and regulatory conditions to state-owned enterprises.

headline: United States Talks Fail as Pakistanis Seek Apology
abstract: Negotiations between the United States and Pakistan failed over Pakistani demands for an apology for American airstrikes last November that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers on the Afghan border.

headline: U.S. and Pakistan Say Deal to Open NATO Supply Lines Is Imminent
abstract: An invitation for Pakistan to attend a NATO summit meeting in Chicago this weekend appears to have helped achieve a resolution.

headline: Exxon and Russia’s Oil Company in Deal for Joint Projects
abstract: The agreement will form joint venture, while a Rosneft subsidiary will acquire shares in shale and oil fields in West Texas and western Canada and Exxon oil and gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Bank of America Starts Mortgage Reduction Effort
abstract: Bank of America has started sending letters to thousands of homeowners in the United States, offering to forgive a portion of the principal balance on their mortgages by an average of $150,000 each.

headline: Machinists at Lockheed to Vote On Agreement to End a Strike
abstract: If approved by union members, the agreement would end a nine-week strike at a Fort Worth plant and two other sites that build F-35 and F-16 fighter jets.

headline: Iran Sees Success in Stalling on Nuclear Issue
abstract: By continuing its nuclear activities in the face of sanctions, Iran has in effect forced the West to accept an enrichment program it insists is for peaceful purposes.

headline: Spain to Accept Rescue From Europe for Its Ailing Banks
abstract: European finance ministers promised up to $125 billion in aid, which they hope will quell rising financial turmoil ahead of elections in Greece next week that could roil world markets.

headline: A Law Shielded Many Texans When the Housing Bubble Burst
abstract: Texas required any homeowner seeking to refinance a mortgage or take out a home equity loan to have at least 20 percent equity after taking out the new loan.

headline: After Defeat, Livni Quits Parliament in Israel
abstract: Tzipi Livni, who lost the leadership of her centrist Kadima Party and her position atop the opposition, resigned from the Israeli Parliament on Tuesday but said that she was not quitting public life.

headline: Cloud Leaves Some Tech Giants Seeking a Silver Lining
abstract: Some companies that powered the personal computer industry are notably absent from advances in cloud computing.

headline: Newly Elected Myanmar Lawmakers Balk at Word in the Oath of Office
abstract: Opposition members, led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, do not want to swear to “safeguard” a constitution that they had promised to rewrite in their campaigns.

headline: Clasping Hands, Ex-Guerrilla and Queen Briefly Bridge a Divide
abstract: The gesture was a remarkable sign of reconciliation for both figures, since the queen is the titular head of Britain’s armed forces — the sworn enemy of the Irish Republican Army.

headline: Country Comfort Wanted, and a Nearby Safety Net
abstract: The availability of advanced medical care can be crucial when retirees choose a residence.

headline: Agents for Secret Service Face Misconduct Inquiry
abstract: Eleven agents were placed on leave on Saturday as an investigation was opened into accusations of misconduct involving prostitution in Colombia.

headline: Practicing Prudence in Picking Travel Cards
abstract: When choosing credit cards to use for travel, be aware of their benefits and be prepared to keep track of the charges on them.

headline: Lockheed Chief to Retire and Hand Reins to an Insider
abstract: The military contractor said Robert J. Stevens would retire and be succeeded by Christopher E. Kubasik, now president and chief operating officer.

headline: Supply Lines Cast Shadow at NATO Meeting on Afghan War
abstract: A deal to reopen military supply routes through Pakistan to Afghanistan fell apart just as President Obama began talks on ending the NATO alliance’s combat role in Afghanistan.

headline: Using an Offbeat Charm to Keep TV Fans Engaged
abstract: Kat Dennings has struck a chord on “2 Broke Girls” with her portrayal of Max, a waitress with a murderous sideways glance and an offbeat, deadpan wit.

headline: When You Write a Report Card, Explain the Grades
abstract: Laura Yecies of SugarSync, an online storage service, says performance evaluations need to offer positive feedback for employees.

headline: In Serbia, a Populist Makes Gains in Elections Marked by Anger Over the Economy
abstract: Sunday’s vote in presidential and parliamentary elections in Serbia could determine whether the nation lurches back toward nationalism.

headline: Winemaking Lures the Wealthy, but Not With Profits
abstract: If there is one investment that has more to do with the heart than the head, it’s vineyards. Wealthy people have yet to be deterred by the prospect of never making a profit.

headline: Hundreds Protest Screening of Pro-Pinochet Film in Chile
abstract: At least 60 people may have been arrested in the protests over the screening of “Pinochet,” a sympathetic look at the dictator’s rule. Pinochet loyalists held their own rally outside the theater.

headline: Russian Official’s Death Threat, in Bold Type
abstract: The editor of Novaya Gazeta, a prominent newspaper, wrote an open letter accusing Russia’s chief federal investigator of threatening to kill a deputy editor.

headline: Vaccinations Begin in a Cholera-Ravaged Haiti
abstract: A year and a half after the waterborne disease first struck Haiti, more than 530,000 Haitians have been infected and more than 7,040 have died.

headline: Dark-Horse Candidates Add to Egypt’s Suspense
abstract: Ahmed Shafik, a prime minister under former President Hosni Mubarak, and Hamdeed Sabahi, a socialist, appear to be gaining support before the election.

headline: In Poppy War, Taliban Aim to Protect a Cash Crop
abstract: An attack on a Helmand Province police headquarters was part of the militants’ increased efforts to protect opium poppy farmers and their economic interests.

headline: Chávez Out of Sight but Big as Life on Twitter
abstract: The president of Venezuela remains in Cuba for cancer treatment, but keeps up a dialogue with political friends and foes that has led to a flurry of Internet rumors.

headline: Spam Invades a Last Refuge, the Cellphone
abstract: Cellphone customers received roughly 4.5 billion spam texts last year, twice as many as in 2009, and remedies to the growing menace are few.

headline: Making a Cake at 30,000 Feet
abstract: Curtis Stone is a chef and co-host of Bravo’s “Around the World in 80 Plates,” and has been a contestant on “Celebrity Apprentice.”

headline: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Expanding Use of an Anticoagulant
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said concerns over bleeding outweighed the evidence that Xarelto reduced the risk of blood clots.

headline: Suspect in ’95 Tokyo Attack Is Said to Be Caught
abstract: Japan’s public broadcaster said that Katsuya Takahashi, a former member of the Aum Shinrikyo cult, was arrested Friday on suspicion of murder in the 1995 subway gas attack.

headline: For Health, Drink Water (but Don’t Drink the Water)
abstract: Being fastidious about the basics of cleanliness can reduce the odds of becoming ill while traveling.

headline: North Korea Describes Provocation
abstract: It was unclear whether the North’s complaint against South Korea was an attempt to build an excuse for a future nuclear test or an overture aimed at drawing the United States back to the negotiating table.

headline: The Curtain Opens on 401(k) Fees
abstract: New rules will require fuller disclosure about fees in retirement accounts. And that could mean an unpleasant surprise when investors open their statements this fall.

headline: Downgraded in the Sky, Too
abstract: For high-level executives who lose their positions, gone are the days of flying overseas or hopping from one American city to another, often in the front of the plane.

headline: When Flying 720 Miles Takes 12 Hours
abstract: Even with the demand for seats increasing, the big airlines have not restored many of their flights, particularly on routes to small airports.

headline: At Annual Meeting, Wal-Mart to Confront Shareholder Unrest
abstract: The retailing giant holds its annual meeting Friday, celebrating 50 years in business but also having to deal with shareholder opposition to board members and some corporate policies.

headline: Amid Uproar, Graphic Painting of South African President Is Removed From Gallery
abstract: Controversy erupted after a painting depicting South Africa’s president, Jacob Zuma, with his genitals exposed was exhibited at a Johannesburg gallery.

headline: Americas Meeting Ends With Discord Over Cuba
abstract: Western Hemisphere nations failed to issue a consensus statement amid disagreements over whether to let Cuba join future summit meetings.

headline: Authorities Bar 3 Leading Candidates in Egypt Race
abstract: Egyptian election authorities eliminated the three presidential candidates in an unexpected decision that threw the contest into disarray once again.

headline: Subtly Selling ‘Green’ to the Flat-Screen Crowd
abstract: Energy Forward, a label for appliances that meet Energy Star’s top standards, seeks to appeal to consumers’ inner tech fan.

headline: Canadian Police Violated Laws in G-20 Sweep, Inquiry Finds
abstract: Police officers jailed people illegally and escalated violence at protests surrounding the Group of 20 meeting in Toronto two years ago, an independent review concluded Wednesday.

headline: U.S.-Pakistan Freeze Chokes Fallback Route in Afghanistan
abstract: Pakistan’s ban on NATO truck traffic to protest a deadly American airstrike has increased demand on Afghanistan’s sketchy infrastructure everywhere, and on one tunnel in particular.

headline: Report Says Pepsi in Deals With IHOP and Applebee’s
abstract: PepsiCo plans to announce an exclusive deal to supply all nonalcoholic beverages in IHOP and Applebee’s restaurants, according to a note distributed Sunday to subscribers of a trade publication.

headline: Regulators Move Closer to Oversight of Nonbanks
abstract: The Financial Stability Oversight Council will examine the riskiness of some nonbanks in an effort to place stronger regulations on important financial institutions.

headline: You Can Change the Channel, but Local News Is the Same
abstract: Agreements in which local TV stations share news operations are seen by the stations as a survival strategy, and by critics as a barrier to competition.

headline: At News Corp., a Plan to Sever Publishing Arm
abstract: The News Corporation is in talks to sever its publishing assets from its lucrative entertainment units.

headline: A ‘Mad Men’ Debut for a Behind-the-Scenes Player
abstract: Turn, a Silicon Valley company that helps marketers, will run its own commercial on the season finale of “Mad Men.”

headline: Groups to Help Online Activists in Authoritarian Countries
abstract: Human rights proponents from different generations combine efforts to give closed societies a voice.

headline: Nascent Deal Would Let Dissident From China Study in U.S.
abstract: Chinese officials will allow Chen Guangcheng to travel to the United States with his family, American officials said, but Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton cautioned that this case still unresolved.

abstract: The center would make eBay the first major tech company to use alternative power as a primary source for such facilities.

headline: Tensions on a Campus Mirror Turbulence in a New Tunisia
abstract: A university dean’s experience dealing with ultraconservative Salafist students on a secular campus offers a window into the larger forces at work in Tunisia today.

abstract: Turkey escalated its warnings, even as some American and allied officials privately raised questions about whether the Turkish warplane shot down by Syria had been on a spy mission.

abstract: A prominent American forensic scientist, Henry C. Lee, said a police detective from the city of Chongqing contacted him about analyzing a blood sample from someone who had died after drinking.

abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron said he had won an agreement for a Scotland Yard team to conduct an investigation in Libya into the killing by Libyan diplomats of a London police officer in 1984.

abstract: A judge with the National Labor Relations Board found that Target managers had intimidated workers and violated federal labor laws.

headline: Violence Spreads in Struggle for Baghdad Shrine
abstract: A return of sectarian violence in Iraq’s capital appears to have been prompted by the rebuilding of a religious shrine bombed in 2006.

headline: How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000
abstract: A neural network of computer processors, fed millions of YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition.

headline: Toyota Back in the Game, Auto Sales Are the Best in 4 Years
abstract: The Japanese company’s sales rose 12 percent, a year after production slowed when the earthquake and tsunami hit Japan.

headline: U.S. Sees Iran in Bids to Stir Unrest in Afghanistan
abstract: American officials say a mixed picture of Iran’s capabilities emerged after the country’s agents tried, but failed, to exploit public outrage over the burning of Korans by American troops.

headline: Colleges for Profit Are Growing, With Federal Help
abstract: While state and local governments spend less on higher education, the volume of federally guaranteed loans to students at commercial colleges continues to grow.

headline: Raising the Floor on Pay
abstract: As the nation’s economy slowly recovers, several states are pushing to raise the minimum wage, arguing that $7.25 an hour is too meager to live on.

headline: In Europe, Divorce and Separation Become a Burden for Struggling Fathers
abstract: The number of single fathers and divorced men in Italy who are in dire economic circumstances is growing, and many are becoming homeless as the euro zone crisis pushes unemployment higher.

headline: Egypt Delays Declaring Winner of Presidential Election
abstract: A deferral by the election commission intensified a power struggle between the Muslim Brotherhood and Egypt’s military rulers.

headline: Verifying Ages Online Is a Daunting Task, Even for Experts
abstract: Recent sexual assaults on children by adults who pretended to be minors on Skout, a mobile social networking app, has highlighted the challenge of verifying ages online.

headline: World Leaders Urge Growth, Not Austerity
abstract: Meeting at Camp David, leaders of the world’s richest countries banded together to press Germany to back more pro-growth policies to halt the deepening debt crisis in Europe.

headline: 2 Publishers Deny Claim of E-Book Price Fixing
abstract: In response to a Justice Department lawsuit, the two book publishers denied any price fixing for e-books and accuse Amazon of engaging in anticompetitive behavior.

headline: Report on Its Banks’ Needs Raises Spain’s Borrowing Costs
abstract: The release of results of two audits is expected to let Spain’s government begin bargaining with European officials over the terms of a bailout.

headline: After Cabinet Officials, Next on the Docket for Pakistan’s Chief Justice Is His Son
abstract: Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry is heading a three-justice panel investigating corruption allegations against his son.

headline: A Power Vacuum Is Killing the Euro Zone
abstract: The world needs to face the danger that the euro could implode — proving that one of the world’s major economic units simply hasn’t worked.

headline: Catering to Caviar Tastes From an Unexpected Place
abstract: An entrepreneur’s plans to produce caviar in South Korea have finally come to fruition, 15 years after he imported 200 sturgeons from Russia.

headline: China to Investigate Death of Labor Activist
abstract: Chinese officials, bending to public pressure, have announced an investigation into the death of dissident Li Wangyang, whose body was found hanging from a hospital window this month.

headline: Corruption Case Hits Hard in a Tough Time for Greece
abstract: The case of the former defense minister, Akis Tsochatzopoulos, has raised emotional issues in a political culture widely seen as rife with corruption.

headline: Turkey to Consult NATO Over Downing of Jet by Syria
abstract: Turkey has admitted the plane strayed into Syrian territory but said Sunday that the jet was in international airspace when it was shot down.

headline: Reviving Real Estate Requires Collective Action
abstract: Lenders need to write down the amounts owed by homeowners, but the different stakeholders have been unable to agree on how to do this, though they share common interests.

headline: Experts Say Default Would Mean Eviction
abstract: Greece’s exit would be a seismic event politically and economically, but it is something investors have been preparing for.

headline: Bin Laden Death Anniversary Prompts Increased Security
abstract: Officials emphasized that there is no credible information on any threats, but will increase their vigilance at selected airports abroad.

headline: Public Suicide for Greek Man With Fiscal Woe

headline: A Shipwreck Cuts Two Ways for an Island’s Lifeblood
abstract: The tourism-dependent Giglio has had a drop in overnight bookings but an increase in day trips since the Costa Concordia capsized.

abstract: Conflicting reports about former President Hosni Mubarak’s health added new volatility to a political and constitutional crisis in the country he once ruled.

abstract: After the Greek and French elections, growth is now a priority in Europe, but significant change may depend on how far Germany is willing to budge from austerity.

abstract: The Afghan president’s spokesman said Saturday that last week’s civilian casualties during a raid on Taliban fighters in eastern Afghanistan were unacceptable.

headline: German Ruling Against Circumcising Boys Draws Criticism
abstract: In a nation that is home to millions of Muslims and more than 100,000 Jews, the Cologne court’s decision was seen by many as an attack on religious freedom.

abstract: Jamal Yousef, a former member of the Syrian military pleaded guilty on Friday in federal court in Manhattan to conspiracy to provide material support to a Colombian terrorist organization.

abstract: Money has been fleeing Greece for more than two and a half years. But the outflow has picked up since last week’s election raised the specter of Greek default.

headline: U.N. Council to Expand North Korea Sanctions
abstract: The council’s unanimous measure condemning North Korea’s failed rocket launching reflected the country’s near-total isolation over the issue.

headline: A Web Retailer Buys the Perfect Domain Name. Then Comes a Letdown.
abstract: Despite high hopes and careful planning, the Newark Nut Company’s Web traffic took a dive after the company moved to Nuts.com.

headline: Trustee Sees Customers Trampled at MF Global
abstract: A report on the collapse of MF Global reveals a questionable series of moves that indicate the firm failed in its duty to protect the assets of its clients.

headline: New Balance Celebrates Its Homemade Footprint
abstract: The shoe company began an ad campaign this month to highlight the 30th anniversary of its 990 running shoe, which is made in the United States.

headline: A New Front Line in the U.S. Drug War

headline: Luxury Liner’s Removal to Begin Off Italian Coast
abstract: The Costa Concordia, the cruise ship that ran aground in January, will be lifted onto a platform beginning next week and then towed away to be demolished.

headline: Publicis Makes Advertising's First Foray Into Palestinian Territories
abstract: The French company has bought 20 percent of Zoom Advertising, a small agency that comes with considerable symbolic significance, the company said.

abstract: Lakhdar Boumediene, who spent seven years at Guantánamo Bay before being released for lack of evidence, says he still does not understand why he was detained and just wants a return to normalcy.

headline: Fannie Mae Posts Profit; Seeks No Aid
abstract: The government-backed mortgage financier said it made a profit in the first quarter and that it does not need additional bailout money — a first since the federal government took it over in 2008.

abstract: A token sentence deflates some political pressure, but Yousaf Raza Gilani could still lose his job.

abstract: Fallout from JPMorgan Chase’s bad bets is revealing lapses in the policing of the office that disclosed a multibillion trading loss.

headline: Latin American Markets Aim for a New Decade of Gains
abstract: Analysts see continued economic success for the region — and for investors who keep money there for the long haul.

abstract: In a major precedent relating to conditions in an American maximum security prison, the court allowed for the extradition of the cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri and four other defendants.

abstract: Janet Yellen, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said the country’s lackluster recovery could require an emphasis on growth, not inflation, beyond 2014.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

abstract: The founders of Instagram, now multimillionaires after Facebook bought their app this week, were helped along the way by the tight web in the Bay Area tech scene.

headline: Departing EADS Chief Urges Europe to Recommit to Industry
abstract: Louis Gallois, who will retire next month from European Aeronautic Defense & Space, emphasizes that Europe must not neglect its own industries as it pursues a global vision.

abstract: Turkey’s foreign minister reported increased Syrian military attacks near the border and a relentless influx of refugees from Syria on Friday.

headline: Philippine Chief Justice Defends Finances at Impeachment Trial
abstract: At times weeping on the stand, Chief Justice Renato C. Corona testified for the first time in his impeachment trial in the Philippine Senate.

abstract: The corruption allegations against his son were a serious blow for the chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, who until now has been virtually venerated by many Pakistanis.

abstract: Russia’s leaders took part in a trade union parade with an estimated crowd of 150,000, as a nation re-enacted celebrations from the Soviet era.

abstract: Young adults in Iran who came of age after the revolution have resigned themselves to making the best of a bad situation.

abstract: The inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission is focused on at least three studios and creates a potential roadblock for the industry’s plans to expand in one of the world’s largest markets.

abstract: Interior Ministry officials said on Wednesday that prison authorities are close to a decision to return Hosni Mubarak, the former president, to a hospital outside the penal system.

abstract: The government and opposition issued a joint list of demands that could pave the way for the reopening of NATO supply lines there.

abstract: Major airlines are investing in things like better seats, while Spirit is making a profit and expanding with low fares but many fees.

abstract: Much of the Earth’s population growth is in sub-Saharan African nations like Nigeria, where trends that have lowered birthrates elsewhere have not yet caught on.

abstract: Objections to proposals on money market mutual funds, intended to avert a future taxpayer bailout, echo past battles over financial industry reforms.

abstract: Authorities raided companies connected to a billionaire opposition leader, seizing satellite dishes being distributed to provide access to an opposition station.

abstract: Kenyan authorities were looking for several people who they believe planted a homemade bomb at a crowded market in Nairobi on Monday.

abstract: The security guard wanted in the slaying of three colleagues and the wounding of a fourth, was captured as he tried to cross into the United States.

abstract: A new study finds that New York, New Jersey and Maryland are the best states at helping residents’ incomes rise. Louisiana, Oklahoma and South Carolina fared worst in the study.

abstract: The recent death of Víctor Báez, a longstanding police reporter, has added to a climate of fear among journalists in Veracruz State, a center of increasing drug violence.

abstract: The story of Strikers, the country’s only bowling alley, seems to be that rarest of things, an Afghan good news story.

abstract: The search giant also reported first-quarter revenue that rose 24 percent and earnings that slightly beat analysts’ expectations.

abstract: Foursquare, a start-up whose app lets users share their locations, has seen its growth slow, and its founders hope that suggesting places to users could change that.

abstract: The International Monetary Fund’s extra lending capacity could be used if the euro zone crisis worsens or global financial conditions deteriorate.

abstract: Frustrated by stalled negotiations, the parents of an Army sergeant abruptly disclosed that he was the subject of secret negotiations.

abstract: With its best-selling drugs losing patent protection, Pfizer is shedding money-making but noncore businesses to focus on pharmaceutical sciences.

abstract: The administration of Mexican President Felipe Calderón decided Wednesday to look into bribery payments after pressure from lawmakers and good government groups.
