abstract: François Hollande, who was the mayor of Tulle, France, for seven years, has won praise there for his common touch.

headline: The Continuing Problem of Bank Instability
abstract: A reader responds to “Telling Strength From Weakness,” the Fair Game column of April 29.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Future for the Networks This Fall
abstract: A look at the needs of major television networks as the upfronts begin.

headline: Amid Signs of Economic Weaknesses, China to Free Cash for Lending
abstract: After this week’s disappointing economic figures, China’s central bank said Saturday that it would reduce the share of deposits banks must set aside as reserves.

headline: Power Shortages Set Off Small Protests in Myanmar
abstract: Numerous protests have arisen in Myanmar over persistent power shortages as the past year’s democratic reforms have led to rising expectations from a long-suppressed population.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
abstract: This week’s reports include the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for March and personal income and spending for April.

headline: Facebook Offers More Disclosure to Users
abstract: Seeking to address criticism of its privacy practices, the social networking site said it would provide a downloadable archive of the many types of data on individuals that it stores and tracks.

headline: Apple’s Response on Its Tax Practices
abstract: A statement from the company in response to an investigation by The New York Times.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.

headline: British Minister Concedes Sympathy to Murdoch TV Bid
abstract: Jeremy Hunt, the culture minister, told a British panel that he had been personally sympathetic to a bid by Rupert Murdoch to take over British Sky Broadcasting but that he did not act with any favorable bias.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
abstract: Data will include retail sales and import prices for May, Kroger and Smithfield Foods will report earnings and Apple will hold its annual conference.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.

headline: Letters: The Bridges to the Future
abstract: Readers respond to “Repairing Roads Can End All Kinds of Gridlock” (Economic View, June 3).

headline: The Fading of the Euro
abstract: A reader responds to “A Power Vacuum Is Choking the Euro Zone” (Economic View, May 27).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.

headline: The Federal Reserve’s Interest Rate Statement
abstract: The Federal Open Market Committee kept the federal fund rate steady and extended a program meant to keep long-term rates low.

headline: Can Government Rescue Housing?
abstract: Readers respond to “Reviving Real Estate Requires Collective Action” (Economic View, June 24).

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A reader criticizes the new Nissan minivans that will become the “Taxis of Tomorrow” for New York City.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.

headline: Nokia Lowers Its Estimate for Profit in First Quarter
abstract: The world’s largest maker of cellphones by volume lowered its forecast on Wednesday as demand for its Symbian-based smartphones, which the company is phasing out, weakened sharply.

headline: With Venezuelan Food Shortages, Some Blame Price Controls
abstract: Staples like milk, meat and toilet paper can be hard to find in Venezuela, and many blame the government’s price-control policies.

headline: Business Day Live: A Slowdown in China
abstract: Weighing an economic slowdown in China, and commodities traders boycott an exchange over a regulatory dispute.

headline: Surpassing the Great American Consumer
abstract: Upwardly mobile consumers from much poorer countries are about to displace Americans in their share of the world economy.

headline: Battery Power Drives Screen Size
abstract: If Apple is putting a bigger screen in the next iPhone, it will be to make more room for a bigger battery, not because of big-screen envy.

headline: Herman Cain to Host a National Radio Show
abstract: The one-time Republican presidential candidate will be offered to stations in place of “The Neal Boortz Show,” which will end at the same time.

headline: Karnataka Bans Most Scientists From Tiger Parks, Halting Years of Research
abstract: Wildlife officials claim scientists’ presence harmful to tigers.

headline: Photos of Soldiers Posing With Body Parts Add Strain to a Taxed Relationship
abstract: The revelation that United States soldiers posed with body parts of dead insurgents is just the latest in a series of self-inflicted wounds to a American military trying to negotiate a way out of Afghanistan.

headline: The Fiscal Legacy of George W. Bush
abstract: Republicans’ insistence that tax cuts are stimulative and that tax increases never reduce the deficit are unsupported by the facts, an economist writes.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: ‘Open Data’ and Turntable.fm
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes how blind people are using iPhones and a discussion of how Zynga’s purchase of Omgpop, the maker of the game Draw Something, is looking a month later.

headline: For Union-Owned Bank, Lifeline Offers Chance for Growth
abstract: Amalgamated Bank announced on Wednesday that two financiers, Wilbur L. Ross Jr. and Ronald W. Burkle, had closed a deal giving them 41 percent ownership in the bank. Amalgamated said the money would be used to shore up its capital ratio and expand.

headline: Challenging the Long-Held Belief in ‘Shareholder Value’
abstract: Lynn A. Stout, a professor at Cornell Law School, says that the business principle that companies should be run for the sole purpose returning value to shareholders has worked out horribly and, as a matter of law, is not true.

headline: The Boldface Names on the Witness List for Gupta’s Trial
abstract: Possible witnesses who could be called to testify — or whose names may come up during the trial — include Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldman’s chief executive, and A.G. Lafley, the former chief executive of Procter & Gamble.

headline: The Cost of Microsoft’s Surface Tablet
abstract: Let’s just assume for a few minutes that Microsoft’s Surface tablet is as delicious as Microsoft executives made it out to be on Monday night. Does Microsoft then have any hope of competing with the iPad on price? Even if it does undercut Apple, which no serious tablet maker has done, it is no assurance of success.

headline: In Latest Pay Rebuke, Investor to Oppose Goldman Director
abstract: In a letter to clients this week, the managers of Sequoia Fund announced plans to vote against director James A. Johnson, former chief executive of Fannie Mae, and urged other shareholders to do the same.

headline: Wednesday Reading: The Frugal Traveler Flies Business Class
abstract: The Frugal Traveler flies business class, how muscle workouts may boost brainpower, law school to offer master’s degree online and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Refunds for Wedding Gifts After the Couple Splits Up
abstract: A Web site offers refunds for wedding gifts, if the marriage ends in divorce.

headline: Groups Seek Senate Review of Universal-EMI Deal
abstract: The Consumer Federation of America and Public Knowledge, opponents of the Universal Music Group’s $1.9 billion bid for EMI’s record labels, are asking the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust issues to examine the deal.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Apps That Eke Better Sound From Old Earphones
abstract: A number apps let you tailor your music to your tastes. At less than $10 each (some are free), they could save you from buying new headphones.

headline: Hedge Fund Intensifies Attack on Yahoo Amid Storm Over Padded Résumés
abstract: On Friday, the hedge fund Third Point, which is in the middle of a contentious proxy battle with Yahoo, called for the dismissal of the technology company’s chief executive, Scott Thompson, after revealing that he had inaccurately stated his credentials.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Ignorance, Too, Can Be Viral
abstract: Fast access to false facts and uninformed comment give everyone a sense of expertise. Online or on air, people can find a basis to convert any prejudice into hidebound conviction.

headline: Why the Bailout in Spain Won’t Work
abstract: It now appears that the $125 billion bailout of Spain’s banks could make things there worse, not better. And market indicators for the next domino in line for a bailout, Italy, point in the wrong direction.

headline: India’s Industry Helps Open a Door to the World
abstract: India’s understaffed foreign service relies on business leaders for diplomacy.

headline: Real Estate Giant Domus Holdings Files for an I.P.O.
abstract: By taking the parent of Century 21 and Coldwell Banker public, the company’s majority owner, Apollo Global Management, is betting that the American housing sector is finally ready for an upswing.

headline: Divided Lebanon Powerless to Keep out Syria’s War
abstract: Violence and protests in Lebanon linked to the conflict in Syria have stoked long-standing fears that the uprising against the Damascus regime could destabilize its fragile neighbor.

headline: Q&A: Making iTunes Ignore the Gap
abstract: Thanks to a setting in iTunes, fans of opera and “Abbey Road” do not have to hear seconds of silence between selections.

headline: Digital Diary: Instagram and the Internet’s ‘Secret’ Places
abstract: The news of Instagram’s sale brings a sharper reality into focus — that the secluded and private corners of the Web where we can let our hair down and be our authentic selves are fewer and farther between with each passing day.

headline: Executive Turntable: Universal Hires Former Warner Brothers Boss
abstract: Tom Whalley, a former head of Warner Brothers Records whose résumé includes signing Tupac Shakur and Nine Inch Nails, gets a new label with Universal.

headline: Macedonia’s Plea for a Seat in NATO Falls on Busy Ears
abstract: The small country with a disproportionately large force in Afghanistan makes a case for admission into NATO.

headline: I Have Seen the Future of Manufacturing, Part 2
abstract: And it’s not as scary as this owner feared it might be.

headline: Image of the Day: June 8
abstract: Thousands of asthma patients throng a camp in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh to be administered a cure consisting of live sardine fish smeared with herbal paste.

headline: A Pitch for a Pollution Solution Goes Off the Deep End
abstract: There was a lot to like about the first part of this pitch, including a socially conscious solution to a serious problem.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: A Rising Debate on Inequality
abstract: A look back on eye-popping pay packages and more in our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Former Dewey & LeBoeuf Partner Sues Firm’s Management
abstract: Henry Bunsow, a former partner at the bankrupt Dewey & LeBoeuf, is suing the firm’s management team and several partners, claiming they misrepresented the financials and pushed partners to make capital investments.

headline: How Much Punch Does a Wine Pack?
abstract: Alcohol content in wine is an issue that is generating a lot of discussion among winemakers, critics and consumers around the world, as levels seem to rise year after year. Part of the problem is that there is no “normal” alcohol level for wine. Some light wines have no more alcohol than a lager. Others, like those of Weingut Franz Hirtzberger, topped out at 14 percent. Is that a bad thing? Not necessarily.

headline: Saudi End to Olympics Women Ban Will Have No Practical Effect
abstract: Saudi Arabia has been accused of “tokenism” after lifting a ban on sending women athletes to the Olympics. But, with the country’s top female competitor out of the Games, Saudi women may not even have a “token” representing them.

headline: John Arnold Is Said to Close Hedge Fund and Return Investor Money
abstract: John Arnold, one of the most profitable traders in the hedge fund industry, is said to be shutting down Centaurus Advisors and returning money to investors.

headline: In BRICS Nations, Journalists at Risk
abstract: In Brazil, Russia and India, killers of journalists go free.

headline: Live Nation Joins the Dance Party, Buying Promoter of Creamfields
abstract: The deal to buy the British promoter signals the increased interest in electronic dance music events, and could lead to more festivals in the United States.

headline: A Female President Demands Equal Rights for Africa’s Gays
abstract: It could have been Barack Obama’s change of heart, or the entreaties of a pair of African elder statesmen, or David Cameron’s threat to cut off aid. But whatever the reason, Joyce Banda says she intends to change Malawi’s anti-gay laws. Could she change Africa, too?

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Nobody Is Happy
abstract: Institutional investors joined a “bumper crop of proxy fights,” a JPMorgan regulator faced tough questions, Nasdaq’s plan to settle Facebook claims met investor anger and tensions grew between MF Global trustees. A look back on the past week’s highs and lows.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Spinning in Syria, and a ‘No Fuss’ Coming Out for Gay Actor
abstract: Also, no afternoon TV program has broken out of the pack since the end of Oprah Winfrey’s show, and Gordon Brown contradicts earlier testimony in Britain’s inquiry into press ethics.

headline: Wednesday Reading: A Frugal Bike Tour of a Danish Island
abstract: A frugal bike tour of a Danish island, athletic training on a vegan diet, checking up on Windows security and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Image of the Day: June 6
abstract: The Venus transit as visible from Agra, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Verizon to Buy Hughes Telematics for $612 Million
abstract: Verizon Communications said on Friday that it had agreed to buy Hughes Telematics, a maker of wireless systems for vehicles, for $612 million in cash.

headline: Yahoo Will Sell a Stake in Alibaba
abstract: Under the deal, Alibaba will buy back half of Yahoo’s stake, and Yahoo will sell an additional 10 percent when Alibaba goes public.

headline: Image of the Day: May 18
abstract: A man pierced his tongue with a thin rod in protest in New Delhi.

headline: Google’s Comment on Street View Data
abstract: Google issued a statement regarding data that it has said was mistakenly collected in Street View, its program to take pictures along the world’s roadways. The company said, “We did not want this payload data and we never used it in any of our products in Germany or anywhere else in the world.”

headline: An Estimate for Needed Retirement Savings
abstract: A new analysis says employees need 11 times their salary, beyond Social Security, to pay for their retirement.

headline: Gupta’s Wealth in Spotlight at Trial
abstract: A private banker’s notes indicate that Rajat K. Gupta’s net worth was $84 million in 2008, the year when prosecutors say he leaked confidential corporate information to Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: How to Protect Yourself From Your Own Investing Ignorance
abstract: Diversifying our investments is really about protecting ourselves from our own ignorance because we do not (and cannot) know how any single investment will perform over time.

headline: In the Chen Case, Collateral Damage
abstract: As high-level negotiations swirled around the fate of the human rights advocate Chen Guangcheng, several members of his inner circle of supporters and “barefoot lawyers” were picked up by the Chinese authorities. The lawyer Jiang Tianyong, for example, says he was detained — and beaten so badly that he lost the hearing in one ear.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Why Small-Business Lending Is Such a Confusing Mess
abstract: It is hard to get definitive answers to important questions about lending, but the author — a new contributor to You’re the Boss — hopes to help.

headline: Credit Suisse Said to Plan New Round of Layoffs in Europe
abstract: Credit Suisse, which announced a major restructuring effort last year, may reduce the work force of its European investment banking division by as much as 30 percent, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Will There Be a Meaningful Volcker Rule?
abstract: Sound arguments about regulating too-big-to-fail financial institutions may lose out to a barrage of advertisements and campaign spending on behalf of Republicans, an economist writes.

headline: An iPhone Charger With a Bonus
abstract: Hoping to capitalize on the smartphone’s continuous need for juice, Iomega has released SuperHero, an iPhone dock that not only charges but also backs up content.

headline: At Last, Taster’s Choice in a Paris Wine Bar
abstract: It’s not always easy to find a place to sample high-quality wines by the glass in Paris. You’re better off going to the wine-producing regions of France. Or Italy. Stephane Girard is trying to change that.

headline: Facebook I.P.O. Raises Regulatory Concerns
abstract: Regulators, in part, are concerned that banks may have shared information about Facebook with certain clients, rather than broadly with investors.

headline: Yahoo’s General Counsel Resigns
abstract: Yahoo said on Friday that its general counsel, Michael Callahan, had resigned, in the latest executive change under the Internet company’s interim chief executive, Ross Levinsohn.

headline: NBC’s ‘Community’ to Lose Its Temperamental Maestro
abstract: The news that the sitcom’s creator, Dan Harmon, was being replaced as “show runner” will no doubt be a blow to the show’s rabid (if relatively small) fan base.

headline: Once an Ambitious Law Firm, Reduced to Grim Dispatches
abstract: The slow economy and cost-cutting at companies have hurt many of the nation’s law firms, including Dewey & LeBoeuf.

headline: For Private Equity, Fewer Deals in Leaner Times
abstract: Private equity is not the money machine it used to be. Buyouts are more costly, sellers are less willing to negotiate, credit markets are choppy and returns are down, pushing players to take more risks.

headline: Facebook Shifts Its Approach to Payments
abstract: Facebook signaled its ambitions to grow as a payment platform, with changes to how its users can buy goods and services without leaving its site. It is also a clear signal to Wall Street that the company is pushing to make more money.

headline: On Air, an ‘Excited’ Matt Lauer Confirms His Plans
abstract: Matt Lauer, the co-host of the “Today” show, told viewers on Friday that he had decided to stay on the show.

headline: Consumer Agency Seeks Details on Financial Abuse of Elderly
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is inviting consumers to share stories of financial abuse of the elderly.

headline: Nasdaq Plan Comes Under Fire at Industry Conference
abstract: One broker says of Nasdaq’s handling of the Facebook I.P.O. last month: “It’s hard to envision it having been handled more badly.”

headline: How Ackman Won in the Fight Over Canadian Pacific
abstract: Although his rhetoric was at times overheated, William A. Ackman waged a smart campaign to win changes at the railroad company.

headline: Using Your 401(k) to Buy a Small Business
abstract: It takes a creative and determined buyer to purchase a small business in today’s lending environment.

headline: Fighting Cyberbullies With Laws and Laughter
abstract: Online abusers can drive their innocent victims to despair and even suicide. Some victims are using the law to punish the perpetrators, while others are opting for humor.

headline: Disclosure by Short-Sellers Would Improve Market Clarity
abstract: Wild gyrations of stocks based on the barest mention by short-sellers revive the debate on whether rules should require disclosures of big short positions.

headline: Investing in Julia
abstract: Living in and taking part in society requires acceptance of some responsibilities for others, an economist writes.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s Growth Prospects
abstract: As Facebook goes public, it has to figure out how to use its vault of information to enrich its shareholders.

headline: Google Brings Free Wi-Fi to Some New York Subway Stations
abstract: This summer, New York subway riders might be able to actually get some work done on the train (instead of just playing Temple Run on their smartphones). Beginning Monday, free Wi-Fi will be available at a number of stations courtesy of Google.

headline: Friday Reading: Student Loan Debate Becomes Election-Year Fight
abstract: The student loan debate becomes an election-year fight, why mobile data is a cash cow for carriers, early menopause is linked to fracture risk and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Dial 108 for Ambulance in Tamil Nadu
abstract: Much of India lacks emergency services, but a new program brings ambulances to the remotest parts of this southern state.

abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: F.B.I. Begins Preliminary Inquiry Into JPMorgan
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining potential wrongdoing surrounding JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss, people briefed on the matter say.

headline: At Gupta’s Insider Trial, a Star Goldman Witness and Charts
abstract: Lloyd Blankfein’s presence aroused the spectators’ gallery, but the jury might have been more impressed with a series of “summary charts” that crystallized the case that prosecutors have presented.

headline: Many Young Adults Still Struggle With Health Costs, Report Finds
abstract: Some young adults report struggling with health expenses that are causing them to delay educational plans or make other tradeoffs.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Moves Past NBC’s ‘The Voice’
abstract: “American Idol” on Fox has regained its spot as the top-rated show on television, surpassing “The Voice” on NBC.

headline: RailAmerica May Put Itself Up for Sale
abstract: One of the largest operators of short-line railroads in the United State says it is in preliminary discussions toward a possible sale.

headline: Like It or Not, Facebook Changes E-Mail Settings
abstract: Facebook has changed people’s e-mail address settings on the site to automatically show @facebook.com addresses. The company argues that this was not a change to the site’s privacy settings, just a “visual setting change.”

headline: Twittergate Rattles France Before Vote
abstract: The French profess not to care about the love lives of their politicians. However, a very public spat involving President Hollande’s past and present partners has captured interest days before crucial elections.

headline: Jobs and the Election: A Weekly Tracker
abstract: To track the economy, The Times is creating a weekly report on the predicted path of job growth and the unemployment rate between now and the election.

headline: A Conversation With: Actor Prosenjit Chatterjee
abstract: The Bengali actor talks about his latest attempt to return to Bollywood and why he chose Bengali cinema over mainstream Bollywood early on in his career.

headline: Bent on Expansion, Molson to Buy StarBev of Europe
abstract: Molson Coors is buying StarBev, which brews more than 20 brands in countries including the Czech Republic, Serbia, Croatia and Romania, for 2.65 billion euros from the private equity firm CVC Capital Partners and StarBev management.

headline: The iPhone Is Still a Strong Seller for AT&T and Verizon
abstract: There’s no sign that Apple’s iPhone is losing momentum. The popular smartphone remains a strong seller for both AT&T and Verizon, the nation’s two big carriers, even at a time when the number of new contract customers is slowing down to a crawl.

headline: A Modest Monkey Proposal
abstract: In which we propose a unique solution to Delhi’s monkey problems.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Warren Buffett Likes Newspapers, and Barbara Walters Apologizes
abstract: Also, a big deal involving Taylor Swift will finally give labels and performers a cut of radio revenue.

headline: Pfizer Confirms Spinoff of Animal Health Unit
abstract: Shares in Pfizer were up slightly on Thursday after the drug maker announced that it planned to take its animal health unit public rather than sell it.

headline: Federal Prosecutor Nominated for District Court Bench
abstract: President Obama has nominated Katherine Polk Failla, the chief of the criminal appeals unit in the United States attorney’s office for the Southern District of New York, to the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Assigning Blame in Dewey’s Collapse
abstract: Supporters and detractors of Steven H. Davis, who possessed an equanimity that inspired confidence, agree he was the driving force behind a series of moves that sowed the seeds of Dewey & LeBoeuf’s demise.

headline: Tip of the Week: Making Mobile Screen Shots
abstract: How to take a picture of whatever is on the iPhone or Android smartphone screen.

headline: Kraft Tries Again With a Ritz Snack, Aiming Younger
abstract: Ritz Crackerfuls was introduced in 2009, with same target audience as Ritz crackers: women ages 35 to 54. But in a new humorous campaign, the product will be pitched at busy adults, ages 25 to 54.

headline: Majority of CVR Shareholders Accept Icahn Offer
abstract: Carl C. Icahn announced on Monday that he had gotten the right to buy CVR Energy, after a majority of shareholders agreed to sell their shares.

headline: Parents’ Fight With Apple Over ‘Bait Apps’ Moves Forward
abstract: Is Apple doing enough to protect parents’ wallets from their own children? That seems to be the debate that has been brewing in a year-old lawsuit related to iPhone apps and the purchasing mechanisms inside them. After parents type in their password to the App Store, children have a window to keep buying stuff.

headline: Inside a Story About Helping the Elderly to Die
abstract: For an outsider there is something striking about the Dutch attitude to euthanasia, as well as to marijuana and prostitution, all of which are legal, but closely regulated.

headline: Deutsche Borse Asks Court to Overturn Decision to Block NYSE Deal
abstract: The German exchange has asked a European court to overturn a decision by antitrust regulators that blocked its planned merger with NYSE Euronext.

headline: Time to Dial the Turkey-Syria Hotline
abstract: Turkey tried its best to steer neighboring Syria towards political reform. With that battle lost, tensions are rising along their common border as Ankara gears up for possible intervention to protect its own stability.

headline: Pursuing Foreign Fraud Claims on American Soil
abstract: A Securities and Exchange Commission report on whether investors should be able to pursue fraud claims on foreign securities that take place outside the United States may face a hostile reception in Congress.

headline: The Return of the Videophone (Again)
abstract: A new company, telyHD, is trying to move video chats from the PC to the TV room with some new set-top hardware and a connection through Skype.

headline: India the Worst Big Country to Be a Woman
abstract: India lags all major economies, including Saudi Arabia, in treatment of women, survey says.

headline: The Road Toward Recovery for Sahar Gul
abstract: Sahar Gul, a young Afghan woman who was tortured by her husband and in-laws for six months, is recovering at a shelter for abused women in Kabul.

headline: India’s ‘Telecom Revolution’ Turns Ugly
abstract: Facing new regulation and retroactive taxation, companies are pulling out of India, criticizing the government and threatening to sue.

headline: Let the Memes Begin …
abstract: Gary He’s take on CNN’s initial wrong call on the Supreme Court ruling on the health care law.

headline: After Coty Bid Dies, Avon Faces Hard Slog
abstract: Shares in Avon plunged on Tuesday after Coty withdrew its $10.7 billion bid. Now the cosmetics maker faces few easy options in its turnaround effort.

headline: Cooking the Planet or the Self, an Uneasy Choice
abstract: The rising demand of air-conditioners among India’s middle classes to sustain the soaring temperatures, could worsen global warming.

headline: Apple’s Former Patent Chief Joins Nest Labs
abstract: Apple’s former patent chief, Richard Lutton Jr., has joined Nest Labs, a hot Silicon Valley start-up, which has developed a sleek, energy-saving digital thermostat. Honeywell, the giant of the thermostat industry, sued Nest, alleging patent infringement, earlier this year. Nest filed its reply on Thursday.

headline: The Return of Oprah’s Book Club
abstract: After two years, Oprah Winfrey’s highly influential book club is being revived, with “Wild,” by Cheryl Strayed, as the first selection.

headline: How to Help Durga and Girls Like Her
abstract: Several nonprofits try to encourage poor girls in India to stay in school.

headline: Profit and Proliferation: A Special Report on Belgian Arms in the Arab Uprising, Part I
abstract: The uprisings in Libya and Syria have cast the Belgian small arms industry as a case study of the difficulty of balancing the preservation of local revenue and jobs with the risks of compromising European policies and human rights values.

headline: Thursday Reading: How Foul Is Your Favorite Beach?
abstract: How foul is your favorite beach, luxury doghouses, new detergent pods pose poisoning risks and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Obama Will Need Young Voters to Keep His Job, Even if They Don’t Have One
abstract: The kids are revolting. And their displeasure over education costs and job prospects are shaking up politics from France to Canada to Chile to the United States.

headline: Monday Reading: Future Grandparents Pay for Egg Freezing
abstract: Future grandparents pay for egg freezing, how to travel with your mother, student loans weigh on a generation and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Martin Marietta Feels the Einhorn Effect
abstract: Martin Marietta Materials’ stock price plunged sharply seconds after the Greenlight Capital founder recommended shorting the company’s shares at the Ira Sohn Conference.

headline: Digital Notes: Clear Channel Signs Rivals’ Stations to Its App
abstract: The company’s streaming-radio app, iHeartRadio, will be adding streams from 106 stations controlled by two other major radio companies, the Cox Media Group and Emmis Communications.

headline: For Europe’s Banks, Pinch of Debt Crisis Intensifies
abstract: After a strong rally in European stock and bond markets earlier this year, financial institutions are again gearing up for fallout from the continuing sovereign debt crisis.

headline: ‘First Responders’ Might Have Second Thoughts on Myanmar
abstract: The first public confrontation between democrats and the government of Myanmar since the election has raised the question of whether the West has been too quick to roll back political and economic sanctions.

headline: Head of Institute of International Finance to Step Down
abstract: Charles Dallara, the managing director of the Institute of International Finance who had a prominent role in negotiations between private bondholders and Greece, is stepping down.

headline: Dewey & LeBoeuf Said to Encourage Partners to Leave
abstract: At least 10 more partners left the New York law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf on Monday as it tried to stave off collapse by persuading its lenders not to force it into bankruptcy.

headline: Friday Reading: Taking Calcium May Pose Heart Risks
abstract: Taking calcium may pose heart risks, summer gas prices are expected to be moderately lower, a battle brews over labeling of genetically modified food and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across the nation.

headline: Income of Rulers vs. the Ruled
abstract: Is today’s socioeconomic gap between American politicians and their constituents really unusually wide? A look at inequality between leaders and those they lead, from Rome to the present.

headline: Popular Support for Growing Trade Ties Between India and Pakistan
abstract: Indians in Delhi and the border town of Attari are enthusiastic about the growing trade ties.

headline: A New Leica, Not in Living Color
abstract: A camera from Leica uses the latest technology to achieve an old-fashioned goal: perfect black-and-white photography.

headline: Few Seize on a U.S. Bond Program Backing Green Energy
abstract: Even as state and local governments struggle to meet higher green energy standards with ever-shrinking budgets, billions of dollars of so-called Qualified Energy Conservation Bonds have gone unused.

headline: Banking Culture Blasted in Backlash Against Greed
abstract: The City of London is reeling from the latest revelations of greed and dishonesty within the banking sector. The public wants to know why the guilty are not already in jail.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Mother Myth and Big Omaha
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selection includes a study of the best times to post to social media, a report from Foxconn on features of the coming Apple TV and a Facebook founder renouncing his U.S. citizenship.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Facebook Adds Sandberg to Board
abstract: Facebook is adding Sheryl Sandberg, its chief operating officer, to its board. The company has been pilloried for having no women on the board.

headline: Cricket and the Ajmer Sharif Shrine Bolster India Pakistan Relations
abstract: When Pakistan’s leaders come to India, either a match or a shrine visit provide common ground.

headline: Backlog of Disability Claims for Veterans Sends Democrat on a Tear
abstract: During a House Veterans Affairs Committee hearing on the ever-growing backlog of disability compensation claims Tuesday, one lawmaker turned a normally staid policy meeting into a contentious affair.

abstract: Births to mothers 15 to 19 years old are at their lowest levels in the United States since at least 1940, when the government began keeping track.

abstract: Thanks to integration with Microsoft’s Messenger program, Windows Live Hotmail users just need to link their Windows Live profiles to Facebook to chat with online friends right from the mail window.

abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Test Launch of Agni V, India’s Long-Range Missile
abstract: Video of India’s successful missile test.

headline: European Regulators Approve J.&J.’s Takeover of Synthes
abstract: European regulators approved Johnson & Johnson’s $21 billion acquisition of the medical equipment maker Synthes on Thursday after the company agreed to divest part of its European operations.

headline: Bain Capital Said to Plan Raising New Fund
abstract: Bain Capital will soon begin raising its 11th leveraged buyout fund, with an aim of drawing in about $8 billion from investors, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: S.L.R. Video Cameras for the Pros
abstract: The world of professional TV and film changed suddenly when digital S.L.R.’s — still cameras — were designed to capture video. And I mean, incredible video, with all the flexibility of interchangeable lenses and amazing low-light capability.

headline: Two Financiers Take Control of Barneys, Ending Its Debt Struggles
abstract: Perry Capital, which is Barneys’ biggest bondholder, announced on Monday that it had taken control of the retailer, concluding a long-running effort to reorganize its finances after laboring under nearly $600 million in debt.

headline: In London, A Wealth of Indian Mangoes
abstract: Web retailers bring Indian mangoes to British homes, quickly and cheaply.

headline: At Made in NY Awards, Kickstarter Shares Honors With Streep and De Niro
abstract: The awards, which were handed out Monday night at Gracie Mansion by the mayor, recognized people and companies for their achievements in “making it” in New York.

headline: America’s Place in the New World
abstract: American leaders have long presumed that the world’s democracies will align themselves with the United States, but India and Brazil are challenging that idea.

headline: How Big Data Sees Wikipedia
abstract: Kalev Leetaru, a researcher at the University of Illinois, has been looking at Wikipedia as a Big Data resource, concentrating on the connections between cities around the globe over time. The result is an interesting historical atlas of the rise of globalization and warfare

headline: Fresenius Group Bids $4.1 Billion for Hospital Operator
abstract: The Fresenius Group offered $4.1 billion to buy the German hospital operator Rhön-Klinikum, as it looked to increase its presence in the German market.

headline: A Conversation With: USIBC Chairman Ajay Banga
abstract: “India can’t just sit there and wait for investment to come in.”

headline: Journal Reporter Quits Over E-Mails to Iraqi Envoy Nominee
abstract: Gina Chon agreed to resign after she admitted violating company policy by showing articles before publication to Brett McGurk, then on the National Security Council staff.

headline: OPEC Sees Sanctions Taking Toll on Iran Oil Production
abstract: A decline in Iranian oil demand from reliable customers including India, after pressure from Obama administration.

abstract: The desktop interface, called “windows, icons, menus, pointer,” or WIMP, never seemed to work for most people. What has worked in intuitive computing is iOS, which continues to make its way onto the desktop.

headline: This Week in Small Business: 10 Billion Video Ads

abstract: Coty said on Monday that it was abandoning its pursuit for Avon Products, citing Avon’s “unwillingness to engage in discussions.”

abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

abstract: The Hub, a children’s cable channel, is hoping to get some buzz at the event by having Mr. King conduct an interview with the actor who voices a character on one of its cartoons.

abstract: Trying to decipher what went wrong with the internationally-recognized project.

headline: Will Manmohan Singh Shake Up the Finance Ministry Again?
abstract: A decade ago, the Prime Minister made bold moves in the ministry.

headline: Are the Owner’s Children Entitled to the Business?

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: The Stock Everyone Wants

headline: Gupta’s Daughter Testifies at His Insider Trading Trial

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Spawns Circle of Young Tycoons

headline: The Well, a Pioneering Online Community, Is for Sale Again

headline: A Harvard Professor Analyzes Why Start-Ups Fail
abstract: One crucial issue: Do you want to make a lot of money, or do you want to run the show?

headline: Appeals Court Revives Viacom Suit Against YouTube

abstract: The central bank of India, Reserve Bank, tells exporters to convert half of their foreign currency earnings into rupees.

headline: Burmese Are Wary of Tourism’s Dark Side

How can a tourist travel responsibly without enriching the very people who kept the country in the dark for so many decades? And will Myanmar avoid following Thailand and Cambodia into sex tourism?

abstract: Royal Bank of Canada has agreed to buy the 50 percent stake in RBC Dexia Investor Services that it does not already own for 837.5 million euros, or $1.1 billion.

abstract: Pastor Maldonado took his first Formula One victory. Then, a little over an hour after the race, as the team celebrated, there was an explosion followed by a fire in the team’s garage.

abstract: Shares in some of the Europe’s largest financial institutions fell as much as 8 percent on Tuesday as fears about the debt crisis re-emerged.

abstract: The Mac OS X Dock can automatically hide itself, whether you want it to or not.

abstract: The Larry (Ellison) versus Larry (Page) show closed out its first week inconclusively, and now likely moves into the technical weeds. But don’t be fooled: the right kind of decision in this trial could profoundly affect much of the tech industry.

abstract: Bank of America is exploring a potential sale of its foreign wealth management unit, after the business has failed to generate attractive returns, a person briefed on the matter said.

abstract: For the most part, the list of most-streamed songs for 18 cities in the United States align with standard pop charts. But the regional differences were revealing.

abstract: Senator Richard Shelby took aim at regulators on Tuesday in his opening statement at a hearing on MF Global, saying that missing customer money “reveals a serious regulatory failure.”

headline: Image of the Day: May 28
abstract: A Sufi festival in Rajasthan.

abstract: As Orthodox Christians the world over celebrate Easter this weekend, there are tensions within the Eastern Churches over religion and politics and the relationship with other faiths.

abstract: Brownface and fake Indian accent offend Indian-Americans.

abstract: Madison Avenue’s skepticism about Facebook. | High-end bicycles boom as Silicon Valley thrives. | For TV advertising, a disruptive technology.

abstract: Despite an international battle for preservation that lasted more than five years, the former United States Navy destroyer John Rodgers finally fell victim to the ravages of seawater and good intentions gone awry.

abstract: If love of mangoes is nearly universal in India, so is disagreement over which variety is best.

headline: Kerala’s Cochini Jews Meld Into Israel
abstract: A ‘hardy handful’ of Jews from Kerala immigrated to Israel.
