abstract: Variations of the 802.11 wireless networking standard have different ranges and throughput speeds.

headline: Research in Motion Projects a Quarterly Loss
abstract: Research in Motion, the beleaguered BlackBerry maker, has tapped J.P. Morgan Securities and RBC Capital Markets to assess its business and financials, and it expects to report a quarterly loss.

headline: Citigroup Wins Fed Auction for Maiden Lane Bonds
abstract: On Thursday, the Federal Reserve Board of New York announced that Citigroup had won an auction for $1.6 billion of assets, beating out six other financial firms for the bonds.

headline: Just a Minute: In Britain, The Sun’s Success Hasn’t Shifted to Sunday
abstract: Amy Chozick discusses the challenges facing a new Sunday edition of The Sun, the anchor of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspapers.

headline: Taking On Home Projects to Save Money
abstract: Better-off Americans are willing to take on do it yourself projects to save money, a new survey finds.

headline: Before Loss, JPMorgan Was One of Volcker Rule’s Fiercest Foes
abstract: JPMorgan Chase and its chief, Jamie Dimon, have been among the most outspoken opponents of the Volcker Rule, spending significant amounts of both money and time to get their message across.

headline: Digital Notes: Another Jolt to U.S. Case Against Megaupload
abstract: The search warrants used to carry out a raid on the service were found to be illegal, the chief judge of a High Court in New Zealand ruled. Also, Yahoo moves toward Spotify and iHeartRadio, and away from Rhapsody.

headline: Conan O’Brien to Appear on Letterman Show
abstract: Mr. O’Brien has often cited David Letterman as being influential to his career, and Mr. Letterman publicly sided with Mr. O’Brien in 2010 when NBC took the “Tonight” show away from him.

headline: Taking a Second Meeting With Dreve.me
abstract: Digging deeper into a new venture’s plans, including assessing three potential sources of revenue.

headline: Coty Tries to Rally Support for Avon Bid Amid Skepticism
abstract: If Avon Products’ stock price is any indicator, Coty still has some work to do in persuading investors in the cosmetics company to accept its $10 billion unsolicited bid.

headline: Dewey’s Bienenstock Discusses Law Firm’s Demise
abstract: The bankruptcy lawyer Martin J. Bienenstock acknowledged that the guaranteed long-term pay contracts given to partners were at the core of Dewey & LeBoeuf’s problems.

headline: Small Gain in Newspaper Circulations, Aided by Digital Subscriptions
abstract: Sunday newspaper circulation increased by a surprisingly robust 5 percent, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, while daily circulation increased less than a percent. The Wall Street Journal remained in the top spot with a total average daily circulation at 2,118,315.

headline: SAP and the Data Analytics Speed Race
abstract: SAP, the big German software company, has made an impressive, if late, entry to the emerging market for real-time data-analysis technology. Its real competitive advantage, analysts say, is the knowledge it has gained from its business applications stronghold, allowing it to show companies how to use “big data.”

headline: News Corp. Offers $2 Billion in Australian TV Takeover
abstract: The company’s proposed $2 billion takeover of Consolidated Media Holdings, the television business of the Australian billionaire James Packer, would help News Corp.’s Australian unit offset its reliance on newspapers.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: Consumers Getting Savvier About Credit Scores
abstract: Consumers are becoming savvier about their credit scores, new findings from the Consumer Federation of America show.

headline: In New York, Indian Mangoes Remain Elusive
abstract: Indian mangoes’ much-anticipated stateside debut has been less than spectacular.

headline: Kodak Concedes Difficulty in Drawing Lead Bidder for Patents
abstract: Eastman Kodak is seeking to set up a confidential auction for its portfolio of over 1,100 patents, after the bankrupt film pioneer acknowledged that it had encountered difficulty drawing a lead bidder.

headline: LinkedIn Tweaks Calendar Feature to Stop Taking Meeting Notes
abstract: LinkedIn said it would stop taking users’ meeting notes from their calendars on Wednesday, after security researchers discovered that the company was transmitting sensitive data back to its Web servers without users’ permission. The revelation came just one day before LinkedIn’s Web servers were breached.

headline: In Cambodia, Sentencing of Women Activists Sparks Outcry
abstract: The sentencing of 13 women, including a 72-year-old, after demonstrating on the site of their former homes in Phnom Penh prompts swift local and international criticism.

headline: Politico to Expand Its Subscription Service
abstract: Politico will start to hire more journalists this week in an effort to increase its coverage on the economy and the military.

headline: SXC Health Solutions to Buy Catalyst Health for $4.4 Billion
abstract: SXC Health Solutions agreed on Wednesday to buy Catalyst for about $4.4 billion in cash and stock, uniting two companies in the drug benefits management sector.

headline: How Fast Will States Recover Peak Employment?
abstract: A forecasting firm says that all but eight states will regain their prerecession job levels by 2015.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Chinese Interest in Movie Theaters, and the Beatles on TV
abstract: Also, how Joel I. Klein became Rupert Murdoch’s legal compass, and remembering the man behind many of the most popular TV game shows.

headline: Across India, Nepotism as a Way of Life
abstract: Politics, Bollywood, and overall success in India itself depend on family ties.

headline: Vikram Gandhi’s Documentary ‘Kumaré’
abstract: A film about the director who impersonated a yoga guru and imparted spiritual wisdom in Arizona.

headline: Ignoring the Real Money in the Bank of America Lawsuits
abstract: Law firms representing shareholders are fighting over a settlement in class-action lawsuits against the Bank of America board over its Merrill Lynch acquisition is adequate. But another federal securities lawsuit out there is where the real money is.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A regional round-up of news from across India.

headline: After JPMorgan Trading Debacle, a Chorus of Criticism
abstract: Since disclosing a $2 billion trading loss, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief, has been getting flayed for having been a vocal opponent of the regulatory reform while overseeing risky trades.

headline: Japanese Insider Trading Case Ensnares U.S. Firm
abstract: The Japanese financial regulator proposed a fine of $185,000 against First New York Securities for alleged insider trading, as part of a widening investigation into suspicious trading.

headline: A Conversation With : ‘The Meadow’ Author Adrian Levy
abstract: The release of men kidnapped in Kashmir was undermined at the the highest levels by India’s intelligence agencies and military, author says.

headline: Victory Spurs Talk on Bharara’s Next Move
abstract: Several top prosecutors for Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, have already left his office, and he appears to have switched his focus to cybercrime.

headline: Is My Family Business Going to Be an Orphan?
abstract: I am going to make sure that my family does not suffer any more consequences from being born (or married) into the chaos of entrepreneurship. At the same time, I am going to do everything possible to preserve the business for the sake of my estate and my employees.

headline: Tip of the Week: Caret Browsing
abstract: The caret browsing feature in Internet Explorer and Mozilla Firefox can make it easier to select text on Web pages for copying and pasting.

headline: Square Introduces a Digital Loyalty Card
abstract: On Tuesday, Square released software updates for Square Register, its iPad app that serves as a cash register for merchants. At the same time, it updated its Pay With Square app for customers with an iPhone or Android handset. The software upgrades will allow merchants to reward regular customers by applying discounts automatically when they return to the store.

headline: ‘National’ Loses Power as an Idea in India
abstract: The political supremacy of New Delhi and the central government is being challenged by state governments and other regional forces.

headline: Where Do We Go From Here?
abstract: It’s tempting to look at Friday’s weak jobs report and conclude that the economy has entered a significant new slowdown. But it may not be correct.

headline: What is the Ministry of Health Trying to Tell Doctors?
abstract: Deciphering the message behind recent reports that Indian doctors studying overseas will be forced to return home.

headline: Securities Law Ruling Creates Unintended Problems
abstract: In a 2010 decision, the Supreme Court changed the rules for when a securities lawsuit could be brought by an investor against a foreign entity. In effect, it took a sledgehammer to decades of case law with a ruling that lower courts are still trying to sort out.

headline: Netflix: Earnings Offer a Stream of Bad News
abstract: How Netflix, a nimble pioneer that changed the wheels on its business model while flying down the road, still managed to veer into the ditch.

headline: Young Photographer’s Death Has Some Worried
abstract: 22-year-old Tarun Sehrawat died of malaria while on assignment for Tehelka magazine in the forest-dense state of Chhattisgarh.

headline: Why the Next Jobs Report Matters More Than the Last
abstract: The May report, due Friday, will indicate whether the economic slowdown of March and April was largely a statistical blip.

headline: Daily Report: The E-Books Pricing Controversy Continues
abstract: On the Media Decoder blog, Julie Bosman of The New York Times reports on Barnes & Noble’s response to the Justice Department’s proposed settlement with publishers in its lawsuit over the pricing of e-books.

headline: ‘Dystopian Future’ Draws Problem Solvers to Mumbai
abstract: The landscape of the city and its challenges become a subject of discussion at seminars and exhibitions in Mumbai.

headline: KSL Raises Bid for Great Wolf Again, to $7.25 a Share
abstract: This latest turn of events comes less than 24 hours after Apollo Global Management raised its offer for Great Wolf to $7 a share, matching KSL’s previous bid.

headline: Channeling Iran in the High-Stakes Nuclear Talks
abstract: Iran’s chief negotiator, Saeed Jalili, is preparing his script for a meeting with world powers in Istanbul this weekend on his country’s nuclear program. Here is what might be — and not be — in it.

headline: Your Best Tip for Raising a Moneywise Child
abstract: Bucks readers — both parents and children — share the single best advice or wisdom that can turn a child into a master of money as a young adult.

headline: Daily Report: Questions of Fair Play Arise in Facebook’s I.P.O.
abstract: Lawmakers are questioning a process in which the banks involved in Facebook’s stock offering shared a negative outlook about the company only with select clients.

headline: Eduardo Saverin’s Billionaire Blues
abstract: When you have been very close to something that changed the world, it is not easy to make the rest of your life align with that experience. And for more than one billionaire, the money only complicates things. As Eduardo Saverin says, “You are always afraid.”

headline: We All Start Small
abstract: Housing prices may have finally hit bottom and even begun to recover, in the view of many experts. The latest figures from S.&P./Case-Shiller offer support.

headline: Flying the Facebook Flag
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, one of the underwriters for the social network’s initial public offering, decked out its headquarters at 270 Park Avenue in Manhattan with Facebook paraphernalia in anticipation of a visit from company management.

headline: Amazon Web Services Knocked Offline by Storms
abstract: Amazon Web Services, which stores vast amounts of data for companies worldwide, was knocked offline by electrical storms across the East Coast. The failure also took a number of sites, including Netflix, Instagram and Pinterest, offline.

headline: Average Household Feeling Less Distressed, Analysis Finds
abstract: A quarterly index finds improvement in average household finances.

headline: Pepsi and Twitter Announce Partnership on Ad Campaign
abstract: The initiative is part of Pepsi’s attempt to refresh its brand and take advantage of the involvement of young people on social media platforms.

headline: In Blocking Activists, the Fed Protects Poorly Performing Banks
abstract: In recent matters involving struggling banks, the Federal Reserve has sought to limit the ability of shareholder activists to nominate directors, which some investors view as an instrument of good corporate governance.

headline: The Surface: Celebrate the Competition, Question the Premise
abstract: Microsoft unveiled its new tablet, the Surface. There are many unanswered questions about it and some tough sledding ahead, but for the moment, we can celebrate the innovation.

headline: As Our World Shrinks, It Also Narrows
abstract: Even for travelers with unlimited budgets and time to roam, the world map is starting to look like a redacted Pentagon document, splotched with no-go areas.

headline: New Bankruptcy Documents Reveal Outsize Pay at Lehman Before Collapse
abstract: New documents from the Lehman bankruptcy case reveal the extraordinary compensation bestowed upon dozens of the bank’s employees in the years leading up to the investment bank’s demise in September 2008.

headline: Finding Ways to Protect an Investment in Horses
abstract: The Wealth Matters column looks at the risks of investing in racehorses, and Bucks readers offer their own tales of investing in a passion.

headline: Counting on Votes From Paris-on-Thames
abstract: If London’s French community had a city of its own it would be the size of Nice. Up to 400,000 French people are estimated to live in the British capital and candidates in Sunday’s presidential election cannot afford to ignore them.

headline: How I Fire People
abstract: If you are a boss, the day will arrive when you will have to fire someone. One subject that is not often addressed is the actual mechanics of the firing.

headline: Daily Report: App Developers Stick With Apple
abstract: Smartphones running Google’s Android operating system outsell iPhones more than two to one. But as Nick Wingfield and Brian X. Chen report in Monday’s New York Times, Apple has held onto one critical advantage even as Google’s system has surged: the loyalty of mobile app developers.

headline: Can Balotelli Make Italy Less Racist?
abstract: Italy’s hopes for a European championship are riding on Mario Balotelli. But, as a black man who has felt Italian racism, I can’t help but wonder if more is too.

headline: Mongolia Wrestles With Dinosaurs, NATO and Politics
abstract: Two events on Sunday, the sale of a Tyrannosaurus skeleton and a NATO summit in Chicago, promise to raise the global profile Mongolia.

headline: For Some Corporate Chiefs, Private Security Is a Tax Break
abstract: Dozens of corporate boards, including those of Halliburton, Kraft, Home Depot and Waste Management, insist or recommend their C.E.O.’s fly on private jets for security reasons. It’s a common corporate tax trick.

headline: The Short, Explosive Rise in Instagram’s Valuation
abstract: It’s safe to say that few companies have experienced as rapid a rise as Instagram, whose valuation has increased by 50 fold in little more than a year.

headline: NBC Announces 16 New Series for Fall Lineup
abstract: NBC’s plans for the fall 2012 television season include a host of new comedies and a dystopian drama, “Revolution,” created by J.J. Abrams of “Lost” fame.

headline: Glaxo Said to Aim to Replace Human Genome’s Board
abstract: The British drug company GlaxoSmithKline is looking to replace the board of Human Genome Sciences, the biotechnology company it is trying to acquire for $2.59 billion, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Prepaid Debit Cards: Here a Fee, There a Fee
abstract: Prepaid debit cards are becoming more popular but can carry hefty fees, according to a recent Consumer Reports analysis.

headline: Stores Go Online to Find a Perfect Fit
abstract: Traditional retailers like Nordstrom are tapping into the expertise of e-commerce companies like Bonobos, which in turn are learning the advantages of bricks and mortar.

headline: Jurors Begin Deliberations in Insider Trading Trial
abstract: Day 1 of deliberations by the jury of eight women and four men concluded without a verdict in the trial of the former Goldman Sachs director Rajat K. Gupta.

headline: How to Make Animations With the Jittergram App
abstract: Jittergram is a nifty free app that lets you make and share simple stop-motion animations using an iPhone. Here is how to use it.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Former Calpers Chief With Fraud
abstract: Federal regulators charged Federico Buenrostro, a former chief executive of the nation’s largest pension fund, with defrauding a private equity firm into paying $20 million to his friend.

headline: SolarCity Takes Step Toward Public Offering
abstract: The company, an installer of rooftop solar energy systems, has filed a draft registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: News Roundup: Deal on Night Raids, Marines in Australia, Iran’s Influence on Afghanistan
abstract: A deal seems close on night raids in Afghanistan, United States Marines arrive in Australia, and American officials see a pattern of meddling by Iran in Afghanistan.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: A Hot Time for Health Care Deals
abstract: Amid a weak merger market, drug makers are striking a flurry of deals, with Pfizer agreeing to sell its infant nutrition unit to Nestlé for $11.9 billion on Monday.

headline: Kabul Toasts the Queen With a Cool Drink, and the Fizz of Diplomacy
abstract: On an occasion of celebrating Queen Elizabeth II’s birthday at the British Embassy in Kabul, remarks tiptoed around Afghan, British and American interests, not always gracefully.

headline: Regulators Sue Silicon Valley Entrepreneur
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Benedict Van on Monday, accusing him of luring unsophisticated retail investors with “false and misleading” promises about start-ups that he claimed would be the “next Google.”

headline: With Nexus Q, Google Wants to Make Entertainment More Social
abstract: Google unveiled its new Nexus Q media player, a gamble that people are interested in making their home entertainment more social. At $299, the Q is pricier than competitors like Apple TV and Internet TV systems like Boxee. It is intended to make it easy to share content.

headline: Facebook vs. Twitter
abstract: In the world of social networks, Facebook and Twitter can be compared to the old children’s story “The Tortoise and the Hare.” But this race is not judged by speed but by the long-term relationship with users and their privacy.

headline: Airborne Tales of Fistfights, Diuretics and Crooning Pilots
abstract: A recent plane crash in Lagos and the failure of runway lights at the airport in Abuja have led to renewed concerns about air travel in Nigeria. A pilot for a major carrier says maintenance is slipshod, safety inspectors are bribed and pilots have behaved erratically in the cockpit. One pilot, with the plane being rocked by turbulence, began to sing to his passengers over the intercom. Share your own harrowing tales of air travel with us.

headline: Air India’s Boeing Showdown Could Be a Mistake
abstract: The Indian government’s latest fight with a foreign company may hurt Air India, analysts say.

headline: Twitter Empowers Engineers With New Patent Agreement
abstract: Twitter, in what it says is an act of good will to its engineers and designers, announced a new patent agreement that gives control back to inventors in potential patent legal suits.

headline: Daily Report: A Russian Tycoon and His Soon-to-Be Facebook Fortune
abstract: In Wednesday’s New York Times, Andrew E. Kramer tells the story of Alisher B. Usmanov, a Russian steel tycoon who made an ambitious bet on Facebook in 2009, in the midst of the global recession. That bet is about to pay off, to the tune of about $6 billion.

headline: Time Warner Cable Head Sides With TV Networks Over Ad-Erasing Technology
abstract: Glenn Britt, the chief executive of Time Warner Cable, said he opposed services like Auto Hop, introduced by the Dish Network, as a danger to the system that produces television programming and distribution.

headline: Regulators Defend Derivatives Rule
abstract: Regulators approved a rule on Wednesday that spells out the type of derivatives dealers that will soon face federal oversight, a crucial piece of the broader regulation for the market that played a major role in the financial crisis.

headline: Daily Report: Researchers Find Clues in Flame Virus
abstract: Security experts have only begun to examine the thousands of lines of code that make up Flame, a data-mining computer virus that has been designed to steal information from computers across the Middle East, Nicole Perlroth reports in Thursday’s New York Times. But already digital clues point to its creators and capabilities.

headline: Greetings From Afghanistan!
abstract: Even in Afghanistan, you can take away a picture keepsake of your stay. But be forewarned, most Afghan postcards don’t show sunny beaches.

headline: ARM in Partnership to Secure Mobile Payments
abstract: ARM, the London-based company that designs the chips in most of the world’s smartphones, announced a partnership with two other companies to improve security for mobile services for easier and safer payments by mobile device.

headline: KPN Rejects America Movil’s Official Bid
abstract: The Dutch telecommunications company KPN rejected an official offer from América Móvil, owned by the billionaire Carlos Slim Helú, continuing to say the $3.2 billion bid was too low. Now KPN shareholders will have a month to decide.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Closes 15th Fund at $525 Million
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, one of the old-line giants of the venture capital industry, has closed its 15th traditional fund at $525 million, the firm announced late on Thursday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Inside Anonymous and Inside Flickr
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes a new mobile camera app that can recognize faces and identify them, a tale of Flickr after Yahoo bought it and Leica’s black-and-white digital camera.

headline: Google Cuts Prices for Map Use by Site Owners
abstract: Google is bowing to criticism and defections and cutting the prices it charges for heavy use of its maps by Web sites. The price of a million downloads a day will fall to less than $500 from almost $4,000.

headline: At Milken, Feelings of Malaise
abstract: Judging from the mood of the attendees at the Milken conference, Wall Street is not the capitalist feeding frenzy it used to be.

headline: How the Banks Endangered Medicare
abstract: Banks’ out-of-control risk-taking and the government’s failure to rein them in created many problems, which critics of government spending are now using as an excuse to attack Medicare, an economist writes.

headline: Equality and Fraternity Through the Eyes of an American in Paris
abstract: On the eve of France’s presidential election, Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, takes a very personal trip back to his roots with a French television crew to explore the nature of opportunity in today’s France.

headline: Discovery Is Said to Pursue Revision3, a Web Video Company
abstract: While the possible purchase price is said to be relatively small — in the $20 million to $40 million range — it would represent an investment in the growing market of online video.

headline: Crisis and Aftermath, in Treasury’s Slide Show
abstract: A presentation on the depth of the financial crisis, the impact of the government’s intervention and the state of the economy is a political document that’s easy on the eyes.

headline: M.B.A.s Playing at Prime Minister
abstract: At a Madrid business school, international M.B.A. students simulate real-world policy making. Read D.D. Guttenplan’s story of a clash of global ideologies in the classroom.

headline: On ‘Greece-Proofing’ China
abstract: China urgently needs to “Greece-proof” itself to avoid powerful shocks that will come if Greece leaves the euro, a leading Chinese economist says, amid the sound of screeching brakes from the Asian giant’s economy.

headline: A Government Program That Could Improve the Economy
abstract: When the government kick-started the Internet and shared the GPS system with the public, it transformed the economy. Now it is opening up government data.

headline: The Taliban, in Their Own Verse
abstract: A new anthology of insurgent poetry, just published in Britain, is being received with both appreciation and anger. The poems themselves show how the Taliban’s public bravado and severe Islamic code are sometimes at odds with its fighters’ ruminations.

headline: Regulator Releases ‘Road Map’ on Swaps Overhaul
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission plans rules that will require companies to trade most derivatives contracts through regulated exchanges and force most derivatives deals to go through clearinghouses.

headline: Afghan Killings and an Amnesia Defense
abstract: A former military lawyer on why a case he worked on in the 1970s might shed some light on the coming defense of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales.

headline: Fox News Host Corrects Obama’s ‘Silver Spoon’ Quote
abstract: Steve Doocy of “Fox and Friends” acknowledged that he “did some paraphrasing that seemed to misquote the president,” by making a comment from Mr. Obama appear to be directed at Mitt Romney.

headline: Jobs Tracker Holds Steady
abstract: This week’s economic data have brought few surprises. The economy has weakened in recent months, but perhaps not as much as last week’s jobs report suggested.

headline: Next Up to Testify, Rupert Murdoch, Who Has Been Prepping
abstract: Rupert Murdoch arrived in London last Thursday with Joel Klein and a small coterie of advisers, lawyers and communications consultants to prepare to testify before the Leveson inquiry on press ethics.

headline: Products That Challenge RIM on Smartphone Security
abstract: Research in Motion has said the security of its smartphones is superior to that of its competitors’ phones. But companies specializing in security tools for Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android systems may give businesses another reason not to buy a BlackBerry.

headline: Eike Batista to Invest in Brazilian Music Festival
abstract: The Brazilian magnate is expected to announce Friday that he has purchased a 50 percent stake in the company that puts on Rock in Rio, a big music festival series.

headline: Disruptions: Too Much Silence on Working Conditions
abstract: Makers of tablets and devices could talk more about how they are monitoring their supply chain.

headline: Plagiarism Charge Against Elizabeth Warren Made, Then Quickly Dropped
abstract: The Corner blog of The National Review mixed up the original publication date of Ms. Warren’s book.

headline: The Best Cars for a Teenage Driver
abstract: Midsize sedans are a good choice for teenage drivers, says Edmunds.com.

headline: For Incoming International Students, a College Checklist for June
abstract: Kathy Steiner-Lang, the director of the Office for International Students and Scholars at Washington University of St. Louis, advises students to make their travel arrangements this month to prepare for college in the United States.

headline: AOL Patent Deal Does Not Appease Starboard
abstract: Starboard Value sent a letter to AOL’s board on Tuesday, to congratulate the directors on the patent sale to Microsoft, and to warn them of a coming proxy fight.

headline: Daily Report: A Device to Read Your Thoughts
abstract: The physicist Stephen Hawking is trying out a device the size of a matchbox that aims to allow him to communicate by merely thinking, David Ewing Duncan reports in Tuesday’s New York Times. The iBrain is part of a new generation of devices and algorithms intended to monitor and diagnose conditions like sleep apnea, depression and autism.

headline: Spanish and English Mix in a Web Telenovela
abstract: “Mia Mundo” will feature what Telemundo is calling “the new Latina,” and is using the acronym for Modern Independent Achiever, its desired viewer.

headline: Want to Place Bets on Facebook’s Next Acquisition?
abstract: As you may have heard, Facebook scooped up the profitless photo-sharing app, Instagram, for a cool $1 billion on Monday. Now some have started placing bets on which start-ups the social network will acquire next.

headline: Who Will Be Next to Call Nuclear Energy Indispensable?
abstract: Japan’s prime minister beseeches his people to allow nuclear plants to restart, even after Fukushima. Energy experts have been telling us for more than a year that the world had no non-nuclear option.

headline: R.I.P. Zune
abstract: Microsoft is phasing out Zune, a name that once symbolized grand plans to curb Apple’s entertainment ambitions. The Zune music service will be renamed Xbox Music, as Microsoft seeks to capitalize on the most successful brand in its consumer strategy.

headline: Energy Sector Deals Keep Coming, as Chesapeake Strikes 3
abstract: Struggling amid a surplus of natural gas and depressed demand, energy companies continue to look to deal-making to bolster their financial positions, with Chesapeake raising $2.6 billion with its latest moves.

headline: Tomorrow’s Privacy Struggles, On Display Today
abstract: AT&T Labs recently showed off a batch of prototype technologies, several of which serve as a window into how people will be able to track their friends and lovers with increased efficiency.

headline: How Elite Colleges Still Feed Wall St.’s Recruiting Machine
abstract: Until we address what is drawing students to investment banking, the brain drain to Wall Street won’t change, and Wall Street won’t, either.

headline: Pocket: The New Way to Read It Later
abstract: The popular time-shifting service Read It Later is now called Pocket, with new apps for iOS and Android that allow a user to save text, video and images found online for later offline viewing.

headline: As Men Turn to ‘Pink Collar’ Jobs, Training Is a Hurdle
abstract: Since 2000, men have increasingly entered occupations dominated by women, but with the onset of the recession they did so particularly in jobs with lower training requirements.

headline: Live Blog: Facebook’s Market Debut
abstract: Shares of Facebook are now trading on the Nasdaq market, the third largest initial public offering in United States history. DealBook’s live blog tracked all of the reactions to the I.P.O. throughout the day.

headline: Facebook Raises $16 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: The initial public offering, priced at $38 a share, values Facebook at $104 billion, putting the social networking company on par with McDonald’s, Citigroup and Amazon.com.

headline: A Sober New Reality in Credit Downgrades for Banks
abstract: Banking industry analysts think downgrades by Moody’s will cause lasting pain for some of the biggest American banks.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Ads, Ads Everywhere, and What Ratings Are Best?
abstract: Also, the Vatican hires a Fox News correspondent as a senior communications adviser, and a Web site that focuses on the Unites States Supreme Court gears up for a big week.

headline: How Do You Compete With FedEx and U.P.S.?
abstract: Rick Jones is trying to change the way Lone Star employees interact with customers.

headline: Monday Reading: Act Now to Go to the London Olympics
abstract: Act now to get tickets to the London Olympics, half of new college grads are jobless or underemployed, making progress against clutter and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: The Lessons of ‘Natural’ Disasters
abstract: TALCAHUANO, Chile — Reporters who cover world-class calamity see a clear pattern. Nature’s havoc is unpredictable and unpreventable. But death tolls that climb high into five and six figures are man-made.

headline: Lawmakers Push for a Final Volcker Rule by the Summer
abstract: The lawmakers who sponsored an effort to rein in risky trading on Wall Street are now urging regulators to finalize a forceful version of the Volcker Rule by the summer.

headline: Mortgage Servicers Face New Oversight
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is proposing new rules to tackle aggressive tactics and sloppy record keeping among mortgage servicers. Such companies, typically arms of the nation’s biggest banks, collect payments and handle customer service for mortgage lenders.

headline: Ackman’s Influence on Burger King’s Future
abstract: How is Burger King set to go public again, roughly a year and a half after it was taken private in a $3.3 billion leveraged buyout? The answer, in large part: the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman.

headline: Losing Faith in American Institutions
abstract: The downward spiral in Americans’ trust is not unique to government, though, and it’s also not terribly recent.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
abstract: Also, Jeffrey L. Bewkes makes a lot of money but he made a little less last year.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
abstract: Doing the math on how many new customers a deal must attract to succeed.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chairman gives his ukulele a workout in a duet with Jon Bon Jovi, just six months after a breakout performance celebrating the Chinese new year.

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
abstract: Todd Haskell and Andy Wright both received oversight of additional advertising categories with a focus on digital strategy and cross-platform sales.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
abstract: Bucks readers offer their opinions on classes that teach teenagers about spending, saving and investments.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
abstract: On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced a new initiative called “Girls Who Code.” By creating a mentoring and teaching program, they hope to increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Avengers’ Ascendant, and Rupert’s Twitter Tear
abstract: Also, “60 Minutes” is not looking its age, and a look at TuneCore, which has become one of the world’s major suppliers of online music.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks Information From British Inquiry on News Corp.
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who heads the commerce committee, has asked the Leveson inquiry for any information it has found that would be relevant in the United States.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
abstract: Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, succeeds Rohan S. Weerasingh, who recently joined Citigroup, a longtime Shearman client, as the bank’s general counsel.

headline: When Hillary Meets ‘Didi’
abstract: What will the most powerful women in India and the United States discuss on Monday.

headline: Vodafone Takes Legal Action Over Tax Proposal in India
abstract: The British telecommunications giant Vodafone said Tuesday that it had started legal proceedings against the Indian government over a proposed retroactive tax law that could cost the company more than $2 billion.

headline: China Demands Apology from U.S.
abstract: American and Chinese officials simultaneously broke the news on Wednesday afternoon that the blind dissident lawyer Chen Guangcheng had left the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. Within minutes, the Chinese followed up with a demand that the U.S. apologize for harboring Mr. Chen.

headline: A Shiny New Web Site for the S.E.C.
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has given its home page a face-lift, but it has the same functionality as the old bare-bones Web site, including the 1994-looking “next generation” search page for regulatory filings.

headline: On Keeping Medical Bills From Hurting Your Credit Score
abstract: Consumer experts offer advice on dealing with medical debts and making sure those debts don’t show up on credit reports.

headline: On Night ‘House’ Ends, NBC Is From Mars, ABC Is From Venus
abstract: The last episode of the Fox drama gave a bump in the ratings, while two competition shows skewed in opposite directions — “American Ninja Warrior” on NBC drew a male audience, while ABC’s “Bachelorette” drew women. They tied for the night.

headline: Q&A: Staying Secure on the Road
abstract: Hotel wireless networks can keep you connected when you travel, but be aware of security issues.

headline: S.E.C. Files Charges Against Father and Son, and Twin Brothers
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission brought two separate fraud cases on Friday that involved family members, including one in which twin brothers claimed they had a stock-picking robot named Marl.

headline: What They Said: India’s Changing Tax Rules
abstract: Finance Minister Mukherjee’s tax rollback was welcomed in some quarters and criticized in others.

headline: Inquiry Begins Into E-Mail Hacking at Sky News
abstract: The British news channel, whose parent company is part-owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, admitted this month that it had hacked into e-mails.

headline: Czechs Protest New Austerity Measures
abstract: Up to 90,000 Czechs, angered by austerity and corruption, marched in some of the biggest demonstrations in their country since the fall of Communism.

headline: Strong Profits on Wall St., and Markets Move Higher
abstract: Robust quarterly reports from Apple and Boeing echoed the general tone of company earnings, which have been beating analysts’ expectations this season.

headline: Chevron Misses Forecasts Despite Higher Oil Prices
abstract: Chevron missed first-quarter profit and sales estimates as falling production blunted the impact of surging oil prices

headline: Syrians Defy Leaders to Aid Those in Need
abstract: An increasingly organized underground network is providing food and medicine to people trapped by the offensive of President Bashar al-Assad’s government.

headline: Ads Advise Maximizing the Moviegoing Experience
abstract: A new campaign from Imax urges movigoers to watch large-format films for emotional rather than rational reasons.

headline: Gunmen in Afghan Police Uniforms Kill 2 NATO Soldiers
abstract: NATO did not confirm the nationality of the victims, but a spokesman for the governor of Helmand Province said that they were British soldiers.

headline: Pentagon Study Says China Military Getting Stronger
abstract: The annual appraisal of China’s military modernization also suggests Beijing leaders want to project power while avoiding confrontation with neighbors and the United States.

headline: American Eagle Looks to Sell Children’s Apparel Unit
abstract: The company said it was “exploring options,” including a full or partial sale of assets, for the 77kids by American Eagle brand, the company said in a statement.

headline: As Nuclear Talks With Iran Restart, New Hopes for Deal
abstract: Diplomats in Istanbul for the first talks with Iran in more than a year suggested an agreement by Tehran to let inspectors visit all its nuclear sites could open the way to more negotiations.

headline: Volatile Philippine Region Courts Tourists, Cautiously
abstract: Local tourism officials on the Philippine island of Tawi-Tawi are promoting the area’s sandy beaches, but violence and kidnappings pose a significant problem.

headline: Thousands in Cairo Protest Mubarak Aide’s Presidential Bid
abstract: Egypt’s rival Islamist groups drew supporters to Tahrir Square to protest against the presidential campaign of Omar Suleiman, the longtime spy chief under President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

headline: Kim Jong-un, in New Position, Promotes 70
abstract: The wave of promotions came as North Korea’s young leader was dealing with the aftermath of an embarrassing failure of a rocket launching.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: Carla Ballecer and Karen Gereffi joined Johannes Leonardo, New York, part of WPP, in new posts. Ms. Ballecer becomes a senior copywriter and Ms. Gereffi becomes a senior art director.

headline: Greece: Man Dies After Fall From Acropolis
abstract: A Greek man died on Thursday after falling from the Acropolis, the capital’s most prominent landmark, in what appeared to be the latest suicide linked to Greece’s economic hardship.

headline: KB Home Cuts Loss; Its Shares Rise 12.6%
abstract: The home builder reported increases in the number of houses delivered and sales prices.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Buys a Newspaper in Texas
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway said on Friday that it had agreed to buy The Waco Tribune-Herald, which has a daily circulation of 34,000, to expand in Texas.

headline: No Relief Rally on Greek Vote
abstract: Borrowing costs in Spain and Italy reminded investors that the troubles facing the euro zone were far from resolved. On Wall Street, stocks were flat and Treasury bonds were steady.

headline: Drug Kingpin’s Son Is Arrested in Mexico
abstract: Mexico’s navy said it had arrested Jesús Aflredo Guzmán Salazar, 26, “the presumed son” of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, nicknamed El Chapo, who runs the Sinaloa drug gang.

headline: Iran Recalls Its Ambassador From Azerbaijan
abstract: The ambassador in Baku was summoned home amid a series of protests and rising tensions over matters as varied as weapons purchases and the Eurovision song contest.
